column2: Sparks, Nev., was the scene of the recent 1971 United States National Open Chess Championship, an eight-round Swiss-system event, which attracted 134 contenders. It was held in John Ascuaga's Nugget.
BERKELEY, Calif., April 7 -Berkeley, seedbed of numerous political and cultural revolutions, might have started another new trend.
The RCA Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed to purchase the color picture tube manufacturing equipment of the Admiral Corporation.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, April 8 (AP) -- The South Vietnamese Government said today that the 100,000 American soldiers who will be phased out of Vietnam from May 1 to Dec. 1 "will be gradually replaced by our own troops."
ROME, April 7 -- A nationwide general strike, called for one day by Italy's three major labor organizations, disrupted industry today but caused little hardship for the public and tourists.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -The Securities and Exchange Commission has indicated, in a letter to a member of Congress, that it still believes that pricefixing of sales commissions on stock transactions probably should end at the $100,000 mark, rather than at the $500,000 level that went into effect this week.

ALBANY, April 7 -- The state has agreed to pay a South Mall contractor $51,973,000 more than his original contract called for because of construction delays that have plagued the massive state office building project here, state officials disclosed today.

A taxpayer fortunate enough to have some personal property that has increased in value, such as a painting, a stamp collection, a few acres of land or a summer home, can get a tax break if he arranges to sell to someone who will pay him in installments.

MOSCOW, April 7 -- The Soviet Union has announced the start of construction on a major oil pipeline from the great Samotlor field of West Siberia, the largest petroleum pool ever discovered in this country.

In a cool white room of clicks and hums, at precisely 11:41:37 yesterday morning, the IBM 360 on the left wrote: "Waiting for Work." The IBM 360 on the right, its associate, blinked 20 glass eyes and a man swallowed unnecessarily, and then it was 11:42:45 and the IBM 360 on the left wrote: "Job 20 is purged."

MIDDLETOWN, Ohio, April 7 (UPI) -- The Armco steel corporation today confirmed that it has raised prices of steel products used in the manufacture of electric power distribution equipment by $20 and $30 per ton.

It was probably to be expected that sooner or later Eileen Schauler would appear as Florinda in Ginastera's "Don Rodrigo," and, on Tuesday night in the performance given by the New York City Opera at the New York State Theater, she did it for the first time.
The London Stock Exchange weakened toward the close as buyers held off as the Easter holiday approached, and a few profit takers moved in.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -George Meany, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., accused the Administration today of pursuing a "double standard" in its economic policies -- one for labor and one for banks and big business.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Faced with the threat of another Presidential veto, the House rejected today a move that would have increased education appropriations $728.6-million above the Nixon Administration's requests.

Having had some experience as a prosecutor of war crimes, may I undertake to point out what seems to me to be some significant parallels between the public reaction to the Calley verdict and that of the German people to Nuremberg.

The extraordinary letter of Capt. Aubrey M. Daniel 3d, Army prosecutor in the Calley case, is at one and the same time a magnificent expression of American idealism and a stark and stunning indictment of the role played in this affair by Richard M. Nixon, President of the United States.
GIANGHIA, South Vietnam, April 2 -- Quangduc has the fewest people of any of the 44 provinces of South Vietnam, and if those who live there had their way it would be smaller by nearly half.
There has been a great deal of weeping and gnashing of teeth over the new Securities and Exchange Commission rule that forces corporations to report divisional sales to the S.E.C. annually.

Vera Chytilova is a Czechoslovak director, born in 1929, who has been making movies since the early 1960's. One of her features, "Daisies," played here in 1967, and I remember the episode as being the best thing in an omnibus film called "Pearls on the Ground," which was shown at the 1966 New York Film Festival.
LONDON, April 7 -- A beneficiary of the estate of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, creator of Sherlock Holmes, began legal proceedings here today to stop the quick sale of the author's copyright.
Bond prices climbed swiftly yesterday morning in a burst of enthusiasm that disappeared during the afternoon.

Auction records were posted last night for American artists from the 19th century to the 1930's. The sale was held at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, and grossed nearly $1-million in the first half of a sale of native works that will continue today.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -Senior military planners generally believe that President Nixon's announcement of substantial new troop reductions makes it clear that 1972 will be the riskiest year in Vietnam since disengagement started two years ago.
LONDON, April 7 -- The strike that has hit the Ford Motor Company's British operations for more than nine weeks ended tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The increasingly political debate over the court-martial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. took a new tack today as Democrats and Republicans clashed over whether President Nixon had improperly intervened in the case.
When midtown streets are silent under a hint of dawn, 28th Street and Avenue of the Americas is alive with gladioluses and chrysanthemums.
Feathered Ruler took kindly to the "off track" at Aqueduct yesterday and won the feature event.

A lawyer for a convicted heroin dealer told the State Commission of Investigation yesterday that his client had agreed to testify in open court against a former New York detective who was his admitted partner in a drug-trafficking business.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. -Mrs. Kirk Douglas glides from group to group in a quietly expensive tweed midi, Veronique Peck, in a suede shirtwaist and crocheted skullcap, blends elegantly with Gregory in his La Jolla tweeds.
PARIS, April 7 (Reuters) -- North Vietnam agreed today to resume the peace talks here tomorrow after a three-week interruption, a spokesman for the Hanoi delegation said.

A Bronx social-work executive was called by the defense of 13 Black Panthers yesterday in an attempt to rebut testimony of a police uncercover agent whom she had hired while he was posing as a Black Panther.
So, what are you going to do for an encore?
Volume declined and prices turned mixed on the American Stock Exchange yesterday as traders prepared for the Good Friday, three-day weekend. The Amex will be closed today.

An aide to Controller Abraham D. Beame who had a part-time outside job as consultant to a labor union has been cleared by the city's Board of Ethics of "any violation of the City Charter, Administrative Code or Code of Ethics."

Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday the closing of a 15-block portion of Madison Avenue in midtown Manhattan to traffic for two hours on each of five successive weekdays, as part of the city's observance of Earth Week.

Bulldozers were leveling the rubble of old fuel depots and junkyards yesterday along the Bronx bank of the Harlem River below Morris Heights for the formal ground-breaking next Friday for the first state park in New York City.

An audience at an auction of American paintings yesterday -- the last part of a sale begun on Wednesday evening -- bid enthusiastically on works that just a few years ago commanded a fraction of the $1-million spent in the two-day event.

The Norton Company announced yesterday in Worcester, Mass., the election of Robert Cushman as president and chief executive officer. John Jeppson, who was president, becomes chairman succeeding Milton P. Higgins who was made chairman of the finance committee. Mr. Cushman was formerly an executive vice president.

The 13th-century king of Castile and Leon, Alfonso X, was known as "el Sabio." This has been variously translated as "the sage," "the wise" and "the learned." The epithet was coined for his cultural interests, not for his disastrous political rule.

SANTIAGO, Chile April 8 -- The constitutional reform that President Salvador Allende Gossens has proposed to nationalize the copper industry was passed by the Chamber of Deputies with small but significant modifications.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- A Federal Court of Appeals rejected today the Nixon Administration's assertion that Federal agents may legally wiretap radical groups without court approval.

CHICAGO, April 8 (AP) -- With Bobby Hull and Stan Mikita scoring twice each, the Chicago Black Hawks stampeded the Philadelphia Flyers, 6-2, tonight to take a 2-0 lead in their Stanley Cup playoff series.

A healthy respect for history should make all who are concerned with the fate of Jerusalem take into account the fact that the Holy City is eminently and equally sacred to the three great religions, Judaism, Christianity and Islam -- citing them in the order of their appearance on the world scene.

When Howard J. Samuels woke up yesterday in his apartment on East 52d Street, he had a terrifying thought about the plunger who had waited all night at Grand Central Terminal to be the first legal offtrack bettor.

The retirement of Irvin S. Taubkin, director of public relations of The New York Times, and the appointment of William G. Blair as his successor were announced yesterday by Sydney Gruson, vice president and assistant to the publisher.

The time and place for the elimination chess series to determine the challenger for the world championship, now in the hands of Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, have been set and confirmed, according to Ed P. Edmondson, executive director of the United States Chess Federation.

PARIS, April 8 -- President Nixon's announcement of continuing troop withdrawals was described today by the North Vietnamese and the Vietcong as "a maneuver aimed at disguising the prolongation and widening of the war."

Having liked everything about "The Cubist Epoch," which opens to the public today at the Metropolitan Museum, I was surprised to learn that it came under critical attack during its run at the co-sponsoring institution, the Los Angeles County Museum of Art.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Representative Ogden R. Reid, the ranking Republican member of the House Foreign Opertions subcommittee, charged today in letters to two Administration officials that the treatment of Communist prisoners in South Vietnam represented a continuing violation of the Geneva Convention.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The military, political and economic situation in Cambodia has been deteriorating over the last two months, according to knowledgeable sources within the Administration.

A strike by 4,500 moving men entered its second week yesterday with neither side reporting progress in the continuing negotiations. The strike affects household and commercial moving in the five boroughs, Long Island, Westchester County and parts of the Hudson Valley.

MONTREAT, N. C. -- The first time I became suspicious that the United States might become involved in Indochina was in January, 1961. I had just played golf with President-elect John Kennedy, the then Senator George Smathers of Florida, and Billy Reynolds, president of Reynolds Aluminum.
Organized labor and churches have begun a drive to bring household workers into the labor movement.

The first telephone bet for the nation's first legalized offtrack gambling system was made by a woman with the code name of Goldfinch here yesterday at 10:44 A.M. She bet $10 on Title Song to show in last night's first race at Roosevelt Raceway.

The Grand Union Company which operates 574 supermarkets and general merchandise discount stores, had record sales and earnings for the fourth quarter and fiscal year ended Feb. 27, Charles G. Rodman, president of the chain, reported yesterday.
Two more of New York's principal banking organizations reported higher first quarter profits yesterday as declines in revenue were more than offset by lower costs for borrowed funds.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Representative John E. Moss of California has asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to let him know, mmediately, what justification it finds for continuation of the surcharge on stock transactions of 1,000 shares or less.

"There is something very special about these northern voyages," Samuel Eliot Morison casually remarks at the start of his account of the earliest explorations of the treacherous North Atlantic, where "anything might happen to you." And he's made a very special book about them. We're moved, to begin with, by its existence: a 700-page narrative from an 83-year-old historian who announces that it is the first, "God willing," of a three - volume study.

LONDON, April 8 -- Because some Elizabethan plays deal with the common life of the times, it is easy to read more realism into them than they actually contain. This temptation is stoutly resisted by John Dexter, whose production of Thomas Heywood's "A Woman Killed With Kindness" at the National Theater dwells more on re-creating a vanished society than on relating it to the world we know.

KENT, Ohio., April 8 (AP) -- The blame for the violence at Kent State University last May must be shared by the university and students, law enforcement agencies an dthe Ohio National Guard, according to four of the 12 members of a comission that investigated the disorders.

PULLMAN, Wash., April 8 (AP) -- Frank Heckl of Southern California registered his second upset in as many nights by winning the 200-yard free-style event tonight in the National Amateur Athletic Union short course swimming championships.

LAGOS, Nigeria, April 8 -- A Chinese Communist diplomat, Chang Li, came to this sultry capital the other day to open an embassy, establishing diplomatic relations with Nigeria and marking what many regard as a turning point in the Peking Government's relations with Africa.
With a pot of gold hopefully at the end of the line, the opening-day customers of offtrack betting at Grand Central Terminal waited as long as two hours yesterday to place their wagers.

MOSCOW, April 8 -- The 24th Congress of the Soviet Communist party neared its conclusion today with a final round of praise for the Kremlin's policies and a secret afternoon session for the formal selection of the party's Central Committee.

Vanja Orico, a Brazilian singer with many international films and Continental cafe appearances to her credit, made her New York debut Wednesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall. In a variety of folk- and pop-style pieces, including some fascinating chants in Indian dialect. Miss Orico proved to be a fine entertainer.
The turmoil in world financial markets during the last week led to a massive increase in the dollar holdings of foreign central banks, banking figures published yesterday showed.

Unlike most numbers games, the one now being played with the land claims of Alaska's native population promises more good than harm. As the figures rise, so do the possibilities that this country may treat the Eskimos, Indians and Aleuts of its northern reaches with the justice it denied to the Indians of its older states.

Whatever was to happen to William Calley, one result of the first Mylai trial was certain in advance: the United States Army was going to be found Guilty. The Army couldn't win. If Calley had been let off: a whitewash. If he had been (as he has been) condemned: a scapegoat for the higher brass.

For the watching this Easter and Passover weekend, there will be no dearth of special television fare. Most bases have been touched, from the Easter Parade to various church services to a Sunday afternoon showing of Pier Paolo Pasolini's stunning film "The Gospel According to St. Matthew."

According to a Defense Department announcement, the doctor draft has been resumed. Over 1,500 physicians will be drafted this year. Many of this group have already received their draft notices. Many are receiving them at this moment.

WOR-TV yesterday dismissed Lem Tucker as its director of news and public affairs. The action came the day after Michael McCormick, Channel 9's general manager, reportedly had been forced to resign because of his support of Mr. Tucker's news department against the station's parent company, R.K.O. Television.

SAN DIEGO, April 8 (UPI) -- Alex Hannum quit as coach of the National Basketball Association San Diego Rockets today to become head coach, president and general manager of the Denver Rockets of the American Basketball Association.

The Grumman Aerospace Corporation said yesterday that it expected to make a profit on its present contract to produce 38 F-14 Navy fighters, but acknowledged that it faced losses on subsequent production contracts without a price increase from the Pentagon.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Three Senate leaders said today that President Nixon indicated at a private briefing yesterday that he intended to withdraw all United States troops from Indochina by a specific date, but the White House vehemently denied it.

In his latest speech on the Indochina war, President Nixon said he would not set a specific date for "ending American involvement" in the conflict because this might put the remaining American troops in danger and interfere with the release of our prisoners of war.

SATKHIRA, Pakistan, April 8 (Reuters) -- Scores of terror-stricken families tonight fled this town in the Khulna district of East Pakistan amid reports that a Pakistani Army column was moving on the area.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (UPI) -- The Agriculture Department said today that 23 big farm operators got Federal farm subsidies of $500,000 or more in 1970 -- the last year the law will allow most of them to get such large payments.
PHILADELPHIA, April 8 -- A new cultural center, the $5.7-million Annenberg Center for Communication Arts and Sciences, was dedicated at the University of Pennsylvania today.
The following quotations from Puerto Rican children at Public School 15 on the Lower East Side have been taken from compositions compiled into a paperback called "Can't You Hear Me Talking to You?"

The Appalachian mountains are being destroyed by strip mining while conservationists in and out of government agitate for new laws to stop it. Ironically, effective legislation to save the hills may be available, though wholly unenforced.

Nearly 40 paintings, wood carvings, drawings and papiermache masks inspired by Central and West African motifs -- the work of 22 children of Intermediate School 201 in East Harlem -- went on display this week in the American Museum of Natural History.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (UPI) -- Suspected contamination of a large batch of chocolate candy and cake frosting was announced by the Food and Drug Administration today, a month after the hazard was discovered. The manufacterer said most of it had been eaten by now.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The Defense and Justice Departments said today that they had given up attempts to prosecute 15 former servicemen linked to the Mylai killings by Army investigators.
Two newcomers joined the cast of the City Opera production of "Roberto Devereux," Wednesday night, Sergio Di Amorim in the title role and Kay Creed as Sara.

In the fifties, during the development of the long-playing phonograph record, the Webcor name became one of the best known in the high-fidelity field. But time, events, and the increasing flow of Japanese electronics imports took their toll on Webcor.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Amidst 77 anonymous-looking men, four young women were graduated as sky marshals today after attending the Treasury Department's four - week training school.
The Madrigal Singers and University Choir of Washington University, St. Louis, sang at Tully Hall Wednesday night under the direction of Orland Johnson.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 8 -- President Nixon's announcement of the withdrawal of 100,000 troops by December created little stir in Saigon today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, April 9 -- The United States command reported today that 88 American soldiers were killed in combat in Indochina last week, the highest toll for a week in nearly 10 months.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The Post office Department announced today that it would immediately begin organizing a new security force to protect major postal facilities.
NEWARK, April 8 -- The Newark Teachers Union announced today that it would make no further proposals to end its 10-week-old strike until the Board of Education made a contract offer.
NEW DELHI, April 8 (Reuters) -- The Press Trust of India said Pakistan military forces launched a three-pronged attack today to establish control in the western region of East Pakistan.

KARACHI, Pakistan, April 8 -- The Pakistani Government announced today that it had mounted air strikes on "hostile pockets of armed infiltrators" in East Pakistan and had also raided "roadblocks erected by miscreants."

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- President Nixon disclosed today that he had decided to defer a decision on general import relief for the shoe industry, though he opened the way to "adjustment assistance" for 11 groups of workers in the industry.
When the sun sets today, Jews the world over will begin observance of the week-long festival of Passover, commemorating the liberation of the Israelites from Egyptian bondage.

There have been some hopeful developments recently on the problems of transportation and air pollution in the New York metropolitan area. Governor Cahill of New Jersey deserves congratulations for putting the Port of New York Authority on notice that it musk aid the mass transit situation; the extension of express bus service for commuters is good news, too.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 8 (AP) -- A New Zealand-born correspondent and a Japanese cameraman were listed as missing today, 24 hours after they disappeared during a battle.

New York City's two top financial officials are exploring, separately and with differing plans, the possibility of buying a New York Stock Exchange seat to save commission costs when pension funds buy stocks and bonds.
ROME, April 8 -- In an unusually bitter homily during Maundy Thursday rites today, Pope Paul VI likened defecting priests to Judas.
Roger S. Coleman of Hartsdale, N. Y., a former member of the New York Stock Exchange, has been censured and fined $10,000 in a disciplinary action, the Big Board disclosed yesterday.

For generations, most of the cantors who lead the musical part of Jewish services came from an elite group consisting of sons of cantors and devout youths who, from their earliest years, spent long hours singing in synagogue choirs.

The earth did not give way this week when the New York Stock Exchange abandoned the system of fixed commissions under which it had operated since its founding in 1792. To be sure, many brokers are extremely unhappy over the forced switch to negotiated commissions on the portion of orders over $500,000. They contend that this will slice deeply into their revenues and may drive some out of business.

Profit taking and evening-up activity, preceding the long holiday weekend, tended to consolidate silver futures yesterday and prices closed lower on the Commodity Exchange, Inc., here in moderately active trading.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury indicted five former officials of an Indiana manufacturing concern today for conspiracy to defraud the Government by making unauthorized welds on parts they were supplying for the F-111 military airplane.
NEWARK, April 8 -- Tens of thousands of this city's public school students have been playing hooky with impunity since the teachers' union strike began 10 weeks ago.

A policeman on his way to work yesterday rescued three-persons from a blazing three-story frame building on Staten Island. However, he was prevented by intense flames from saving two small children, who died in the blaze.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- There was general agreement here today that President Nixon gave a little ground last night to all the factions that have been tugging at his Vietnam policy.
The stock market showed little reaction to President Nixon's televised Wednesday night address on Vietnam as prices finished slightly higher yesterday in slower trading.
In a mildly scatterbrained way yesterday, the credit markets moved in several different directions.

MOSCOW, April 8 -- A sharp controversy between Soviet electric-power and farm interests over the use of the environment was disclosed today at what has otherwise been a harmonious Soviet Communist party meeting.

"I still believe in the long skirt, but we have to compromise," said Gustave Tassell, speaking of clothes for next fall. "Lots of skirts are to here," he said, drawing an imaginary line across his own leg, just below the knee.

The Defense Department's stepped-up conscription of young physicians "has placed thousands of sick people in New York City in serious danger," an organization of interns and residents declared yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 8 -- Pakistan charged here today that India was interfering directly in East Pakistan by using "armed infiltrators in plain clothes," by sending in truckloads of army and by massing six divisions on the border.

SAIGON, Friday, April 9 (Reuters) -- North Vietnamese gunners shelled an American helicopter base here today in South Vietnam's Central Highlands. About eight rockets and mortar shells hit Camp Holloway but no casualties or damage was reported.

With the competition down to four teams, the National Basketball Association playoffs resume today with the New York Knicks facing the Baltimore Bullets at Madison Square Garden in the afternoon and the Los Angeles Lakers taking on the Milwaukee Bucks at Milwaukee in the evening.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Pentagon generals and admirals, expert at feint and flank attack, have demonstrated in a series of bureaucratic skirmishes that they do not intend to be dominated by President Nixon's fledgling Office of Management and Budget.

John Cage's "Sonatas and Interludes," 20 pieces he wrote in the late nineteen-forties for piano whose sonorities he had altered by affixing a variety of hardware and software to the strings, do not often get a hearing.

Those who fail to survive the qualifying stage of a championship normally have the opportunity to compete in a consolation event. Experts who have had, the misfortune not to qualify usually spurn this golden opportunity and seek other forms of consolation.
The naive editorial "Congress and the Middle East" (March 26) appears in the company of such lucid articles as "The Bean and the Pill" and "Divided Command in Saigon." All is not lost.

The head of Trans World Airlines said yesterday that his company had been seeking a firm British European Airways order for the Lockheed airbus as part of an agreement for producing the plane with its original Rolls-Royce engine.

The recession is affecting several business lines of the Avco Corporation "and signs of a rebound are few in spite of some indications of a turnaround," James R. Kerr, president and Kendrick R. Wilson Jr., chairman, told more than 400 shareholders at yesterday's annual meeting held in the Everett, Mass., research laboratory.
Gary Gentry, who had difficulty finding an apartment earlier this week, had trouble finding the plate yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The Federal Home Loan Bank board announced yesterday another increase in liquidity requirements for saving and loan associations.

PHILADELPHIA, April 8 (UPI) -- The Penn Central Railroad told a Federal court today that 277 of its boxcars had been stolen in an elaborate plot executed by the tiny La Salle (Ill.) Railroad and two other concerns.
WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- Ten House Democrats said today that President Nixon's intervention in the Calley case had been "extremely improvident."

Concerts can be exciting, beautiful, stirring, stimulating and all sorts of other things. But they are not often joyful in the way that the one given by the New England Conservatory at Town Hall Wednesday night was.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- House Speaker Carl Albert said today that there was no evidence that the recession was ending, and that the House Democratic leadership, therefore, must initiate legislation to deal with it.
BERKELEY, Calif., April 8 -- "Haven't you heard?" Mrs. Ilona Hancock asked yesterday, "Berkeley is at least five years ahead of the rest of the country."

Military conscription has been part of the American scene for more than thirty years. Many of our law-makers appear to have become so habituated to the permanence of the draft that a great deal of the current debate over its extension does not focus on the heart of the question.
The restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored where indicated.

Yesterday morning at 10 o'clock Mrs. Anna Tannenberg, a 69-year-old Brooklyn housewife, became the one millionth visitor to the Brooklyn Museum this fiscal year, which ends June 30. It was the first time that the museum reached the million mark in attendance within one year since 1933, when, as one museum spokesman said, "people went to museums to forget about the Depression and get in out of the cold."
Despite a later Easter this year, consumer buying increased sharply last month in the stores of six of nine major retail chains that reported March results yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES -- In France of the Third Republic it was often said that the best profession from which to launch a political career was that of veterinary because it enables a candidate to insure the farmer's vote in his district. In most countries the law is considered the likeliest springboard but any aspirant for high office in the Argentine Republic might do well to start in an officers' academy.

DETROIT, April 8 -- The new black director of the General Motors Corporation has told his fellow directors he will vote against them and in favor of an Episcopal Church resolution calling on G. M. to close its plants in South Africa.
From May 10 to 15, hunters in New York State will once again have a chance to bag a bearded (male) wild turkey in all or parts of 16 counties.

Once there was a little murder mystery musical called "The Girls Upstairs" fermenting in the minds of playwright James Goldman and composer Stephen Sondheim. Now there is the smash hit musical spectacular "Follies" thriving at the Winter Garden.

Nicholas Doob, a 23-year-old student at Yale University, is still another gifted moviemaker in the worthy series at the Whitney Museum presenting new screen talent. His two pictures, the hour-long "Set-Up," and the 18-minute "42d Street Movie," opened yesterday and will run through Wednesday.
A 13-year-old Brooklyn boy was arrested yesterday after he allegedly shot three persons in a dispute between two families.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- President Nixon intends to issue a "clarification" of his intervention in the Calley case, White House sources said today.

The Milbank-Frawley Housing Council, which is financed by the city to develop housing plans in the Milbank-Frawley urban-renewal area in upper Manhattan, has moved to block the Department of Development from evicting 116 families from one of the sites in the area.

Paul Zindel's tortuously titled play, "The Effect of Gamma Rays on Man-in-the-Moon Marigolds," is just entering its second year of life. Now at the New Theater and with an entirely new cast, the production still stands as a glowing endorsement of the well-made play that is in fact well-made.

The House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee served a subpoena yesterday on the Columbia Broadcasting System to obtain all televised and untelevised materials pertaining to the network's controversial documentary "The Selling of the Pentagon."

WASHINGTON, April 8 (UPI) -- Richard G. Kleindienst, the Deputy Attorney General, said today that he never intended to suggest that Congress undertake a full-scale investigation into the operations of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

TOKYO, April 8 (AP) -- A report from Peking today said that the Chinese invitation to an American table tennis team was aimed more at building friendship between the two peoples than at improving relations between their governments.
In contrast to the milling throngs celebrating the arrival of offtrack betting at Grand Central and Forest Hills, a gathering of 24,043 enjoyed the expansive comfort of Aqueduct racing yesterday.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 8 -- An alleged terrorist bomber and bank robber was shot down in the Federal Courthouse here today while brandishing a sawed-off automatic rifle reportedly smuggled to him by his wife in their second escape attempt in a year.

A Manhattan district superintendent has refused to turn over last week's reading test papers of his pupils to Board of Education headquarters for scoring because, he said, the citywide tests were unfair to many children.

WESTBURY, L. I., April 8 -- Legalized offtrack betting got off to what Howard J. Samuels, its most enthusiastic proponent, described as a fantastic start, with $62,306 from two outside parlors wagered on the races at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
MINEOLA, L.I., April 8 -- State Labor Commissioner Louis L. Levine said today that he would ask the Federal Government to declare Nassau and Suffolk Counties high unemployment areas.

In what became the zaniest show on earth, with 17,250 fans cheering the loss of a mask in lieu of Toronto blood, the Maple Leafs stunned the Rangers last night, 4-1, to even their Stanley Cup playoff series at one game apiece.
SAN RAFAEL, Calif., April 8 -- The judge whom Angela Davis sought to have removed from her pretrial hearings ruled today that there was no reason why he should be disqualified from the case.

Cosmic ray tracks found in helmets worn into space by Apollo astronauts have shown that exposure to the heavier, more damaging rays was sufficient to raise a serious problem on long missions, such as one to Mars.

When Howard J. Samuels tried for the second time in 1966 to become New York's Democratic candidate for Governor, his promotional brochure carried the title: The Man With the Plan. An editorial reproduced in the brochure began as follows:

VIENTIANE, Laos, April 8 (Reuters) -- Eight persons, including several former high-ranking military officers, were reportedly under arrest today for their part in a proposed coup against the Laotian Government that was apparently called off at the last minute.

As a draft law is prepared, it is important to study the consequences of some provisions which might be included in it. One of these possible changes is the elimination of the 2-S Classification, the deferment for college students. At this very time many private colleges and universities are undergoing serious financial crises.
A restaurant chain jumped onto the OTB promotional bandwagon yesterday with an offer designed to appeal to losers.

Mr. and Mrs. Nick DeMartino of Brooklyn, whose 10-month-old adopted daughter Lenore the State Court of Appeals ordered on Wednesday to be returned to her natural mother, filed suit in Federal Court here yesterday to reverse the decision.
A lawsuit alleging that investors who bought odd shares between 1962 and 1966 were overcharged -- perhaps by as much as $20-million according to one estimate -- has survived another legal hurdle.

An estimated total of 50,000 or more people -- including Mayor Lindsay -- toured the International Automobile Show at the Coliseum yesterday, and parochial schoolchildren on the first of their Easter holidays swelled attendance.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 8 -- Ever since the afternoon in April, 1969, when he tossed away the lead and a chance win the Masters by taking bogeys at the last three holes, Charlie Coody has been wondering if he would ever have an opportunity like that again.

When a photographer was taking pictures of Maria Callas not too long ago in her suite at the Regency Hotel, she asked for time out for a drink of water. The photographer's assistant rushed to the serving pantry and brought back a glassful.

The New York-New Jersey port handled a total of 56,585,080 long tons in oceanborne foreign trade during 1970, the Port of New York Authority announced yesterday. This was an increase of 5 per cent over 1969.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- An official of the Environmental Protection Agency said today that the agency was convinced that the Union Carbide Corporation was making "a good-faith effort" to comply with a Federal schedule for reducing air pollution from its ferroalloy plant in Marietta Ohio.

PHILADELPHIA, April 8 -- Encouraged by what they consider a "philosophical shift," a group sponsoring a track and field meet here May 16 said today that it would "recontact" State Department sources about inviting a leading high jumper from Communist China.

Kurt Weill was possibly, very possibly, the finest composer ever to be associated with the Broadway musical. Apart from incidental music written for Max Reinhardt, the musical "Johnny Johnson" marked, in 1936, Weill's debut as a full-fledged Broadway composer.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 11 -- Ten British soldiers were injured in Londonderry today in rioting after two republican parades commemorating the 1916 Easter rebellion against the British in Dublin.

TORONTO, April 11 -- Jack Austin, the Canadian Government's chief adviser on energy matters, has outlined a development strategy that ties Canada's enormous untapped oil and gas reserves to America's growing appetite for these basic industrial and household fuels.
The historic heroism of the defenders of the ancient Dead Sea fortress of Masada and its relevance to modern Judaism was extolled last night in a specially written Passover Haggadah.
WASHINGTON -- Once you went to the supermarket and bought meat, green vegetables and fruit for dinner and you knew there was a good nutritional balance among the basic food groups.

MILWAUKEE, April 11 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Bucks shook off an outstanding performance by Wilt Chamberlain and defeated the Los Angeles Lakers, 91-73, today for a 2-0 lead in the four-of-seven-game Western Conference final of the National Basketball Association playoffs.

CHICAGO, April 11 -- Only a dusty nameplate distinguishes the aging building from others on its North Side Chicago block. Inside a modern-day band of monks has been putting into practice for the last five years its vision for an international, ecumenical church.

If a "no-fault" insurance program, as supported by The Times [editorial March 26] is instituted in New York State, it will overturn a system of jurisprudence that has prevailed in this country for over a century. SYRACUSE, April 11 (UPI) -Six person, including a Lutheran minister, were arrested today at the Roman Catholic Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception after walking down the aisle during an Easter mass carrying a wooden cross with a Vietnamese peasant hat attached.
I could not disagree more with the April 3 letter of Brig. Gen. Hugh Hester even though the general and I were fellow officers in the 12th Field Artillery in World War I.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Supporters of the Administration's plan to cut business taxes by about $3-billion annually struck back at critics today, contending that the basic economic health of the nation depended on the plan's being allowed to go into effect.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (UPI) -- The National Education Association today criticized President Nixon's plan to broaden Federal aid to private school students. It said the proposal would provide Federal money for all-white private schools in the South.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 12 -- An Iraqi Government spokesman said today that 16 Jews who had been arrested on charges of attempting to leave Iraq illegally had been released on bail.

BOSTON, April 12 -- A group calling itself the Citizens Commission to Investigate the F.B.I. says it has the names of persons who functioned as informers for the Federal Bureau of Investigation over the last few years.

First-quarter net earnings of the Libbey-Owens-Ford Company were $14,749,000, or $1.21 a share, more than double the $6,480,000, or 44 cents a share, of last year. They were 96 cents a share in the 1969 first quarter.

Back in the old days Eddie Brannick of the New York Giants would stand on his Polo Grounds parapet and gaze enviously across the Harlem River to the Yankee Stadium where the Bronx Bombers did their cannonading with considerable thunder and frequency.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 12 -- A home-rule message asking the State Legislature for permission to impose a real estate transfer tax in Nassau County was voted 3 to 1 today by the Republican-controlled Board of Supervisors.
A group of 30 scholars -all experts on East Pakistan -- have addressed an appeal to Pakistan's President for a truce and restoration of "legitimate and responsive government," in the East.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -- Thousands of children and a half-dozen clowns roamed the south lawn of the White House today in warm, sunny weather at the annual Easter egg roll.
The proving isn't over for the Rangers.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -The Chinese Nationalist Ambassador ended a six-year tour here today by sounding a note of concern about the Nixon Administration's policy of improving relations with Communist China.

EDGARTOWN, Mass. -Freeman Willoughby of the Edgartown post office recently reminded me that the early run of small striped bass should be off the south shore of Martha's Vineyard before the end of April.

PEKING, Tuesday, April 13 -The United States table tennis team visiting Communist China saw the Great Wall yesterday. Their hosts seemed bent on making a success of this venture into personal diplomacy.

NEWARK, April 12 -- Police Director John L. Redden warned today that "the guns are being loaded again by those who would plunge this city into the same type of apocalyptic convulsions it experienced in 1967."
NEW DELHI, April 12 -India now has 547 million people and 7 out of 10 cannot read or write, according to a preliminary report on the country's first census in a decade.

LOS ANGELES, April 12 (AP) -- A nationwide campaign to promote Mayor Lindsay for the 1972 Democratic Presidential nomination was announced today by a former campaign aide of Senator John V. Tunney, Democrat of California.
The Goldman Band will play its regular series of Guggenheim Memorial Concerts in Prospect Park this summer, Saturdays from June 26 through Aug. 14.
The murder and manslaughter trial of Mrs. Alice Crimmins took an unusual turn yesterday when the prosecution reopened its case to call a surprise witness.
A Federal judge here issued a preliminary stay yesterday to bar the return of a baby girl adopted by Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas DeMartino of Brooklyn to the child's natural mother.
The Mets, faced with legal action in New York over their rain-plagued home opener, arrived yesterday in Montreal to help the Expos open their third National League season today.
The John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company confirmed yesterday reports that its agents would soon have a new product to sell -- insurance on cars, homes and boats.
The Columbia Broadcasting System's documentary, "The Selling of the Pentagon," has won a special Peabody Prize award to be announced formally on April 21.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- A vacation in which scant attention was paid to the news may provide a poor perspective, but what offer a good one these days? And in the instant case, two strong impressions did work their way unscientifically through more personal concerns.
ALBANY, April 12 -- Governor Rockefeller signed a series of austerity bills today that cut state aid to New York City by $9.5-million and to the City University by at least $3-million.

ALBANY, April 12 -- Governor Rockefeller appointed Mario A. Procaccino, former New York Controller to the Battery Park City Authority today. Authority members received $100 a day when they work, with a maximum of $5,000 a year.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -The Federal Reserve? Open Market Committee voted in January to ease monetary policy further, partly in order to make up for a "shortfall" in the growth of the money supply in the final quarter of 1970, it was disclosed today.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 12 -- Official sources said today that Ceylonese security forces had gone on the offensive in efforts to suppress guerrillas, who are seeking to replace the Socialist Government of Ceylon with a more radical regime.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -The Securities and Exchange Commission warned the public today of risks it believes investors will be taking if they buy a new type of interestbearing security that will soon come on the market.
LONDON, April 12 -- Gypsies, plagued for years by hostile laws and harassment, are pressing for international recognition and a new consciousness of their plight across Europe.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The 22 American servicemen, including First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., who have been convicted of the premeditated murder of Vietnamese citizens were all sentenced to life in prison.

The commanding officer of the police precinct covering Greenwich Village was removed from his command yesterday after eight of his patrolmen were suspended on departmental charges of stealing cartons of meat from a packing plant.

KARACHI, April 12 -- The administration in Dacca, the capital of East Pakistan, announced today that Government troops had destroyed all "subversive elements" around a key railhead and it promised that the lives and property of "minorities and other people" in the eastern wing of the country would be protected.
The Toronto stock market was sharply higher yesterday in moderately active trading. The industrial index advanced 1.27 to 187.41, its highest level since Dec. 1, 1969.

KARACHI, Pakistan, April 12 -- The Pakistani Government announced today that it had received a note from Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China strongly supporting its efforts to put down a movement for autonomy in East Pakistan.

MOSCOW, April 12 -- The Soviet Union marked today the 10th anniversary of man's first space flight by Col. Yuri A. Gagarin on the Russian craft Vostok 1, and forecast that the next decade would be an era of manned space stations in earth orbit, and exploration of the moon and the planets by automatic stations.

The National Urban League yesterday released the report of an autopsy performed here on the body of Whitney M. Young Jr., the league's executive director. It attributed Mr. Young's death in Nigeria last month to drowning.

The sharp upward move in short-term interest rates led bankers to speculate yesterday that the prime rate -- the minimum interest rate on bank loans to business -- could move up a notch, despite a generally soft economy and weak loan demand.

" Hamlet," which was televised Nov. 17 as a "Hallmark Hall of Fame" presentation with Richard Chamberlain in the lead, walked off with 13 nominations in the 23d National Television Academy of Arts and Sciences Awards, which will be presented on the National Broadcasting Company on May 9.
PEKING, April 12 -- John Tannehill, a member of the United States table tennis team visiting here, says he has asked his Chinese hosts if he can extend his stay for a few weeks.

A 13-year-old Brooklyn boy was arrested on charges of arson and homicide last night in connection with a Bushwick tenement fire on March 28 in which a 40-year-old Fire Department captain, John Dunne, was killed when he entered the building to look for children who already had been rescued.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 12 -- Enemy forces in Cambodia are increasing their pressure on the 22,000 South Vietnamese troops there, while the Government forces still search for the momentum they lost seven weeks ago when their commander, Lieut. Gen. Do Cao Tri, was killed.
New York City sued yesterday to invalidate a state order that limits Medicaid payments for abortions for poor women to "medically indicated" cases.

The enduring popularity of Count Basie and his orchestra and of Ella Fitzgerald was made evident on Sunday when they gave two concerts to sell-out houses at Philharmonic Hall. They were received with cheering enthusiasm despite the fact that the performances of both Mr. Basie and Miss Fitzgerald have long since been boiled down to bland, unadventurous routines.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- A feeler from Hungary has raised once again the possibility -clearly still remote -- of membership in the International Monetary Fund by one or more of the Communist countries of Eastern Europe.
Turiana, a lightly raced filly owned by Calumet Farm, registered the second victory of her five-race career yesterday in the seven-furlong feature at Aqueduct.

First National City Bank announced yesterday the appointment of George C. Scott as vice chairman. Chairman of the bank's credit policy committee for the past four years, Mr. Scott will continue to serve as senior credit officer.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -The Civil Aeronautics Board told the nation's financially troubled airlines today that they could raise their domestic passenger fares by 6 per cent next month and could count on approval of an additional 3 per cent increase this summer.

MIAMI, April 12 (UPI) -- Firemen fought several small brush fires in dry, wind-whipped southern Florida today, while forecasters said it may be June before rain relieves one of the worst droughts in the state's history.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 12 -- United States planes are dropping seven-anda-half-ton bombs on North Vietnamese troops besieging a South Vietnamese outpost in the Central Highlands, American military sources said today.
PARIS, April 12 -- A twoweek effort by France's topranking diplomat to settle a critical dispute with Algeria has apparently failed.
The manager and part-owner of a small hotel that housed 13 welfare families at a cost of $4,000 a month to the city was arrested yesterday on bribery charges.

In a green station wagon with a microphone jutting four feet above its roof, noise-control specialist studied dials and jotted down figures yesterday in an attempt to set acceptable levels of noise in the city.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (UPI) -- In another concession to modern styles, the Army in January will stop issuing gray spectacle frames in favor of black plastic ones.

MINNEAPOLIS, April 12 -The Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, president of the University of Notre Dame, told Roman Catholic educators here today that today's students had demonstrated closer concern for the church's traditions of human dignity and human rights than had the Catholic schools.

A class action on behalf of all stockholders was brought against Sensitron, Inc., yesterday, charging the company with "acts, practices and courses of business, which operated as a fraud and deceit upon plaintiff and the class of plaintiffs in connection with purchases and sales of common stock and other securities of Sensitron."
In connection with your report on Mayor Lindsay's address before the Harvard Business Club of New York, regarding "runaway corporations":

WESTBURY, L. I., April 12 -- A review of OTB action tonight disclosed that the first four days of legalized offtrack betting resulted in the funneling of $309,654 into the mutuel machines at Roosevelt Raceway. On-the-scene betting over the same span reached an aggregate of $9,156,845.

Shareholders of Kansas City Southern Industries, Inc., yesterday approved a plan for the company to reacquire the 21 per cent of its shares held by the Lee National Corporation. The approval clears all but one barrier in the fight for control of the diversified holding company.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) Senator William Proxmire challenged today a wide range of military spending policies.

MOSCOW, April 12 -- Premier Kosygin met separately today with the Pakistan and Indian ambassadors as part of an apparently growing Soviet effort to seek a solution to the crisis caused by the civil strife in East Pakistan.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -Postmaster General Winton M. Blount announced today that next-day airmail delivery would be provided by July between principal cities no more than 600 miles apart.

JOHANNESBURG, April 12 (AP) -- The top-seeded Australians, Ken Rosewall and Mrs. Margaret Court, reached the quarterfinals of the $51,000 South African open tennis championships today.

DETROIT, April 12 -- Michigan's Governor proposed today a virtual end of the local property tax as the revenue source for public schools in the state.

The Commonwealth Edison Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the first quarter. WILMINGTON, Del., April 12 -- Shareholders of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. were told at the annual meeting here today that estimated earnings for the first quarter would be in the neighborhood of $1.50 a share, down 21 per cent from the $1.93 a share earned a year ago.

HONG KONG, April 12--Four Americans, held in a Chinese coastal village after their yacht had been seized, were released Saturday and permitted to sail back to Hong Kong, it was disclosed today. They had been two days out of Hong Kong on a trip to Okinawa when the vessel was seized.

Angel Espada, the welterweight champion of Puerto Rico, made his New York debut last night in the Felt Forum ring and scored a majority decision over Edmundo Leite, Brazil's welterweight title-holder.

The letter written by Capt. Aubrey M. Daniel 3d to President Nixon should be read and studied by everyone in America who is interested in the administering of justice. When the President long ago spoke about the need for lowering voices, Captain Daniel was one of those who took him seriously.

MONTREAL -- True, it is spring in Peking. But the glad spectacle of American, Japanese and other youthful foreigners playing Ping Pong in Peking and strolling among amiable Chinese crowds hardly represents a "departure" in policy for the Chinese. It does, however, draw spectacular attention to the sharp distinction the Chinese have always drawn between the friendly American and Japanese people on the one hand and their hostile governments on the other.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The American Society of Newspaper Editors is in Washington again for its annual skull practice, and this year it has some serious questions to discuss, for all news reporters and editors -- radio and television even more than newspaper -are under mounting pressure from all branches of the Government and from the public as well.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 13 -- The United States command soon will downgrade its command system in South Vietnam's two middle military regions to reflect the United States Army's transition from a combat role to a support and advisory function, military sources disclosed today.

DETROIT, April 13 -- The General Motors Corporation is sending a 49-page book describing G.M.'s work in air pollution, safety, abandoned car clean-up and minority hiring to its 1.3 million stockholders.

BALTIMORE, April 13 -Charles Wyche was acquitted yesterday on charges that he had been the gunman in the murder of a Black Panther sympathizer suspected of being a police informer.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation reported yesterday a gain of 13 per cent in firstquarter net income on a 4.8 per cent rise in sales.

The Metropolitan Opera will present a two-week June Festival of 14 performances beginning May 31 and continuing through June 12. Two performances of Verdi's "Aida," "Rigoletto," and "Il Trovatore," Puccinis "Madama Butterfly,' "La Boheme" and "Tosea" and Mozart's "Don Giovanni' will be presented.
Dr. Rollo J. Masselink, a neurologist, died at his home in Bronxville, N. Y. on Monday. He was 66 years old and lived at 150 Midland Avenue.

Wall Street girded itself yesterday for a crucial test of the concept of negotiated sales commissions on stock transactions, amid indications that a major rift over the issue had developed in the investment community. As of today, the membership of the New York Stock Exchange must accept or reject amendments proposed to the exchange s con stitution, providing for the abolition of fixed rates on the portion of all transactions above $500,000 in value.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 14 (AP) -- Prime Minister Sirimavo Bandaranaike has thanked "friendly countries" for supplying urgently needed equipment for her troops and policemen fighting youthful insurgents.
MOSCOW, April 14 -- A Soviet Union disclosed today that it had amended its aviation code to allow searches of airline passengers suspected on carrying weapons and explosives.

MOSCOW, April 14 (UPI) -- Scientific sources said today that the Soviet Union would send up at least two manned spacecraft within the next few days in a series of launchings to inaugurate the second decade of Soviet space exploration.
ALBANY, April 14 (AP) -- Assembly Minority Leader Stanley Steingut said today that he would seek legislation to extend unemployment benefits to jobless workers for another 13 weeks.
LONDON, April 14 -- Britain's largest industrial concern, Imperial Chemical Industries, announced here today that it would buy out Atlas Chemical Industries, Inc., of Wilmington, Del.

Saigon, April 14 (Reuters) -- The Third Marine Amphibious Force was deactivated today at a ceremony in Danang, where the marines first landed in March, 1965. The force, the largest ever deployed by the Marine Corps overseas, once numbered 80,000 men fighting the Vietcong in the five northernmost provinces of South Vietnam.

Federated Department Stores, Inc., which operates 194 retail merchandise stores including Bloomingdale's here and Abraham Straus in Brooklyn, lifted profits by 12.7 per cent in the fiscal fourth quarter, thereby reducing the fiscal year's decline in net income to 4.4 per cent.

A year-old experiment to stagger the hours of more than 60,000 people who work for 70 lower Manhattan concerns to reduce rush-hour subway and train congestion has been called a success. As a result, plans are being made to double the number of employes on the schedule.

Poetry is almost as popular as pot with the young these days. In the spring of 1969, at the Poetry Festival sponsored by Lehigh's School of Education, more than 1,000 people participated. A major issue in the Newark teachers' strike which began on Feb. 1 has been binding arbitration, which the school board claimed that neither it nor the community "could live with."

Last year one of the division managers at the Xerox Corporation decided that he should be devoting his life to something more worthwhile than helping one of America's giant corporations make more money.

New York University will not compete in basketball or track and field next season and will stop recruiting athletes for those sports at once, it was announced yesterday by Dr. James M. Hester, the university's president.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, April 15 (AP) -- An explosion rocked the Soviet trade delegation's building here early today and damaged the United States Consulate next door.

PARIS, April 15 -- France cut off further negotiations with Algeria today over their oil relations and indicated that the special ties between the two countries would now be put strictly on a business basis.

ALBANY, April 15 -- The State Court of Appeals today dismissed the convictions of two Yonkers men for assault and maiming on the ground that a four-year delay in bringing them to trial had "effectively deprived them of their constitutional and statutory right to a prompt trial."

The battle between the B. F. Goodrich Company and the Goodyear Tire Rubber Company for control of the Netherlands tire producer, N.V. Rubberfabriek Vredestein, continued stalemated yesterday after a Dutch court ruled that neither of the American companies could vote their shares in Rubberfabriek. The Dutch court ruling prevents both American companies from registering and voting their Vredestein shares and leaves the Dutch company in the hands of its management for the present.

Jane Fonda and Yves Montand have been signed to star in "Tout Va Bien" ("Everything Is Fine"), a feature film to be directed in English and French versions by Jean-Luc Godard, the controversial moviemaker who was a pioneering member of France's New Wave.

For the first time since they banded together 17 years ago to adopt a code to govern their industry, the country's major comic book publishers agreed yesterday to give themselves written permission to deal with the subject of narcotics.

PARIS, April 15 -- Xuan Thuy, chief of the North Vietnamese delegation at the peace talks here, returned to the conference table today after a sevenweek absence but he brought no change in his country's position with him.

To be reasonably effective, however, a bill must contain certain minimum provisions.

Good Behaving won the $112,200 Wood Memorial at Aqueduct yesterday, and managed to cloud the 3-year-old situation.

HONG KONG, April 17 -- The regional authorities in Communist China's Yunnan Province have introduced a crash course in reading for "illiterate workers and peasants" so that they will be able to study and understand the writings of Chairman Mao Tse-tung.
HANOVER, N. H., April 17 -- The board of trustees of Dartmouth College voted today to consider at its October meeting the establishment of an associated school for women.
PEKING, April 17 -- The transition in China from Canton to Peking is from provincial to metropolitan, from ordinary to grandiose.

Jewish leaders yesterday called on the Soviet Union to restore the cultural and religious rights of Jews and permit them to emigrate, particularly to Israel. Their appeals were emphasized by demonstrations at Hunter College and on Long Island.
TOKYO, Monday, April 19 (AP) -- Communist China charged today that a Soviet ship collided with a Chinese fishing boat in the Gulf of Tonkin on March 31 and that 11 fishermen were lost.

One of the most valuable functions of Lincoln Center's Chamber Music Society has been to present in tandem a a group of musicians who might not, under ordinary circumstances, join talents for an evening of music-making.

Enthusiasts in the city began Earth Week observances yesterday with a modest scattering of local environmental fairs and displays, a demonstration in the Bronx in behalf of bikes, and a 16-mile walk from the Battery to 110th Street and back for health research.

For Mrs. Julio Sabater the twice-daily walk between her home at 251 East 105th Street and the Union Settlement House at 237 East 104th around the block is a walk to friends, help, companionship and, in one sense, her freedom.

The Citizens Budget Commission yesterday attacked Mayor Lindsay's plan to impose a 6 per cent tax on advertising in media, based on the city audience of the media. The city promptly issued a statement defending the tax, which would be paid by the advertiser.
LONDON, April 18 (Reuters) -- A pay dispute today grounded at the last minute the first commercial jumbo jet flight by the British Overseas Airways Corporation.

CANTON, China, April 18 -- It would be presumptuous to make any sweeping generalities about China on the basis of a week's stay. I can only report on what I have seen in Peking, Shanghai, Canton and the areas around them. And I can make an appraisal of the moral, political and intellectual climate.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 18 -- As South Vietnam approaches its presidential election campaign, the voters -- whose ballot is compulsory -- voice a wide range of emotions, often tinged by deep weariness with war.

One day the New York Shakespeare Festival is going to have to give its Public Theater on Lafayette Street some such name as "Drama City -- the world's first theatrical supermarket." It has so many theaters honey-combed into the old Astor Library building that I often wonder whether any people find themselves in the wrong theater by mistake and unexpectedly end up watching, say, Siobhan McKenna instead of "Subject to Fits."

KARACHI, Pakistan, April 18 -- The Governor of East Pakistan, in a radio address tonight, called on absent East Pakistani troops, policemen and civil servants to return to duty and warned the populace not to harbor what he called "miscreants and fascists" in their homes.

Anyone who regularly reads the editorial page of The Times must be quite convinced by now that the alli. gator status here and elsewhere is our top national priority. How else can one otherwise explain several editorials dedicated to this subject during the past two years? These editorials reflected complete misinformation and, therefore, appear to be an attempt to create confusion in the public mind in the hope of arousing sufficient indignation to influence legislators.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. said today that he would not make the Federal Bureau of Investigation a target of his inquiry into Government surveillance unless he saw some evidence of illegality first. He said he had not found such evidence in nearly three years of search.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Improvement of the environment, which formally preempted national attention for only a single day last year, is the focus of a week of activities across the country starting today.

Mayor Lindsay yesterday ordered the elimination of more than 800 full-time and 2,000 part-time and temporary city jobs, effective May 1, and said he would make public "staggering" potential cuts today for the budget year starting July 1.
BOSTON, April 18 -- This city went into mourning today: the Montreal Canadiens eliminated the beloved Bruins from the Stanley Cup playoffs of the National Hockey League.

ESTES PARK, Colo., April 18 -- The White House Conference on Youth began tonight in this isolated mountain resort with an observer remarking, "The biggest authority symbol the kids can march on here is the Rockies," towering majestically just to the west.

BALTIMORE, April 18 -- What seemed so amazing only one week ago seemed perfectly natural today as the Baltimore Bullets ripped apart the New York Knicks, 113-96, and evened their National Basketbal Association playoff series at three victories each.

PITTSBURGH, April 18 -- Last week's inflation alert produced no big reaction in the steel markets. Steel users were alerted to the probability of future price increases sometime ago. By last week, users were well along with programs aimed at hedging against both steel inflation and a possible steel strike Aug. 1.
JERUSALEM, April 18 -- Israel's policymakers speculated today about the possibility that Egypt's proposed union with Syria and Libya could block the pending moves toward a negotiated peace.

When Phil Ochs appeared at Carnegie Hall a year ago he was wearing a gold suit and leading a rock band. Many of those who bought tickets to hear the protest singer sing his familiar quiet songs were outraged.

Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally Jr. has put forward a plan to ask Congress to authorize guarantees of $250-million to $300-million in loans to the financially shaky Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, top industry sources said last night.

New York Hota roached the Eastern final of the United States Challenge Cup for the first time by defeating Taunton, (Mass.), 4-1, in the second overtime period yesterday. Five of Hota's players had played for the New York Cosmos Saturday night in St. Louis.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., April 18 -- More than 10,000 advocates of peace in Indochina gathered today on the steps and lawns of Rhode Island's Capitol for the kickoff of a national "Dump Nixon" campaign.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 16 -- An Asian population growth that will crowd China and India with more than 1 billion people each in less than 30 years is forecast by latest United Nations calculations. More than half the world's population is expected to be in South and East Asia.

BOLOGNA, Italy, April 18 -Prof. Fritz Machlup of Princeton University today warned a conference of some of the world's leading monetary authorities, meeting here at the Bologna Center of the Johns Hopkins University, that the rapid and uncontrolled growth of the Eurodollar market could lead to "very severe trouble."

In the forefront of chess activities among the top echelon players, the Byrne brothers, Robert and Donald of New York and Pennsylvania, respectively, have accumulated many accolades. Robert, a 43-year-old grandmaster, recently led a six-man round robin in the fourth Goldwater -Marshall international of 1971. His score was 3 1/2-1 1/2.

MILLBROOK, N. Y., April 18 -- Terri Cunningham piloted Indiscretion to the regular working hunter championship at the Bennett College spring horse show today after a hackoff with Mrs. Karen Bacon's Academy Award.

DETROIT, April 18 -- Fiftysix of the 269 Roman Catholic schools of the Detroit archdiocese will be closed at the end of the present term, John Cardinal Dearden, the Archbishop here, announced last night.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., April 18 -- A bomb squad from Fort Monmouth, agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the local police sought clues today in the rubble left by an early-morning explosion at the Jewish Center here.

The end of the eleven-week Newark school strike is a victory for reason in a situation that threatened the survival of that troubled city. Primary credit for the settlement belongs to Mayor Gibson, whose refusal to surrender to coercion by black militants resulted in a compromise formula reasonable enough to win ratification by two-thirds of the Board of Education.

Spurning what would appear to be a normally high noon-hour traffic, the two Gucci leather goods and fashion stores at 689 and 699 Fifth Avenue close their doors every day between 12:30 and 1:30 P.M. Customers may knock but they can't get in.
Interpublic, which is very big overseas, will soon be bigger. It has worked out a deal to buy a group of English ad agencies, an Italian ad agency and a British public relations company.
SHANGHAI, April 18 -- A view from one of the city's tall buildings makes it easy to accept the official statement that Shanghai is the premier industrial city of China.
RALEIGH, N. C., April 18 (UPI) -- Kathy Whitworth posted a three-under-par 69 in the final round today to win the Raleigh golf tournament for her first victory of the season.
There is a new kind of crime on the city's college campuses -- crime that frequently goes unreported by its youthful victims but is nonetheless spreading fear through the university community.

HONOLULU, April 17 -- The music, first heard in the mind of Johann Sebastian Bach, was coaxed from a piano by a young man, bare to the waist, whose long, sun-bleached hair almost touched the keys as he leaned down in concentration.

Dennis C. Stanfill, who earlier this month was appointed chief executive officer of Twentieth Century-Fox in all but name, intends to push a major restructuring of the giant motion picture producer and distributor.

Today is a religious holiday in Boston. More people will attend its rites than went to church on Easter Sunday. Though the Massachusetts calendar reads "Patriot's Day," the anniversary of Paul Revere's ride is merely a pretext. The real occasion is the seventy-fifth running of the Boston Marathon.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 18 -- The Ceylon Government today named a seven-member committee to "re-establish civil authority" in areas affected by two weeks of insurgent activity.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 18 (AP) -- Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky said today that it would take 15 or 20 years before South Vietnam was capable of defending itself, but he added that the current pace of American troop withdrawals was "reasonable."

A major crisis with Japan that could damage American security interests severely is looming as a result of President Nixon's decision to hand back Okinawa by treaty, rather than executive agreement. A treaty would require a two-thirds Senate vote; the alternative course would require at most a majority vote of both houses of Congress.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) -- Secretary of Transportation John A. Volpe's newest assault in the battle of the billboards still has not toppled a sign, but it has won praise from Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson.

WASHINGTON -- For more than two decades American officials have provided a vast range of rationales for our involvement in South Vietnam. But only one consistent theme emerges: to permit the South Vietnamese freely to choose their government. President Nixon has reiterated this American objective.

BARCELONA, Spain, April 18 (UPI) -- Jackie Stewart of Scotland defended an early lead against a strong challenge from Jackie Ickx of Belgium today and went on to win the Spanish Grand Prix. It was his third straight victory in the event and it gave him the lead in world driver standing.

PARKERTOWN, N. J., April 18 -- A wind-whipped forest fire burned out of control over 10,000 acres of sandy pine forest near here today, forcing authorities to close sections of the Garden State Parkway.

Richard Joyce Smith, the trustee of the New Haven Railroad Company -- largely a corporate shell -- is considering a proxy fight against management of the Penn Central Company, the holding company that owned the Penn Central Transportation Company before it filed for trusteeship last June.
BASEL, April 18 -- Central bankers of the major industrial countries looked at ways to increase their influence over the volatile dollars that were behind recent disorders on the currency exchanges.

The rector, wardens and vestry of St. Thomas Church, one of the most influential Episcopal parishes in the nation said yesterday that they had lost confidence in the top management of their denomination and feared an ever-widening "credibility gap" between national headquarters and the church membership at large.

Your recent editorial emphasizing that governments everywhere must adopt a strong position toward kidnappers so that political kidnapping might be curbed is a timely call for international action against this rapidly spreading threat to organized social life.

The greatest surprise since the annual international Martini Rossi fencing competition made its debut at the New York Athletic Club 11 years ago was turned in last night by a quiet-mannered, 19-year-old premedical student from France.
BALTIMORE, April 18 -- The Yankees received rough treatment here today as the Baltimore Orioles shelled four New York pitchers for 15 hits and an 11-6 victory.
To Thomas M. McKenna, the young, new supervisor for the city's 35 settlement houses, social work in the neighborhoods is just now returning to patterns established a generation ago.

Even if attitude changes were as easy as Mr. Ubell implies, the fact remains that there are hundreds of thousands of people who require treatment for alcoholism now.

The city has adopted a new policy that emphasizes renewing whole city blocks in rundown areas under its loan program for rehabilitating housing. In the past, the program's low-interest loans went for projects involving only one building on a block.
Three veteran professors -- a historian, a social studies educator and a mathematician -- have been named to receive New York University's Great Teacher awards for 1971.
Alex Johnson, a polished hitter and a questionable fielder, and Frank Healy, a rookie catcher off to a fine start, figured prominently yesterday in baseball's version of the California gold rush.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 18 (UPI) -- An excommunicated Roman Catholic priest called a halt today to a fund-raising drive by parishioners intended to ease his way into a new career.

New York City's request for nearly $880-million in new taxing authority leads a long list of unfinished business for the State Legislature, which will resume its session tomorrow after a 12-day recess.
The city's poor and disadvantaged appeared likely to feel sharply the economies ordered by Mayor Lindsay yesterday to meet the crisis caused here by cutbacks in state revenue-sharing.

To celebrate the second annual Earth Week, which begins today, recipes using natural ingredients might be appropriate on the family menu. Such "earth foods" will be prepared by Bow Ross, a cooking consultant, in the Gourmet Kitchen at Abraham Straus throughout the week.

The Citizens Committee for Children of New York announced its opposition yesterday to an adoption-reform bill pending in the Legislature that would establish a 30-day time limit in which a mother could revoke her permission to give up her child for adoption.

NORTH WILKESBORO, N.C., April 18 (AP) -- Richard Petty sped past a faltering Bobby Isaac shortly after the halfway point and breezed to an easy victory today in the Gwyn Staley Memorial 250-mile stock-car race.

While American environmentalists press for tighter regulation of shipping in coastal waters to prevent oil spills arising from collisions and groundings, the British have been agitated by a similar problem arising from tanker accidents in the Dover Strait outside their territorial seas.

PENSACOLA, Fla., April 25 (AP) -- Gene Littler, a bland, unemotional professional with 18 years on the tour, shot a closing four-under-par 67 and won the $30,000 first prize by three strokes in the Monsanto open golf tournament today.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (Reuters) -- Representative Pauu N. McCloskey of California today called on President Nixon to end what he said appeared to be the deliberate destruction of Laotian villages by calling an immediate halt to bombing throughout Indochina.

NEW DELHI, April 18 -- The predominantly East Pakistani staff of Pakistan's diplomatic mission in Calcutta took over the establishment today and transformed it into a mission of the newly proclaimed provisional government of Bangla Desh -- the Bengal Nation.

TEL AVIV, April 18 -- They were scrubbing the marble floors and carefully dusting the gnarled bronze statues by Jacques Lipchitz. A scaffold obstructed the glass entrance and light fixtures were sprawled along the large plaza leading to the modern new building of the Tel Aviv Museum.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 18 -- Brazilian security forces announced today that they had killed the leader of five leftist terrorists who had slain Henning A. Boilesen, Danish born Brazilian business leader.
JACKSON, Miss., April 18 -- James Charles Evers became the first Negro candidate for Governor in the 154-year history of this state today.
MOSCOW, Monday, April 19 (UPI) -- The Soviet Union launched an orbital scientific space station today. The announcement by the Tass press agency did not say whether the station was manned.

CHICAGO, April 18 -- Again delivering in the clutch, a new habit, the Rangers began their Stanley Cup semifinal series with the Chicago Black Hawks tonight the way they had ended the series against the Toronto Maple Leafs -- with an overtime victory.

A year ago Americans were observing their first Earth Day.
