HARRIMAN, N. Y., April 18 -- Wider latitude for the transportation industry in setting passenger and freight rates was recommended here today by a group of over 60 influential conferees, many from outside the transport field.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Ralph Nader, a persistent critic of the automobile industry, and 39 members of The Yale Law Journal urged the Federal Trade Commission today to investigate the industry's practice of changing the styles of cars every year.
TEL AVIV, April 18 -- The police said today that they had thwarted an Arab guerrilla plot to explode incendiary bombs throughout Israel during Passover, when there were many tourists in the country.

KIETA, New Guinea -- One of the world's last frontiers, the vast Australian - administered tropical area known as the territory of Papua and New Guinea, is moving swiftly toward independence despite extraordinary physical and cultural impediments to nationhood in this wild, hot, malarious, violent and beautiful country.

Mario Bernardi, conductor of the National Arts Center Orchestra of Canada in Ottawa, made his New York City Opera debut at the New York State Theater Saturday afternoon leading Mozart's "The Abduction From the Seraglio."
The chairman of the city's new Taxi and Limousine Commission suggested yesterday that some crosstown streets in mid-Manhattan be reserved for taxis, buses and commercial vehicles.

LAVANG, South Vietnam, April 18 -- The joint American and South Vietnamese invasion of the enemy-held Ashau Valley will not get under way until Wednesday at the soonest, according to ranking American military sources here at the operation's forward command post just south of Quangtri.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The first contingents of an expected total of 1,500 Vietnam war veterans began arriving here this afternoon in preparation for a week-long series of antiwar protests named Operation Dewey Canyon Three.
Ramsey Clark, the former Attorney General, reiterated yesterday his denial of having any kowledge of governmental surveillance of political dissidents while he served in the Johnson Administration.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 18 -- The Arab world reacted favorably today to the federation announced yesterday by Egypt, Syria and Libya, and saw in it strength for the Arabs against Israel.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- "It's business as usual, no problems at all. We're just going about normal tasks."

CAMBRIDGE, England -- The distinguished white-haired gentleman, a Fellow of Trinity College, led the way into the library designed for Trinity by Christopher Wren. Then he apologized for having to rush off.

The spring national championships of the American Bridge Association that ended in Cleveland yesterday were the biggest in the history of the Association, which provides primarily for black players. In four days, the number of tables in play was more than 1,200.

NEWARK, April 18 -- The bitter 11-week-old Newark teachers' strike ended today when the Board of Education and the Newark Teachers Union voted to accept a contract proposed by Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson.

The United States balance of payments showed further deterioration during the first quarter to a record deficit on the official-settlements basis, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company reported over the weekend.

ATHENS, April 14 -- Two prehistoric wall paintings, spectacularly restored after lying buried for 3,500 years under volcanic ash on the Aegean island of Thera, have been put on display for the first time at the Athens Archeological Museum.

A syndicate of major banks, led by the Chase Manhattan, is being formed to assist in the refinancing of F. I. du Pont, Glore Forgan Co., a major brokerage firm that is emerging from financial difficulties.

Daily newspapers across the country gained circulation, revenues and jobs last year, and should show "modest but steady growth" again this year, the American Newspaper Publishers Association reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The Peace Corps' director of minority affairs has resigned his post and filed a formal complaint with the Civil Service Commission, accusing the Peace Corps of discrimination against women and minorities.

BOSTON, April 18 -- Mrs. Sara Mae Berman is not among the official 1,067 entries in the 75th annual Boston Marathon tomorrow.

MILWAUKEE, April 18 (AP) -- Pulling away in the second half, the explosive Milwaukee Bucks crushed the Los Angeles Lakers, 116-98, today and won the National Basketball Association's Western Division final playoffs, 4 games to 1.

MOSCOW April 18 -- The Soviet Union today hailed the proposed new federation, of Egypt, Libya and Syria as a major gain toward ultimate victory over the forces of aggression, Zionism and neocolonialism in the Middle East."
American corporations continue to head doggedly to the bond market to borrow, and the expected cutback in financing activity so far shows no signs of developing.
ROME, April 18 -- The Government is investigating the leak of a secret report by its chief representative in Milan on illegal private armies organized by leftist and neo-Fascist extremists.
Riddle for balletomanes: What is the same but different and new but older? Answer: Germany's Stuttgart Ballet, which opens tonight at the Metropolitan Opera House for a six-week season.

The New York Mets and Pittsburgh Pirates divided a windswept double-header before 51,905 persons in Shea Stadium yesterday and broke off their first encounter of the year on even terms after four games.

ST. LOUIS, April 18 -- The headquarters of the Teamsters Union Joint Council 13 is right next to the campus of St. Louis University, but yesterday was the first time that students and workers had come together to find out what they had in common.

SEOUL, South Korea, Monday, April, 19 (AP) -- South Korea plans to withdraw an infantry division from South Vietnam before the end of this year, Foreign Minister Choi Kyu-Hah said today. The withdrawal would involve 13,000 to 15,000 of the 50,000 South Korean troops now in South Vietnam.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., April 18--"Hey, you guys aren't the fascists I thought you were," a bearded Princeton senior said in great amazement to a trim, blue-uniformed cadet at the Air Force Academy here.

Eight persons were arrested on gun charges yesterday following the murder of a West Coast Black Panther official whose bound and bullet-riddled body was found in the burned ruins of the party's office in Corona, Queens.

When Robert Puleo's boy soprano changed not long ago in mid-season, the New York City Opera had an unusual casting problem. WASHINGTON, April 18 (UPI) -- With less than 36 hours before the deadline for voluntarily reaching its first contract agreement with the new United States Postal Service, seven postal unions accused Postmaster General Winton M. Blount today of a "public be damned" attitude in reaching a settlement.

CARACAS, Venezuela, April 18 -- The Chase Manhattan and First National City Banks are once again showing their sharp division in thinking about banking in Latin America. This time it is their separate approaches to the problem of rising nationalism in Venezuela.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Key staff members of all the major securities industry organizations will meet with the Securities and Exchange Commission tomorrow in an attempt to decide how close the industry may be to a recurrence of operational and financial problems and what should be done about them.

SEOUL, South Korean, April 18 -- A crowd estimated at half a million people today heard Kim Dae Jung, the chief opposition candidate for president, bitterly attack what he called Government corruption.
AMMAN, Jordan -- Worry beads, the small strings of beads that Arabs have long loved to fidget with, are showing signs of going out of style.

Bond prices tumbled across a broad front yesterday, apparently because of a growing belief that the long-awaited economic upturn is finally at hand.
A flower show for people without gardens opened yesterday at Gimbels.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- A State Department spokesman said this morning that the United States had no official confirmation of reports of Premier Lon Nol's resignation.

ALBANY, April 19 -- Sponsors of a bill that would have nearly tripled the late State Senator Edward J. Speno's death benefits prepared today to amend it to reduce the death payment by $135,285 to about $80,000.

PORTLAND, Me., April 19 -- A petition by Lever Brothers to stop Federal Trade Commission proceedings on a proposal requiring detergent makers to list ingredients on packages and display pollution warnings in advertisements was dismissed today in United States District Court.

SHREVEPORT, La., April 18 -- Seven hundred construction laborers and their families here, who are enrolled in the nation's first test of prepaid legal insurance, are demonstrating that blue-collar families are not inclined to become legal hypochondriacs when their legal costs are covered by insurance.

Improved weather conditions in the winter-wheat areas of the country, coupled with reports of a decline in Canadian stocks, sent prices of wheat futures plunging yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.
HEREFORD, Tex., April 19 (UPI) -- A tornado cut a seven-mile trail through Hereford early today, injuring 40 persons and causing $2-million in damage. No deaths were reported.

WASHINGTON -- It is difficult for an American to second-guess an election in the United States. All the more so when he tries to predict one abroad. SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, April 19 -- A proposal to reduce military expenditures in Latin America, presented by Colombia and Costa Rica to the general assembly of the Organization of American States, was criticized strongly by Brazil and Argentina today.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to consider a Government attempt to outlaw as anticompetitive an exclusive system of private-brand merchandising by an association of small supermarkets.

NEWARK, April 19 -- Barringer High School in this city's North Ward opened its doors on schedule this morning for the first school day after the 11-week teachers' strike. For the principal, teachers and students, it was a day of indecision, resentment and drift.

CHICAGO, April 19 (UPI) -- The Illinois Pollution Control Board levied a $149,000 fine today against an asphalt roofing plant in Joliet, which it said discharged as much untreated waste into the Des Plaines River as a city with a population of 90,000 without a sewage treatment plant.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court denied today a hearing to a group of New York air traffic controllers who were disciplined by the Federal Aviation Administration after a nationwide walkout on March 25, 1970.

BALTIMORE -- Today, air pollution endangers our health. Tomorrow it may endanger our survival -- or so we are often told during Earth Week. A few of the sternest ecological prophets are measuring the life expectancy of the human race in decades. Air pollution, they caution, may make this generation of Americans the last.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 19 -- There are times when, as a young officer put it, the war in South Vietnam resembles an old film running backward.

ESTES PARK, Colo., April 19 -- As if the White House Conference on Youth were not isolated enough in this mountain retreat 1,500 miles from Washington, heavy snow fell this morning, marooning the conference and its delegates.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (Reuters) -- The State Department today denied charges by Representative Paul N. Mc-Closkey, California Republican, that the United States was embarked on a policy of systematically wiping out Laotian villages by bombing.

Former Representative Richard L. Ottinger opened a campaign yesterday that would involve New Yorkers in withholding a portion of their payments to the New York Telephone Company until service is upgraded.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The nation's manufacturing industries operated on the average at a slightly higher percentage of capacity in the first quarter than in the final quarter of 1970, the Federal Reserve Board reported day.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., April 19 -- In a tough speech extolling "the dignity and the value" of hard work, President Nixon said today that the success of his welfare reform programs would be measured "by the dignity it promotes and not by the dole it provides."
Charles B. McCoy was elected yesterday as chairman of the board of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., succeeding Lammot du Pont Copeland Sr., who did not stand for re-election.
Germany's leading ballet company, the Stuttgart Ballet, arrived back in town last night at the Metropolitan Opera House with its sumptuous and dramatic version of "Eugene Onegin."

HARRISBURG, Pa., April 19 -- The renewal of a Federal investigation by a grand jury that indicted the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan and others was delayed here today because the Federal Government appeared unprepared to deal with legal issues involved in the attempt to question new witnesses.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Yigal Allon is expected to give details tomorrow of Israel's position on an agreement to re-open the Suez Canal when he meets with Secretary Rogers.

Agreement in principle was announced yesterday to merge the Granite City Steel Company, the nation's 14th largest steel producer, into the National Steel Corporation, which is ranked fourth. The companies outlined an exchange of stock that would be worth about $88-million.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 19 -- The Mirage issue, which led to the revival of French influence in the Arab world under Charles de Gaulle in the wake of the 1967 Arab-Israeli war, may now cause the opposite effect, observers here felt.

VIENNA, April 19 (Reuters) -- Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, arrived in Sofia today at the head of a large Soviet delegation to attend the 10th congress of the Bulgarian Communist party opening there tomorrow.

Considerable interest has been created by remarks of Clifford Roberts, tournament chairman of the Masters golf tournament held annually at Augusta, Ga., concerning the absence of black competitors in this prestigious event.
Kentucky Derby fever began rising here yesterday, both on the track and off the track.

Although the Department of Agriculture has many experienced officials and its Agricultural Research Service includes many scientifically learned men, they are remarkably slow learners about environment. For more than fifteen years, they have been spraying various chemicals on the land and water of several Southern states in a futile effort to kill the fire ant, a not very important agricultural pest.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., April 19 -- Vice President Agnew expressed misgivings today about the visit to China of the United States table tennis team and the apparent thaw in relations between the two countries.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 20 -- Government reconnaissance troops were reported pushing through the Ashau Valley yesterday in preparation for an allied drive against that long-time enemy stronghold near the Laotian border.
Major segments of the American motion picture industry are turning away from the detailed exploration of sex that has marked some recent feature films.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Liberals in the House, backed by a broad range of national organizations, will move within the next week to increase the Federal investment in the welfare reform bill now scheduled for floor action next month.

Kinney Rent-A-Car will announce today a multipronged expansion effort that its chief, Harold L. Oshry, hopes will put it in the top five by 1975. By that time the company expects to have its own operation in 52 cities and franchises in 225.

The Venezuelan Minister of Mines and Hydrocarbons, Dr. Hugo Perez La Salvia, came to New York yesterday to tell American consumers that the oil-producing countries should not be held responsible for recent and future petroleum product price increases.

WEST TISBURY, Mass, -- Every outdoors writer should live in the country, close to the source of his inspiration, but there are times when one yearns for the classic simplicity of a New York apartment.
The most dynamic stock-market recovery in more than three decades kept rolling forward yesterday and, in the process, is passed a milestone.
The oarsmen at Columbia yesterday sent $50 they had collected to the University of Wisconsin, whose athletic director, Elroy Hirsch, has threatened to drop crew in a budget cut.
Members of the Railway and Airline Clerks' Brotherhood went on strike yesterday against REA Express in a dispute over the company's establishment of 17 new highway runs in the Northeast.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 19 (UPI) -- Ron Bryant, taking over in the first inning after Frank Reberger hit a batter and walked one and then left the game with a sore shoulder, pitched the San Francisco Giants to a 4-2 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals today for their ninth straight triumph.
Years ago American Telephone and Telegraph was a favorite of the mutual funds. Then the funds became disillusioned.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, April 19 (UPI) -- President Anastasio Somoza Debayle of Nicaragua says he expects to see a stronger two-party system and elections routinely witnessed by observers from the Organization of American States following constitutional reform here.
GENEVA, April 19 -- A Swiss engineer admitted today that Israel had paid him nearly $200,000 for blueprints of an engine used in the French Mirage jet fighter.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI) -- Senator Vance Hartke, Democrat of Indiana, and Senator Strom Thurmond, Republican of South Carolina, announced today that they will write a bill that would maintain a veteran's pension rights if Social Security or other Government pensions increase.
DETROIT -- "The strongest muscle in my body is my mouth," said Dollie Cole, and there may not be many of the Motor City's auto rich who disagree.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Governor Rockefeller urged organized labor today to reverse its position and support the Nixon Administration's plans for sharing Federal revenues with state and local governments.
Jane Russell, the film star, will make her Broadway debut in the role of Joanne in the Harold Prince musical, "Company," on May 10, succeeding Elaine Stritch.

Jim Ryun has agreed to compete against Marty Liquori and possibly Kipchoge Keino in the mile run at the International Freedom Games in honor of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr, on May 16 at Franklin Field, Philadelphia.
HAMDEN, Conn., April 19 -- A 23-piece jazz band and an experimental quintet carried off top honors last weekend at the Quinnipiac College intercollegiate jazz festival.

Reacting sharply to announced cutbacks in city jobs and the threat of mass layoffs, the largest union of city employes isued an angry call yesterday for a mass rally at City Hall and a "march on Albany" next Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI) -- Senator James B. Allen, Democrat of Alabama, opened the Senate's first civil rights debate of the year today with a charge that the Federal establishment makes school integration demands on the South that it does not enforce in the North.
Tile Chrysler Corporation reported yesterday a profit of $10.8-million, or 22 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1971.

It should surprise no one familiar with the Greenwich Mews Spanish Theater that the city's only year-round bilingual acting company has done right by "Yerma" in an English-language version. Even to come close to the passion, poetry and economic structural drive of the great Garcia Lorca's text is no mean feat. See what this excellent unit has done at its attractive, downtown lair, 141 West 13th Street.

OLD FIELD, L. I., April 19 -- Dr. Edmund D. Pellegrino, dean of the State University Medical School at Stony Brook, said today that he had discontinued discussions with the Nixon Administration about becoming the Government's top medical officer.

A crowd of 2,500 showed up early at the Felt Forum last night, bought all 301 of the special "lunch-and-punch" chicken dinners on sale, then stayed late to see a local bantamweight favorite, Davey Vasquez, score a seventh-round technical knockout over Chuck Spencer of Cleveland.

GENEVA, April 19 -- Sir Eric Wyndham White, the former international officer who took over the troubled Investors Overseas Services last year, has now completed his withdrawal from the mutual-fund complex.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The antiballistic missile debate began again in the Senate today with many of the same arguments but little of the enthusiasm or organized opposition of past years.

It is shocking that the Pakistani Army and its political leaders have been maligned in the April 10 letter "Home Rule for Bengal." The Pakistani Army has been accused of "systematic killing of civilians and wanton destruction of properties."
KARACHI, Pakistan, April 19 -- The Government charged today that "armed Indian nationals'' supported by artillery fire from Indian territory attacked a border post in East Pakistan Friday.

Customer accounts of the First Devonshire Corporation, an insolvent former member of the New York Stock Exchange, are being transferred out of the firm to other brokerage houses under a stipulation reached with the exchange, the firm's receiver and its creditors.

NEWARK, April 19 -- About 100 teachers who took part in the 11-week Newark teachers' strike were prevented from returning to their classrooms in six separate schools here today by the president of the Board of Education and groups of parents who said they did not want the teachers back.

SHANGHAI, April 19 -- A small group of foreign newsmen, including this correspondent, two Japanese, one Swiss, three Britons and four Canadians, today started a four-day program that promised to give them the most extensive look at affairs in Shanghai, China's largest city, that any journalistic group has had in recent years.

Back in 1965 Congress passed the Highway Beautification Act, a law to remove all billboards from rural sections of the interstate and primary highway systems. Only now, six years after enactment, is there real promise that the law is to be obeyed. Secretary of Transportation John A. Volpe is making sounds indicating that at long last action is to be taken to remove these illegal eyesores.

Mayor Lindsay warned yesterday that he would eliminate 90,000 city jobs, as the most drastic of four alternatives open to the city, unless the State Legislature restored its cuts of city funds and increased the city's taxing powers.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced last night the arrest of two suspects in last week's robbery of a bank on the Fort Hamilton military base in Brooklyn.
Prices were mixed on the American Stock Exchange yesterday after some late selling pressure reduced the sizes of the earlier gains.

The "dynasty" of the New York Knickerbockers, established amid such excitement last May, ended on its 346th day last night as the Baltimore Bullets completed an uprising against great odds and eliminated the defending champions from the National Basketball Association playoffs.
JERUSALEM, April 19 -- Israel gave the United States her long-awaited "ideas and proposals" today for achieving an interim arrangement with Egypt to permit the re-opening of the Suez Canal.

The Population Council outlined a plan yesterday for providing maternity care and birth control services to people of underdeveloped countries throughout the world at a projected annual cost of 60 cents a person.

The Carnegie-Mellon University Kiltie Band was on hand in Carnegie Hall Sunday night for its fifth annual New York concert. This is a remarkable virtuoso assembly of 100 student musicians, and if their program was designed more to show off the band's capabilities than to present an evening of musical sustenance, few would have complained in the face of such impressive playing.

The Southampton crowd, which tends to be very enthusiastic about paintings, stood around the Bodley Gallery last night, saying nice things about Maria Cooper Janis. And well they should. The elegant Mrs. Janis is one of their own. She's also an artist.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- The Internal Revenue Service recommended today that millions of Americans increase the sums withheld from their paychecks for income taxes this year. If they do not, the agency said, they may have to pay large additional amounts to meet their tax bills next April.
MOSCOW, April 19 -- An unmanned research workshop launched by the Soviet Union this morning into orbit around the earth is expected to become a manned mission.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Tuesday, April 20 -- Lieut. Gen. Lon Nol resigned today as Premier of Cambodia. The general, who is 57 years old, cited health reasons in a letter to the Head of State, Cheng Heng.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The United States is delivering 12 more Phantom fighter-bombers to Israel and is considering a request for more, according to Administration officials.
LONDON, April 19 (UPI) -- Shareholders of Rolls-Royce, Lt., have agreed to a government investigation of the company's affairs, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Major securities industry organizations and the Securities and Exchange Commission agreed today that there are no widespread operational problems in the industry that would require general restrictions on stock trading.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 16 -- There are moments of great peace and beauty in the Bluegrass Country when one can stroll near shaded pastures, close enough to reach out and touch a possible Kentucky Derby Winner. COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 20 -- The Soviet Union was reported today to be providing Ceylon with six MIG-17 jet fighter planes, along with air and ground crews, to help fight ultraleftist insurgents.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- State subsidies appeared today to offer a substantial chance of closing the 525-mile gap between Buffalo and Chicago in the National Railroad Passenger Corporation's planned service when it starts operation May 1.

Press. The President announced the appointment of Neal Ball, 35 years old, of Chicago, to be a Deputy White House Secretary. Mr. Ball joined American Hospital Supply as an assistant in public relations in 1960 and became director of public relations and advertising in 1965.
OTTAWA, April 20 (UPI) -- The Government has ordered a formal inquiry into the four-day riot at Kingston Penitentiary that left one inmate dead and 11 wounded before it ended abruptly Sunday.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- While cases of venereal disease are increasing nationally to a degree that alarms experts, the resources available to deal with this serious health problem have been decreasing, specialists said here today.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The Secretary of Transportation expressed willingness today to compromise on whether "no - fault" automobile insurance should be mandated by Federal law.
Mayor Lindsay officiated last night at the opening of this spring's first weekly Madison Avenue Magic Promenade. He arrived 25 minutes late at 61st Street and Madison Avenue for the ceremony.

ALBANY, April 20 -- The Public Service Commission today warned the state and local governments, including New York City, that antipollution measures directed at utilities could result in utility rate increases or a reduction of electrical generating capacities.

Washington is following a dangerously short-sighted policy in continuing to insist that the Pakistani military government's slaughter of democratically elected leaders and repression of the majority of its population in East Pakistan is strictly "an internal matter." SHANGHAI, April 20 -- Mrs. Hu Fang-tsu was emphatic about it. "Children are a lot of trouble," she said. "Nobody wants very many of them any more." The leader of a production team in the Machiao commune in the countryside 18 miles west of Shanghai, the 35-year-old Mrs. Hu has one child, and she and her husband have no plans to add another.

When the protagonist of a novel has a name like Chance, you know you're in for some heavy furniture moving. Every action, every speech has to be rearranged around that name. In whatever Chance does, there is more than meets the eye. The reader dutifully squints through his cardboard 3-D glasses to discover what's really going on.
Major changes in police methods to prevent the use and sale of heroin here were announced yesterday by Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy.
The nation's newspaper publishers announced plans yesterday for a campaign to strengthen "public understanding of a free press" and to develop "thinking and informed readers."

JERUSALEM, April 20 -- Jorge Luis Borges, the grand old man of Argentine letters, accepted the Jerusalem Book Prize last night with some gentle advice to writers -- avoid politicizing literature lest you muffle "the divine whispering of the muse."

DUBLIN, April 20 (Reuters) -- A visiting British Navy survey launch, the Stork, was seized during the night from its mooring in the harbor of Baltimore, near Cork, towed to sea and destroyed with explosives, police sources said today. No one was aboard at the time. Part of the boat washed ashore later.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The drama and the politics of today's Supreme Court decision on school desgregation lie in the fact that Warren E. Burger has refused to take his guidance from the President who made him Chief Justice.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- The Army is going to allow its female officers and enlisted women to have children.
The American Stock Exchange turned in its worst performance in almost two months yesterday as the list declined on moderate trading.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- A former Superintendent of New York City schools urged Congress today not to block establishment of an experimental program under which parents would "buy" education for their children in either public or private schools.

NORMAN, Okla., April 20 (UPI) -- The long search for a new president of the University of Oklahoma officially ended today with the naming of Paul Sharp, president of Drake University, to the position.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- President Nixon announced today that he would confer with farm leaders on domestic and foreign issues on May 7 as a "Salute to Agriculture Day."

ATHENS, April 21 -- Greek leaders, celebrating their fourth year in power, outlined tonight what they called their chief goals.

The Temporary Study Commission on the Future of the Adirondacks ceased to exist as an official body on April 1. Last December, the commission sent to the Governor, along with its report, suggested legislation implementing many of its 181 recommendations. Because of the budget crisis in Albany, none of these bills has been submitted to the Legislature.

The Bank of New York Company, Inc., a statewide bank-holding company whose largest components are the Bank of New York here and the County Trust Company in White Plains, announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire the Valley National Bank, Valley Stream, L. I., for roughly $33-million in stock.
MOSCOW, April 20 -- The Soviet Union has adopted its own version of the Hippocratic oath for physicians, to take effect with next June's graduating class of the medical schools.
WASHINGTON, April 20 (Reuters) -- The White House press secretary, Ronald L. Ziegler, said today that the United States Government would welcome the visit by a Chinese table tennis team.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- A Senate subcommittee staff report said today drug abuse is on the upswing in the armed forces but rarely occurs in combat.

The stockholders of the Mill Factors Corporation voted yesterday to sell the remaining assets of the insolvent finance company to James Talcott, Inc., a leading commercial finance concern, and then liquidate their company.

A Pakistani wedding tent is the most exotic of the "beautiful retreats" that Barbara D'Arcy has put together for Bloomingdale's this season. But the rest of the eight model rooms opening today on the fifth floor are often almost as romantic.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, April 21 (AP) -- Allied reconnaissance in the Ashau Valley of South Vietnam entered its second week yesterday with still no report of any significant contact with enemy troops in what has long been one of their strongholds.

CIRCLEVILLE, Ohio, April 20 -- The RCA Corporation made its formal entry into the glass business here today. Robert W. Sarnoff, chairman and president, told a gathering of about 200 persons that this made his company "the first and only domestic television picture-tube manufacturer in the glass business."

SEATTLE, April 20 -- Senator Warren Magnuson ended today two days of hearings into the El Paso Natural Gas Company antitrust divestiture matter without coming closer to a resolution of the political and legislative problem that encircles him.

MASERU, Lesotho -- This little African country, formerly Britain's protectorate of Basutoland, has been independent for five years. CINCINNATI, April 21 -- It was just another typical evening in the young life of Johnny Bench, Most Valuable Player: Two excellent throws from his catcher position and a game-winning homer in the eighth inning.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- A high Administration economic official indicated today that President Nixon is as far away as ever from establishing a "wage-price review board" or "guidelines" to try to speed progress against inflation.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Before an applauding audience of veterans of the Vietnam war, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee opened hearings today on "how to end the war."

GENEVA, April 21 -- The fair trade rules under which most of the world's commerce is conducted are to be suspended in favor of the poorer countries in order to help them raise their foreign earnings from exports.

It was presented by the Walter W. Naumburg Foundation.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Following a placid debate that included none of yesterday's rancor, the Senate rejected today, 51 to 35, Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff's proposal designed to require large cities and their suburbs in all parts of the country to integrate their schools within 12 years.

MOSCOW, April 21 -- The Soviet Union, in its first comment on the apparent warming of relations between the United States and Communist China, denounced the Chinese today "for quickly coming to terms with those whom it had just called enemies."

JERSEY CITY, April 21 -- A 5-year-old child and a passerby who ran into a burning apartment building here to attempt to rescue its occupants were both killed tonight.

LONDON, April 21 -- A commission of the Church of England proposed today that divorced persons be allowed to remarry in church.

TORONTO, April 21 -- A leading United States industrialist suggested today that Washington's guarantees of American investments in Latin America might be self-defeating.

LOS ANGELES, April 21 -- The most vocal dissent at the annual meeting of the Columbia Broadcasting System here today came from top management. Frank Stanton, president of the network, dispensed with his customary report on operations to reassert the company's stand against a Congressional subpoena that it feels violates freedom of the press.

The city suffered a net loss of 34,000 jobs during 1970, the first decline since 1963, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.
Under the influence of 17,500 spectators, the New York Rangers will resume their Stanley Cup semifinal hockey playoff series with the Chicago Black Hawks tonight at Madison Square Garden.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The Gallup Poll reported today that "most Americans who presently understand" the no-fault automobile insurance concept are in favor of it.

Her healthy, athletic kind of good looks hasn't exactly been in the fashion forefront these days of frizzy hair and funky clothes.

Among dog show fanciers on the Coast it is also known as the home of the Jalna Kennel, a top pro ducer of Pekingese for several decades.

The elimination and qualification match between Mark Taimanov and Bobby Fischer, on the road to a challenge for the world chess championship, has been set for Vancouver, British Columbia, for May 13, at the University of British Columbia.

MINEOLA, L. I., April 21 -- Nassau County District Attorney William Cahn said today that his office had broken a nationwide, $250,000 - a - year pornography business, which allegedly used little girls, including the photographer's own three- and one - half - year - old daughter, as models for lewd photographs.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 21 -- Gen. Lon Nol received a new mandate today to form a government following his resignation yesterday for reasons of ill health. The action came amid strong indications that a powerful group of colonels, headed by the general's brother, would have opposed any other solution.

WASHINGTON April 21 -- A campaign spending bill that would set relatively high limits for all House candidates and for Senate candidates from sparsely populated states is being drafted for final consideration by the Senate Commerce Committee tomorrow.

BEDAI, India, April 21 -- The disorganized western units of the Bengali independence forces are regrouping in the districts bordering India's West Bengal state, trying to marshal themselves to carry out guerrilla counterattacks.

MOSCOW, April 21 -- Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, said today that Salyut, the unmanned orbital workshop, represented "an important stage" in the Soviet Union's space program.

What is probably the greatest of American plays and a landmark in 20th-century drama opened at the Promenade Theater last night in a staging that is authentic, heartfelt and thrilling. WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- A Government spraying program against fire ants was resumed on April 12 and is expected to cover more than seven million acres in the Southeast this year, the Agriculture Department announced today.

Congress and the Securities and Exchange Commission should turn their regulatory attention to other, larger, institutional investors, he added.

Union teamsters ratified new three-year contracts yesterday with 350 moving and storage companies, thus ending a 25-day strike that had drastically cut moving in the downstate area. Normal service is expected to resume today.

From satirical revues Jane Connell graduated to musical comedy. In recent years she hasn't appeared often enough on the New York stage, and when she has, she has tended to be type-cast. Would she always play Agnes Gooch to someone else's Auntie Mame?
The New York Stock Exchange has gone to bat to defend the $15 commission surcharge on stock transactions that has been in effect for more than a year to provide rate relief for member firms.

ALBANY, April 25 -- Women members of the Democratic State Committee gave a cool reception, including some boos and hisses, tonight to Representative Samuel S. Stratton's assertion that there is "very little difference" between Democratic and Republic positions on the Vietnam War.
A pair of rallying victories marked the Middle Atlantic figure skating championships that ended yesterday at the Abe Stark Rink in Coney Island, Brooklyn.

MOSCOW, April 25 -- A crew member of the Soyuz 10 spacecraft, which returned to the earth early this morning, today described the docking of his ship with the unmanned orbita laboratory Salyut as "a little like a train entering a railroad terminal."

MIAMI, April 25 (AP) -Sandra Haynie, who lost last year in a sudden-death playoff with Carol Mann, fired a par 74 today for a 54-hole total of 219 and a one stroke victory in the Burdines Women's invitational golf tournament.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, April 26 -- Enemy troops reportedly attacked two allied positions in the northern part of South Vietnam yesterday and staged commando and mortar assaults elsewhere throughout the country, inflicting severe losses and ending a period of relative quiet.
SWEDESBORO, N.J., April 25 -- All traffic was halted for nearly four hours tonight on a 25-mile stretch of the New Jersey Turnpike by about 1,000 antiwar demonstrators returning from Washington.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 25 -The final stakes event at Churchill Downs before the 97th running of the Kentucky Derby next Saturday will be the Derby Trial. And the expectation is that it will help in a measure to whittle the large field for the classic.
TEL AVIV, April 25 -- Israel unveiled tonight her recent acquisition of some advanced arms, and the military command termed the weapons build-up during the last year unprecedented.

Ronnie Haigler was saying, "Playing basketball is not reality. People do things for the player they wouldn't do for others. He is not prepared to come down to earth. When he leaves some jive college he never should have gone to in the first place, no degree, no more dream of playing pro ball, what's he got? Drugs, maybe. It's all part of this fanatical emphasis on winning. Ridiculous."

I am home on leave from Vietnam and I have read Burke Marshall's Op-Ed article, "We Must End the War" (April 10.) As a responsible officer of the United States Army in Vietnam, I should like to comment on this article from first-hand knowledge.

Leonid I. Brezhnev's decision to visit Bulgaria for the congress of the Bulgarian Communist party is a reminder of the importance the Kremlin attaches to Eastern Europe even at times when the area is relatively calm and away from the world spotlight.
The Yankees put it all together yesterday -- poor hitting, poor fielding and poor pitching -- and suffered their seventh defeat in nine games as the Minnesota Twins recorded an 8-0 victory.
SEATTLE, April 25 (AP) -- A fire apparently caused by a smoker's carelessness swept through a three-story apartment building today, killing 12 persons.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The staff of the Federal Reserve Board has strongly criticized a new mathematical "model" of the economy that has attracted some attention within the Nixon Administration and tended to support the Administration's optimistic forecast for the economy this year.

Top high school athletes in the metropolitan area, particularly in track and field, would attend local colleges if they could derive the same live-away-from-home feeling offered by schools in the South, Midwest and West, Ron Bazil said yesterday.
About 200 members of historic Grace Episcopal Church visited the equally historic Episcopal Church of the Ascension at Fifth Avenue and 10th Street yesterday in a cautious second step toward merger.

CHARLESTON, S. C., April 25 -- The voters of South Carolina's First Congressional District will choose a successor Tuesday to the late L. Mendel Rivers, after a campaign that has served to reinforce the legends concerning Mr. Rivers's political power.
The Leopard, an East Side restaurant specializing in haute cuisine, will offer dishes made from organic ingredients starting this week.

VIENNA -- A call for a fundamental re-examination of the mometary system in view of the problems of the dollar was made last week at a businessmen's conference here as warnings of the consequences of monetary instability grow shriller all over Europe.

TRENTON, April 25 -- Mike Mosley, a 26-year-old driver from Brownsburg, Ind., won the Trentonian 200 today for the first victory of his career in the championship division of the United States Auto Club.

SAIGON, April 25 -- The joint United States and South Vietnamese operation in the Ashau Valley area is 12 days old and still surrounded by official secrecy, leading some observers to wonder if something has gone wrong, or if the operation is just a training exercise for fresh Government troops.
The 1971 National Magazine Awards, sponsored by Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism, have been won by The Nation, Rolling Stone, Vogue, Esquire and The Atlantic Monthly.

High fashion at a low price would qualify as a hot buy. And that's the idea behind a new dual boutique called Le Hot Buy, at 40 East 53d Street. Men's clothes are carried on the street floor, women's things one flight up, and everything's imported from France.

BALTIMORE, April 25 -- A 30-16 third quarter gave the Milwaukee Bucks control of the game and the series today as they whipped the Baltimore Bullets, 102-83, for a 2-0 lead in the four-of-seven-game playoff for the championship of the National Basketball Association.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 25 -- Informed political sources said tonight that Gen. Lon Nol had decided to serve once more as head of the Government. The general resigned from the post last Tuesday because of ill health.

MONZA, Italy, April 25 (UPI) -- Pedro Rodriguez of Mexico and Jackie Oliver of Britain drove a five-liter Gulf-Porsche 917K to a record smashing victory today in the sixth Monza 1,000-kilometer auto race.
Israel continues to attract foreign capital at a record pace despite the political situation in the Near East, Yeshapahu Stopper, director of Israel's Investment Authority, said here last week.
VIENNA, April 25 -- Austria's federal President, Franz Jonas, was re-elected today in a national vote for another six-year term.
M. A. Schapiro Co., a leading bank stock dealer, proposed over the weekend that the National Association of Securities Dealers register as a national securities exchange.
Two of the most prominent schools of rock might be called Pure Excitement and Texture.

Since his carefree days as a little boy in the Presidential Palace at Port-au-Prince Jean-Claude Duvalier has grown up in the shadow of his dictator-father, sheltered from the poverty of Haiti's 4.5 million people and the violence and intrigues of power in the World's oldest black republic.
" If I don't open my mouth they may take it for the wisdom of age," mused Erik H. Erikson, the grand old man of psychobiography.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., April 25 (AP) -- Murray Oliver rammed in two goals and J. P. Parise scored the tiebreaker to pace the Minnesota North Stars to a 5-2 triumph over the Montreal Canadiens tonight and tie their Stanley Cup semifinal playoffs at two games apiece.

Walt Tkaczuk, the New York Rangers' leading scorer the last two seasons, was ordered into Lenox Hill Hospital last night with what the 23-year-old center described as "just a bruise, that's all" in the calf of his right leg.

Six veterans of the Vietnam war, in a frank, free-wheeling television discussion last night, accused the United States Government of having betrayed them and agreed that the Southeast Asia conflict was a racial war.

TIMONIUM, Md., April 25 -Mr. and Mrs. George West's 4 1/2-year-old doberman pinscher, Ch. Dolph von Tannenwald, increased his claim as top working dog of 1971 by placing best in show at the Baltimore County Kennel Club today.

BONN, April 25 (UPI) -- A professor of history admitted today that he pretended to have been kidnapped by left-wing activists in hopes of preventing a Social Democratic victory in a West German state election this weekend.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee said today that the present foreign aid program was a "shambles" and that "no amount of mobile maneuvering can save it."

A deadly perfect rebound performance by the Black Hawks caught the Rangers flat-footed yesterday, and the Chicagoans skated to a 7-1 rout to even their Stanley Cup semifinal series at two victories apiece.

LISBON, April 25 -- The trial of a Cuban Army captain here this week is regarded as an attempt by Lisbon to prove conclusively its claims of foreign intervention in the guerrilla movement in Portuguese Guinea.

Governor Rockefeller said yesterday he would ask the Legislature today to appropriate $30-million from a previously approved bond issue to expand Stewart Airport into New York's long-sought fourth major jetport.
PONCHATOULA, La., April 25 -- Lenaldo Salinas got up at 5 A.M. the other day to be in Allen Perrin's long, unshaded strawberry fields by dawn.

The 20th Century-Fox Stockholders Protective Committee yesterday opened its battle to change the management of the movie company with an attack on the company's present board as well as Darryl F. Zanuck, its chairman. Mr. Zanuck recently stepped down as chief executive officer.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., April 25 -Citizens of the ferocious little World of tournament table tennis gathered here today for the annual Long Island championships and to welcome three of their number who, as part of the American team, went to Communist China earlier this month.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -The organizers of yesterday's antiwar demonstration and city officials said today that they were pleased that the massive march and rally had not been accompanied by violence.

HOUSTON, April 25 (UPI) -Cliff Richey of San Angelo, Tex., played one of his best matches today as he crushed Clark Graebner of New York, 6-2, 6-1, 6-2, in the final of the $25,000 River Oaks tennis tournament before a capacity crowd of 2,200.
NEWPORT NEWS, Va. -- More power for New York City this summer -- 624,000 kilowatts in all -- is being readied in the famed shipbuilding yards here.

Albert Shanker's column, published as an advertisement under sponsorship of the United Federation of Teachers in The Times on April 11, contained several serious errors which I find potentially harmful to children, families and the general community.

A survey of housing abandonment in seven cities concludes that the phenomenon is national in scope and more severe in St. Louis, Cleveland and Chicago than in New York, where it has received the most publicity.

Standish, the pseudonymous author of "Frank Merriwell," was "'one of America's most peculiarly eminent practitioners of the art of fiction.

A powerhouse of a tournament was the recent 16-man Tallinn International, in Estonia, in which Paul Keres, one of the greats, shared first prize with a former world champion, Mikhail Tal of the Soviet Union. Each posted an 11 1/2-3 1/2 score.
LOS ANGELES, April 25 -The shrinking of the Western wilderness was marked here last week by two regulatory actions.

LONDON, April 25 -- When Edward Heath moved into 10 Downing Street last June, to the surprise of nearly everyone but himself, he came with a program quite unlike any in recent British political history.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -After more than three years of deliberation, the Federal Government has issued a safety standard requiring retreaded tires for passenger cars to meet the same performance criteria as new tires.

The nonprofit Consumer Union intends to test "several hundred" Chevrolet Corvairs in an effort to determine whether the automobile's heating system delivers carbon monoxide gas into the passenger compartment.

BUDAPEST, April 25 -- The Hungarian Communist regime pursued its program of controlled reforms today as seven million voters went to the polls in the first general elections in which officially backed candidates stood a chance of losing.

Carol Neblett is known here as one of the brighter stars of the New York City Opera, but opera is not the only thing she knows. She has studied art-song interpretation with Lotte Lehmann and Pierre Bernac, who really know what it is all about, and it is apparent that she has learned a lot from them.
DETROIT, April 25 -- It was the Sterling Ball, the Motown party -- and it was what a Motown party was supposed to be: screaming loud, jammed and mainly black.

The City Opera production of Mozart's "The Abduction From the Seraglio" has drifted into rather sluggish ways, and even Mario Bernhard's spirited conducting could not keep Friday night's edition from sounding tired.

LOS ANGELES, April 25 -Mayor Samuel W. Yorty of Los Angeles, who has a long record of unpredictable and often unsuccessful political behavior, will arrive in New Hampshire tomorrow to "test the water" and see it it is warm enough for him to enter the state's Democratic Presidential primary next year.

The city's radio and television facilities have been ordered to cut their operating hours to the minimum time allowable under their licenses from the Federal Communications Commission. The reduction will take effect Saturday after the dismissal of 55 employes Friday night in the municipal budget crisis.

The way the gang at Gardner has it figured, about $150-million is spent in this country each year to select, buy and evaluate media for advertising. They want a bigger slice of that pie and they're going to work hard to get it.

Brawling and lovemaking are the twin activities of "Romeo and Juliet's" Verona, and the Stuttgart Ballet's as well. Romeo encompasses both in his course, but Juliet's brother Tybalt seems single-mindedly dedicated to fighting. Saturday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House, Heinz Claus danced the part of Romeo and Jiri Kylian assumed the role of Tybalt, both for the first time this season.
RANCHO LA COSTA, Calif., April 25 -- The golf season is young but Jack Nicklaus, by winning the Tournament of Champions today, already has earned $102,903.

Chairman Mills of the House Ways and Means Committee has injected a new dimension into the long Congressional wrangle over welfare reform by his plan to tie together passage of a $2-an-hour Federal floor under industrial wages and President Nixon's proposal for a Federal floor under family income.
Bowing to a court restraining order, members of the Railway and Airline Clerks' Brotherhood yesterday ended a national strike against REA Express.

The Youth Symphony Orchestra of New York mixed its media Saturday afternoon in Carnegie Hall and came up with two world premieres: "Eclipse," a suite for rock band and orchestra devised by the four members of bwap, and "Opus 31, Miniatures for Synthesizers, Computers and Diverse Instruments" by Paul Conly and Allen Razdow.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 25 -- An outpouring of nationalistic pride and private cash is helping to complete a long-deferred railroad from Belgrade to the Adriatic Sea port of Bar.
The Treasury, which sought so long to issue Government bonds carrying interest rates higher than 4 1/4 per cent, now appears unlikely next month to use its newly gained power to sell them.
Mayor Lindsay said last night he "profoundly" disagreed with Governor Rockefeller's warning against new taxes as destructive and asserted there were "no data to back it up."

The folk mass that had its world premiere yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral could claim more authenticity than most of its genre. The Royal Mass of Mogho, composed by the Rev. Rene Guirma, though it used the ancient Roman Catholic Latin text, was rooted in the songs and culture of the West African people of Upper Volta, who trace their musical tradition back more than 3,000 years.

CHICAGO, April 25 -- State's Attorney Edward V. Hanrahan is to appear tomorrow before a special grand jury investigating the 1969 deaths of two Black Panthers in a predawn police raid amid wiedespread reports that the jury has already voted an indictment against him.
The two-year effort to reform the nation's disastrous welfare system will accomplish little if it fails to ease the crushing financial burden welfare has put on the major states and cities.

PITTSBURGH, April 25 -- Steel producers are starting to look beyond Aug. 1. Mill officials said last week there was little doubt about volume in the period prior to that date. "June is filling up fast," said one official. "I see no respite through the end of July."

JERUSALEM, April 25 -- The Israeli Cabinet reviewed the latest diplomatic exchanges with the United States today, and authorized further discussions aimed at finding a formula to reopen the Suez Canal and separate the Israeli and Egyptian front lines.

LONDON, April 25 -- In observance of Law Day, a group of New York lawyers plan to march this Friday to Foley Square in lower Manhattan, there to speak about ending the war in Indochina. In several other cities committees of lawyers are working for an end to the war.

The Concordia Choir, from Bronxville, N. Y., is one of the most regular college choral visitors to New York each spring. For its 1971 concert, held at Tully Hall yesterday afternoon, the 60-voice choir, led by Ralph C. Schultz, showed again that it is a pleasant, nononsense group that sings with spirit and understanding.

LONDON -- Senior business executives, in spite of the wellpublicized stress and strain of their lives, are less likely to become mentally ill than those lower down the social scale, according to a consultant psychiatrist.
The most comprehensive survey and analysis ever attempted of America's nonprofit performing arts is being undertaken by the Ford Foundation.
The beat of African drums sounded in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday afternoon in an orchestral and choral performance of a new African setting for the Latin mass.
Vincent A. Carson, the only man ever to manage all three of New York's major airports, will retire next Saturday as general manager of Newark Airport, where his colorful career began 35 years ago.

Worldwide net earnings of the Eastman Kodak Company in the first quarter fell 18 per cent to $67,912,000, or 42 cents a share from $82,603,000, or 51 cents a share, in the period a year earlier, according to the report released today. It was the largest quarterly decline in about 20 years.

A new study indicates that well over half the children who go into foster care in the city go back to families or are otherwise discharged from foster care within a year. But chances for others leaving during their remaining years of childhood fade rapidly.

MARTINSVILLE, Va., April 25 (AP) -- Richard Petty gained the lead after Donnie Allison's engine failed today and outran David Pearson for a narrow victory in the Virginia 500. The 262.5-mile race is part of the Grand National Division program of the National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing.

Having built up a good backlog of experience since getting out of Harvard three years ago, Richard G. White has established the Progressive Rock Network. It is an affiliation of 34 FM progressive rock radio stations in the top 50 markets which he is seeking to sell to national advertisers as a package.

PARIS -- "Confidence is suspicion asleep," said Benjamin Disraeli. After a remarkably quiet year in the international money markets, suspicion about the dollar has been reawakened by huge deficits in the American balance of payments. The United States ran a deficit of $10.7 billion to foreign central banks last year.

If you are going to be traveling this summer by auto, bus, train, plane or ship, you should be giving some thought to the insurance you have -- and maybe don't even know you have -- and to the coverage you'll need to protect yourself and your family.
VIENNA -- The specter of Prague's proscribed literary spring is haunting Vienna's cultural scene.

Two Transit Authority policemen staked out in a porter's room of a Brooklyn subway station yesterday afternoon, shot two holdup suspects -- one critically -- after hearing a demand for money over a speaker hooked up to the change booth.
