The centuries-long ties of Polish nationalism that have survived partition, occupation and immigration were in abundant evidence at Columbia University yesterday as a threeday congress of Polish-American scholars and scientists ended.

New orders for American machine tools, a closely watched indicator of future business trends, dropped in the first quarter to their lowest level in almost 11 years. At a total of $176.4-miilion, they were at the most disappointing level since the third quarter of 1960.

Dorr and Jennie Watkins live like Tarzan and Jane in a jungle of palms, baskets of orchids and the heady scent of flowering jasmine. They aren't exactly swinging on vines, since their forest is in an apartment building on the West Side.
KARACHI, Pakistan, April 25 -- The Pakistani Government, in a communique released late yesterday, banned the importing of 46 kinds of goods ranging from razor blades to refrigerators.

BOGOTA, Colombia, April 25 -- The Colombian Government has put down a series of student uprisings that crackled across the country like a string of firecrackers by closing five universities in the last week and occupying some campuses with soldiers and police.

SEOUL, South Korea, April 25 -- President Chung Hee Park pledged publicly today that he was seeking only one more term as President while his chief lieutenants, Kim Jong Pil, told a press conference that "knowledgeable people here anticipate that United States troops in Korea will be withdrawn by 1975 except for a token force."
PASADENA, Calif., April 25 -- The techniques used to guide military missiles to their targets may one day help the blind to see again, a team of California medical and aerospace scientists says.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- President Nixon, after a working weekend at his Camp David, Md., retreat, flew back here this evening, temporarily leaving behind a runaway dog.

Your short editorial of April 5 relative to the President's imposition of limitations on military medical personnel in the performance of abortions sets forth in a most striking manner the great confusion in thinking in which you so readily indulge concerning human life.

NEW ORLEANS, April 25 -What had been planned as the climactic program of the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival, a tribute to Louis Armstrong, lost some of its sparkle last night when Mr. Armstrong was not able to make the trip back to his hometown. The famous jazz trumpeter is in Beth Israel Hospital in New York recuperating from a heart ailment.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI) -- Representative Emanuel Celler, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, said today that the Attorney General's wiretapping policies might be leading the nation toward a police state.
PRETORIA, South Africa, April 25 (AP) -- South Africa has budgeted a record amount this year to maintain and modernize her armed forces, strongest on the African continent.

To the repeated, joyous chant of "Am Yisroel Chai" (the people of Israel live), thousands of men, women and children paraded up Fifth Avenue yesterday in celebration of Israel's 23d anniversary as a nation.

OTTAWA, April 25 -- Moderate forces of the socialist-minded New Democrats, who form Canada's third largest political party, prevailed over a radical Canadian nationalist faction at a party convention that ended here last night.

NEW ORLEANS, April 25 (UPI) -- Vice President Agnew said today that he strongly disagreed with the aim of yesterday's antiwar rally in Washington and found it "grotesque" that some of the demonstrators had carried Vietcong flags.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 25 (AP) -- Lee Trevino charged home with a four-under-par 68 today and won the $60,000 Tallahassee open with a 72-hole score of 273.

THE HAGUE, April 25 -- Tulips and politicians are the most prominent features of the Dutch landscapes this spring. Both are present in extraordinary numbers and variety, but the Dutch do not seem to appreciate them in equal measure.

One year ago, the Montreal Expos started their second season in the National League by losing 10 of their first 11 games. It was an embarrassment to Manager Gene Mauch, who had predicted, "The Expos will win 70 in '70."

CHEYENNE, Wyo., April 25 (AP) -- Five Air Force men were killed tonight when their C47 twin-engine transport crashed and burned behind a row of homes at Cheyenne Municipal Airport. The plane was attempting to land in a light drizzle.

ORANGEBURG, S. C. -- When a colleague of mine at South Carolina State College told me that she and her husband had attended the inaugural ball of the new Governor of South Carolina on Jan. 19, 1971, she commented with a trace of bitterness on the fact that ten or fifteen years ago blacks not only would not have been invited, but also -- if invited -- would not have been admitted had they gone.

Classic guitar-playing is an intimate art, and Ronald Scaglione emphasized the fact with a vengeance in his Saturday night program at Carnegie Recital Hall. Even those sturdy display pieces, Tarrega's "Recuerdos de la Alhambra" and Albeniz's "Leyenda," emerged as mere wisps of sounds so delicately did Mr. Scaglione brush the strings.
A handyman pleaded guilty yesterday to the murder of four persons who died in a fire he set the night of Oct. 2, 1969, in a three-story tenement in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.
The City Council is asking the State Legislature to let the Councils members and employes retire with a 75 per cent pension after 20 years service.

After five months of controversy, the community school board that removed Mrs. Desiree Greenidge as acting principal of Shimer Junior High School in Jamaica, Quens, resolved this morning to reinstate her.
The Beatles, with a little help from their friends, their lawyers, have agreed at last not to disagree about efforts of one of them, Paul McCartney, to get out of their partnership.

Edmond duPont, former senior partner and son of the founder of F. I. duPont, Glore Forgan Co., disclosed yesterday that he was considering legal actions that could block the takeover of the troubled brokerage firm by a group headed by H. Ross Perot.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 26 (AP) -- United States troop strength in South Vietnam dropped to 281,400 men last week, the United States command announced today. The total was 2,600 below the ceiling set by President Nixon for May 1 and represented the lowest level in nearly five years.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 26 (AP) -- The number of American deaths in combat in Vietnam has reached 45,000.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -Arthur F. Burns, the Chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, endorsed today a limited extension of statutory restrictions on interlocking personnel of financial institutions.
LONDON, April 26 -- More than 100,000 census enumerators set out today in heavy rain and unseasonable snow to collect 18 million forms distributed for Britain's 1971 census.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- Billie Sol Estes, the onetime West Texas promoter who has been in Federal prison since 1965, won parole today effective July 12.

GENEVA, April 26 -- Investors Overseas Services has brought a criminal action in the courts here against Arthur F. Adelson, former head of Investment Properties International, Ltd., a subsidiary, a spokesman for the investment group said today.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
PARIS, April 26 -- The Vietcong today called on American soldiers in Vietnam to stop fighting or desert and added that some American soldiers were fighting in the Vietcong ranks.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation announced yesterday that it had obtained $50-million in new bank loans to tide it over while it seeks to conclude negotiations for huge long-term financing needed to salvage its L-1011 airbus program.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- The Nixon Administration and the nation's largest detergent maker asked the Federal Trade Commission today to delay action on a proposal to require manufacturers to warn consumers that phosphate detergents pollute water.

BEL AIR, Md., April 26 -Wright Tisdale's orange and white pointer, Ch. Shandown's Tough O'Kings, was chosen best in show at the Harford County Kennel Club's 20th annual event today. Virgil D. Johnson of Savannah Beach, Ga. made the decision in the final class of six dogs from the entry of 1,500.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -Two new lawsuits, another round of Congressional hearings this week and criticism from Ralph Nader today are challenging the plans of the National Railroad Passenger Corporation to start operations on a shrunken national network next Saturday.

Your recent editorial concerning Mayor Lindsay's plan to collect more taxes as a means of providing essential services prompted me to reflect on some of the reasons services are not provided in an area familiar to me.

The Allied Chemical Corporation has developed an aircushion restraint system for automobiles and will build a multi-million-dollar interim production facility to make the safety device, John T. Connor, chairman, told some 600 shareholders at yesterday's two-hour annual meeting in the New York Hilton Hotel.
ANKARA, Turkey, April 26 (AP) -- The Government declared martial law tonight in 11 of Turkey's 67 provinces.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (UPI) -- Following are excerpts from the text of President Nixon's speech today to the United tSates Chamber of Commerce:

ATHENS, April 26 -- Demetrios Galanis, governor of Greece's central bank, praised today the vigor of the national economy but called for a "careful watch" on high liquidity -the amount of cash readily accessible to the public.

The Southern Pacific Company, one of the most diversified of the nation's railroads, reported yesterday a net income for the first quarter of $18,461,226, or 69 cents a share, up slightly from the $18,389,745, or 68 cents a share, reported for the comparable period a year ago.

Hugh Downs, host of the National Broadcasting Company's television network show "Today," will take leave of the program in October. He will be replaced by Frank McGee, it was announced yesterday by Reuven Frank, president of N.B.C. news.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -North Vietnamese MIG fighters have darted into southern Laos in the last few weeks "on several occasions to threaten U.S. aircraft," a Pentagon spokesman said today.

A sharp increase in crimes in central Harlem during 1970 -- attributed primarily to a rise in narcotics addiction -- raised the cost of crime to more than $2-billion for residents and property owners there, a study by the Small Business Chamber of Commerce disclosed yesterday.

Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc., the hard-pressed conglomerate reported yesterday first-quarter earnings of $1,889,000 before extraordinary items, which was equal to 18 cents a share. This compares with a loss of $9,313,000 before an extraordinary charge and $15,345,000 after the charge in the year-earlier period.
TOKYO, April 26 (AP) -- The tennis fortunes of Australia took another dip today when Japan eliminated her in the Eastern Zone Section A final of the Davis Cup.

James R. Hoffa, the imprisoned president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, arrived at the Federal House of Detention here yesterday to await his scheduled appearance before a Federal grand jury today.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The Senate approved today a $1.4-billion Administration-supported bill to help communities integrate their schools. The vote was 74 to 8. Seven Southern Democrats and one Republican, Senator Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, opposed the measure.

HIGH POINT, N. C. -- Women's fashions come and go with the seasons, but the sturdy sofa, to the dismay of the people who make and sell furniture, can sit in the living room for 11.7 years. What's more, the American family is in the market for home furnishings only four times in a lifetime.
The Open Theater, that leading experimental theater company, has not disbanded -- contrary to rumors and published reports.

Indications that the first quarter of 1971 was good to the petroleum industry received additional support yesterday as the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), the Continental Oil Company and the Union Oil Company reported solid earnings performances for the period.
MOSCOW, April 26 -- The Russians have a name for it -"Makhina" (pronounced "Maheee-nah") meaning "a thing of huge size."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 27 -- A huge ammunition dump in the side of a coastal mountain was exploded by enemy shelling early yesterday, the third day of a wave of attacks through much of South Vietnam.
A former assistant to the bursar of Columbia University was indicted yesterday on charges of having diverted $185,000 in tuition checks and other funds for his personal use.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- A special Presidential commission recommended today that the United States seek "as early as practicable" admission of Communist China to the United Nations but without the expulsion of Nationalist China.
The Bendix Corporation reported yesterday a 36 per cent increase in earnings for the second fiscal quarter.

NEW ORLEANS, April 26 -Vice President Agnew strongly defended J. Edgar Hoover and the Federal Bureau of Investigation here today in an 11page, 28-minute speech devoted entirely to the director, the agency and their critics.
Mayor Lindsay yesterday swore in the ninth man to head the city's Sanitation Department since he took over at City Hall in 1966.
MASCOUTAH, Ill., April 25 -- Like most Americans, Lawrence Friederich has picked up and moved two or three times.

SALT LAKE CITY, April 26 (AP) -- The Utah Stars and Carolina Cougars of the American Basketball Association have settled their dispute over Jim McDaniels, Vince Boryla, the Stars' general manager, said today.

" C'est trois," Jean Cruguet, the quiet-mannered French jockey who learned to ride horses near his boyhood home in Nice, said yesterday. "My mounts, they have been better this year. And, I have been very lucky."
HARRISBURG, Pa., April 26 -- The Federal Government has asked that a second witness called before the grand jury here be found in contempt for refusing to answer the grand jury's questions.

HAMBURG, West Germany April 26 -- French Finance Minister Valery Giscard d'Estaing said today the problem of sterling balances, one of the issues in Common Market negotiations with Britain, would come up in any British-French summit conference and spelled out France's position in the greatest detail yet.

Acute lymphocytic leukemia, which kills more young children in this country than any other disease, is yielding in ever-increasing numbers to intensive, combination therapy with potent drugs and radiation.

Chairman Mao Tse - tung would welcome a visit from President Nixon and would be happy to talk with him, according to Edgar Snow, the American writer who has had frequent access over the years to Chinese Communist officials.

NEW DELHI, April 26 -- The Indian Government imposed restrictions today on the travel of Pakistani diplomats and their families and servants, making it impossible for them to leave India without New Delhi's permission.
ST. LOUIS, April 26 -- The New York Mets knocked Bob Gibson out of the box within four innings tonight and routed the St. Louis Cardinals, 12-2, for Tom Seaver's fourth straight victory of the year.

ALBANY, April 26 -- Senate Majority Leader Earl W. Brydges said today that he favored the restoration of about $75-million in state aid to cities because recent budget cuts voted by the Republican-controlled Legislature "kind of pulled the rug out from under the local governments."

ATLANTA, April 26 -- A former soldier testified today in the court-martial of Army Capt. Eugene M. Kotouc that the stocky intelligence officer cut off the first joint of a finger of a Vietcong suspect he was questioning a few hours after the mass killings at the hamlet of Mylai three years ago.
For the first time this season Jim Perry pitched last night in the manner expected of last year's Cy Young Award winner as the American League's outstanding pitcher.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Two men who advised President Lyndon B. Johnson on the Vietnam war today endorsed proposals to impose legislative restrictions on the President's power to commit the nation to war.
Throughout the long debate over the creditworthiness of the Chrysler Corporation, the company's financing arm, the Chrysler Financial Corporation, has stood as a bulwark in the storm. Or has it?

SEATTLE, April 26 (UPI) -The Boeing Company at its annual meeting here reported an increase m first-quarter profits to $7,185,000, or 33 cents a share, from $6,181,000/ or 29 cents a share, in the initial 1970 period. Sales rose to $857,969,000 in the quarter from $809,457,000.
A well-judged opening lead on the final deal resulted in a victory Sunday night for Tom Griffin's team in Greater New York Bridge Association's Swiss Team Championship.

The threat to New York's municipal broadcast facilities, even if the monetary savings accompanying their discontinuance were sizable, can only be viewed with dismay. So identified has WNYC become with this community that the mind rejects the thought of its loss. [Editorial April 26,]
Human Resources Administrator Jule M. Sugarman proposed yesterday that legislation be enacted to force public and private employers in the city to hire a qualified city resident before a nonresident.

Two things were radically different at yesterday's annual awards of the Art Directors Club. There were more gold medals awarded than at any time in recent memory and the festivities were held at night instead of at a luncheon.

A city Board of Education hearing on methods of allocating school funds was told yesterday that "without proper funding of education, what we are talking about is how to spread the watered-down margarine on unenriched bread so that we can all starve equitably."
While blue chips rested yesterday on Wall Street, glamour stocks staged a calisthenics show starring the contact-lens issues.
No matter which philosophical side of the racquet you prefer, rough or smooth, the Japan-Australia Davis Cup series finally has put tennis in its proper perspective.

LONDON, April 26 -- The Government today ruled out any inland site for a new London airport. The decision was a victory for environment over economics -- probably the most significant in Britain so far.

The Yankees will attempt tonight to pull out of a slump that has seen them lose seven of their last nine games when they meet the Chicago White Sox at Yankee Stadium. The teams will end the two-game series tomorrow night.

The prime business loan rate of the major banks -- which was increased last week to 5 1/2 per cent from 5 1/4 per cent at most institutions -- is likely to go still higher this year, a leading bank economist said yesterday.
Ranger fans were asking yesterday, "How can a team play so superbly on a Thursday and so poorly on a Sunday?"

Madison Avenue merchants polled by the Fifth Avenue Association overwhelmingly oppose the traffic ban from noon to 2 P.M. currently in effect on weekdays along the avenue from 42d to 57th Street, the 1,000-member association reported yesterday.

Eliot Feld's latest ballet, "Theater," seen over the weekend at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is an interesting and impressive work. It is a gloss on the commedia dell' arte, and it is a gloss on one or two earlier ballets to do with clowns, clowning, tragedy and unfulfilled aspirations:
The futures prices of pork bellies -- the basic material for bacon -- fell again yesterday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.
One of the ways that the city's new Sanitation Commissioner sometimes like to think of himself is as a former "two-sewer man" from Brooklyn.

BOHEMIA, L. I., April 26 -Jet air service by a major airline began at Long Island MacArthur Airport this morning when an American Airlines Boeing 727 left here with a full complement of 93 passengers bound for Chicago.
ALBANY, April 26 -- Governor Rockefeller will veto a bill that would have barred construction of a bridge across Long Island Sound from Oyster Bay, L. I., to Rye, administration sources said today.
William Hegmann Jr., a Sandoval, Ill., metallurgical engineer, believes he has perfected an economical technique for producing soft-iron pellets for shotgun shells.
Mayor Lindsay called yesterday for "sweeping reform" of state laws to give local governments more independence from the state and more power to rule themselves.

A community shower room separates the dressing rooms of the New York Rangers and the New York Knickerbockers just beyond the arena proper in Madison Square Garden. When last visited, each was an exceedingly gloomy place.

The Western Electric Company, one of 21 Bell System companies now engaged in contract negotiations, made its initial wage and benefit offer yesterday to representatives of the Communications Workers of America and the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers.
The 28-year-old vice consul of Pakistan here renounced his ties with the Pakistani Government yesterday, saying he would "not serve a government killing our own people."

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The antiwar demonstration here last week and those still to come suggested again how widespread is the opposition to continuing the war. But there is not yet a shred of evidence to suggest that this demonstrable opposition is causing the Nixon Administration to change its basic course.
A tentative agreement was reached shortly before midnight last night by striking retail clerks and managers and the management of Bohacks supermarkets, the union announced.

On Saturday, two days before "The Ballad of Johnny Pot" opened at Theater Four, the star, David Carradine, was dismissed from the show. John Bennett Perry was rushed in to take his place, which made opening night into something of a cliffhanger. Would Mr. Perry remember his lines? Would a new star be born?
Controller Abraham D. Beame urged the City Council yesterday not to establish the Human Resources Administration as a superagency dealing with welfare and poverty.
The star of Broadway's newest rock musical is a 75-year-old diabetic grandmother from Louisiana who has survived two heart attacks and nine major operations.

In the beginning there was the soaring sound of Richard Strauss's 'Thus Spake Zarathustra." Then the announcer came on with a quote from Bernard Berenson, something about standing on a street corner with a tin cup to collect minutes from passers-by.

Dr. Nasry Michelen resigned yesterday as president of Hostos Community College in the South Bronx, saying that the college needed new leadership after a series of crises that placed its operation "in jeopardly."

As Richard T. Connor, the Richmond Borough President, puts it, the Lindsay administration has been handling the vast Staten Island development plan "like a fellow trying to design the 747 on the back of a matchbox."

About 80 scientists and medical educators urged the Lindsay administration yesterday to restore proposed budget cutbacks of $2.5-million that the doctors said threatened the survival of the city's Health Research Council.

With his legs twitching inside his red-striped blue jumpsuit, Joe Frazier entertained the early arrivals at last night's Felt Forum boxing show as a rock singer, not as the world heavyweight champion. And the difference was obvious.

The newest music conducted by Pierre Boulez in the "New and Newer Music" program at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday night dated from 17 years ago, his own "Le Marteau sans Maitre." It followed old and older works by Schoenberg (the 1926 Suite, Op. 29, sometimes known as the Septet) and Stravinsky ("Berceuses du chat" and "Pribaoutki," dated 1916 and 1914, respectively).

WASHINGTON, April 26 -The moonquakes detected by Project Apollo instruments with clocklike regularity as the moon makes its closest approach to the earth each month appear to originate in a single "hot spot" deep within the moon.

TULLAGHANOGE, Ireland, April 13 -- To Brendan Lynch, who farms 53 acres of County Meath land here, the European Common Market means "a house every two miles with a Mercedes car, and a bureaucrat who thinks he knows better than we -carrying a blueprint that says either you fit in or you die."

CHICAGO, April 26 -- The special prosecutor heading a grand jury investigation into the deaths of two Black Panthers in a predawn police raid in 1969 was held in contempt of court today and fined $50 an hour on a round-the-clock basis.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- A bill introduced in the House of Representatives today seeks to avert what educators have called an impending crisis in support for medical education.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -A leading specialist in environmental hazards said today that current budgetary restraints on the development of pollutionfree fusion energy were "in utter disgrace."
Prices on the American Stock Exchange ended on the fence yesterday as the list finished mixed on moderate trading.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- Donald E. Johnson, Administrator of Veterans Affairs, testified today that good progress was being made in treating drug addicts among Vietnam war veterans who seek rehabilitation.

New York City's municipal utilities planner contended yesterday that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company -- not the individual consumer -- should be called upon to pay for improving the deteriorated telephone service here.

ALBANY, April 26 -- The state Public Service Commission today rejected a proposal by the New York Telephone Company to establish intercommunications picturephone service on an experimental basis in lower Manhattan.

During the first week in May most of the school and library districts in New York State will be asking the voters to approve their budgets so that the education of the children and the continuation of library service might not be impaired.

PINEHURST, N. C., April 26 (AP) -- Gary Cowan of Canada, the defending champion, and seven of the eight United States Walker Cup players survived today's opening round of the North-and-South amateur golf tournament.

The Soyuz-Salyut mission has American space experts puzzled. From the sketchy information that has been made public, they are unable to determine if it was a success or a failure, a major step toward a manned orbiting laboratory or a small, hesitant step.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., April 26 -- Reaction ran hot and cold here today on Governor Rockeller's proposal to convert nearby Stewart Airport into the metropolitan area's fourth major jetport. The Governor is seeking $30-million from a $2.5billion state transportation bond issue to purchase 10,000 acres here for jetport development.
PARIS, April 26 -- The French oil industry, with Government support, sought today to impose a worldwide embargo on Algerian petroleum and natural gas.

The least debatable element in the budget plight of New York City and the rest of this state's urban areas is that it was made vastly worse by the inordinate cuts in state aid voted by the Republican majority in the Legislature. One member of that majority -- State Senator Roy Goodman of Manhattan -- has now appointed himself leader of a drive in Albany to restore the cuts.
DETROIT, April 26 -- The Ford Motor Company reported today first-quarter profits of $169.2-million, or $1.57 a share, up 36 per cent from $124.4-million, or $1.15 a share, a year ago.

In the name of economy (sic), a financially and socially disastrous step was taken by our New York State legislators in their recent action during the budget crisis. The newly enacted Social Service Law signed by Governor Rockefeller on April 12 eliminates payment for Home Health Services for non-welfare Medicaid patients.

Contemporary painters and sculptors often talk about closing the gap between art and life, but Kurt Schwitters did, almost 50 years ago. He literally inhabited his art. Gutting his house in Hanover, he turned it into a "Merzbau" -- a multistoried constructivist sculpture. From the inside, the Merzbau resembled a rain forest of ab stract forms, a warehouse of surplus imagination.

Political campaign spending gets more bloated every year. What with television specials, "spot" commercials, continuous polling of the electorate, direct mailings to voters on computerized lists -- not to mention the traditional balloons, billboards and bumper stickers -- the list of things on which campaign managers spend money keeps growing. Now the Presidential campaigns are getting under way more than a year before the first primary is held.
A total of 72 windows for win or exacta betting on the Kentucky Derby will be available this week to New York racing fans, officials of the city's Offtrack Betting Corporation announced yesterday.
JINJA, Uganda, April 25 -Relations between the Government of Gen. Idi Amin and several neighboring countries have been deteriorating rapidly.
BEIRUT, April 26 -- King Hussein said today that security and stability had been re-established in Jordan and that the time had come for national reconstruction and development.

William T. Dentzer Jr., the New York State Superintendent of Banks, announced yesterday his approval of the proposed merger of the Franklin Savings Bank and the Kings Highway Savings Bank to form a combined institution with $1-billion in assets, and nine offices.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -Clark MacGregor, Counsel to the President for Congressional Relations, and Mrs. MacGregor entertained last night and tonight at the first of a series of informal little dinners designed to better acquaint the White House, Capitol Hill and the Cabinet.

The national mood of economic frustration and anti-intellectual reaction has begun to feed a growing movement against academic tenure. The arguments marshaled for abolishing professorial job security are cloaked in high-minded rhetoric of academic reform. This is a transparent disguise of the economic and political anger which provides the true motivation.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 26 -- The investigation of California Rural Legal Assistance, an antipoverty agency, began here today before a special commission that refused to allow Lewis K. Uhler to speak unless he would follow commission rules.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 26 -- The Derby Trial has attracted a field of eight for its running tomorrow, and four of these are considered likely starters in the Kentucky Derby on Saturday. Even if four should be rated good enough for the big race, it will be too many, for the great problem now is to cut down the top-heavy Derby field.

TRENTON, April 26 -- The creation of a state authority designed to attract the New York Football Giants to North Jersey was overwhelmingly approved, 53 to 6, tonight in the State Assembly. Before passage of the bill, opponents charged that the authority involved a conflict of interest.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -Anti war protesters clad in burlap sacks and smeared with make-believe blood pleaded on Capitol Hill today for an end to the conflict in Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- President Nixon today nominated four Federal judges to fill long-standing vacancies on the United States courts in the New York City area.
Macrame -- the art of creative knot-tying -- has in the last few years sprung from the obscurity of old sailors' homes and Victorian parlors into a highly popular craft.

PORT - AU - PRINCE, Haiti, April 26 -- Jean-Claude Duvalier, the 19-year-old President for Life of this black republic, indicated today that his new regime would seek friendlier relations with the outside world.

NEWARK, April 26 (AP) -Former Assemblyman Peter W. Moraites surrendered to Federal authorities this morning to begin serving a 16-month prison sentence for accepting money from a company that had sought loans from a bank of which he was a director.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -Productivity, or output per man-hour, rose only about half as much in the manufacturing sector of the economy in the first quarter as reported last week, the Labor Department disclosed today.
TORONTO, April 26 -- Thomas J. Watson Jr., chairman of International Business Machines Corporation, promised today to "bend every effort" to appoint a woman to the board of directors this year.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 26 -- Lon Nol was described by one of his official counselors today as a man too ill either to make important decisions or to be informed of bad news. Nonetheless, the counselor said, the situation in Cambodia is such that the general must again head the Government.

CAIRO, April 26 -- The Egyptian leadership, although it has officially welcomed Secretary of State William P. Rogers's announcement that he would visit Cairo, indicated today that it was wary of the motives behind the trip and skeptical that any benefit for Egypt would emerge.

An official of the American Public Health Association warned yesterday that narrow emphasis on recycling as a means of solving the nation's waste problem could create a public health problem by delaying the disposal of garbage.
Governor Rockefeller certainly received bad advice in deciding to scuttle the community-development bond issue and put in its place a transportation bond issue.
Mozart's "The Abduction From the Seraglio" has only six characters, all of them major, although only five of them sing (the Pasha is a speaking part).
The Rockefeller administration is reportedly considering the proposal of legislation that would loosen rent control in the state.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 26 (AP) -- Alabama's attorney general used a centuries-old legal concept today to charge 13 large companies in Birmingham with endangering the lives of citizens by polluting the air.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -The leading proponents of national health insurance appeared before Congress today to criticize each other's plans and agree on only one thing -the country's health care bills will rise almost 50 per cent in the next three years.
Willis Reed of the Knicks will enter Roosevelt Hospital today to undergo surgery on the sore left knee that has hampered his play for the last two seasons.

Edward Fry, associate curator of the Guggenheim Museum, was dismissed by the museum's director yesterday in a controversy over the cancellation of a show by Hans Haacke, the artist, that was to have included photographs of Manhattan slums labeled with the names of the buildings' owners.

In Protestant North America, Catholics have often felt the need to reassert their fundamental loyalty as Americans. Yet now, at a time when our society faces profound polarization, public attention has been drawn to the so-called Catholic Resistance. The emergence of this phenomenon illustrates the way that religion determines an individual's relationship to his government.

Smith, Kline French Laboratories announced yesterday following its annual meeting in Philadelphia, that Thomas M. Rausch, president and chief executive officer, has been elected to the additional position of chairman. Mr. Rausch, 49 years old, succeeds Walter A. Munns who retired as chairman at the annual meeting. Richard L. Matthews was elected a group vice president.

Reading about Kaiser Wilhelm's secret plan to invade the United States back before World War I could make your hair stand on end if you started thinking about what this country would be like today if the Kaiser's plan had succeeded.

LISBON, April 26 -- Lisbon's military court convicted Capt. Pedro Rodriguez Peralta of the Cuban Army today on charges of having served as a training instructor and adviser to the African party for the Independence of of Guinea and Cape Verde.

Retailers asserted yesterday that the city's proposed regulations on unit pricing were "discriminatory," and they contended that the rules would not be widely applicable to slum-area stores, where unit pricing was "needed most."
The credit markets, muddling along as they await the terms of the Treasury's $8.44-billion refinancing tomorrow, declined quite sharply in quiet trading yesterday.
Tenneco Inc., reported yesterday a high in first-quarter operating revenues, while net income ran higher than the year-ago period.
TEL AVIV, April 26 -- Israeli artists will decorate the lounge off the President's box in the Symphony Hall of the John F. Kennedy Center in Washington, it was announced here today.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., April 26 -- Twelve Long Island commuters proved something today that they had long suspected -it is more expensive to travel to New York City by helicopter than it is by Long Island Railroad or by automobile, but it is also much faster.

The delivery of the Lee National Corporation of cash, securities and title to five parcels of industrial real estate in exchange for shares of kansas City Southern Industries, Inc. was completed Yesterday.

An examination of the transcript of the murder trial of Mrs. Alice Crimmins confirmed yesterday that the prosecution had tried unsuccessfully to get the judge to permit testimony by a doctor purporting to show that she had admitted killing her two children.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The Supreme Court upheld today the constitutionality of state referendum laws that permit a majority of the voters in a community to block construction of low-rent housing for the poor.

A month after the military crackdown in East Pakistan, absenteeism by Bengali workers is still crippling the economy, according to well-informed travelers who were in East and West Pakistan this week.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that states cannot suspend unemployment compensation payments to jobless persons while their former employers challenge their eligibility.
LONDON, April 26 -- The British Leyland Motor Corporation, the last major British-owned company in the worldwide automobile business, introduced today its new family car, the Morris Marina.

The state election in Schleswig-Holstein was doubtless a setback for Chancellor Brandt's coalition government in West Germany but this aspect should not be exaggerated. Nor should one salutary result be overlooked: the vote for the neo-Nazi National Democratic party (N.P.D.) dropped to 1.2 per cent, costing it all four of its seats in the state legislature and reinforcing the impression that it is collapsing throughout the country.

A Buxtehude cantata and a contemporary jazz piece by J. Labes, each performed with an appropriate instrumental ensemble, were juxtaposed in the eclectic program put on by the Zamir Chorale in Carnegie Hall Sunday night.

WESTBURY, L. I., April 26 -Ferric Hanover had to be scratched from a $15,000 overnight event Saturday night at Roosevelt Raceway because of a minor throat inflammation, but Ben Webster his trainerdriver, is hopeful the 4-year-old won't miss the $105,969 Realization Pace this Saturday night.

A former member of the City Planning Commission, Beverly Moss Spatt, has recommended that the commission be abolished and its duties assumed by a powerful new agency under the direct control of the Mayor.

WASHINGTON -- The climactic celebration of the 500th birthday of Albrecht Durer, who was born on May 21, 1471, will begin on May 21, when a year-long exhibition of the German master's work opens in his natal city, Nuremberg. In the meanwhile, the National Gallery in Washington is doing pretty well with an exhibition of Durer prints and drawings from American collections that opened Sunday and will remain on view through June 6.

Black Panthers on trial here on bomb-conspiracy charges were depicted yesterday by two of their attorneys as victims of a police plot to prevent young black militants from becoming united in an effort to improve conditions in which blacks live.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- President Nixon told an appreciative audience of businessmen today that despite a "sense of despair" in some elements of the population, there was no reason to lose "confidence" in the nation's economy, the aims of its foreign policy, or its sense of concern for the poor.

The Kingston Trio, one of the foundation stones of the pop folk boom of the late 1950's, is back in business after a slight hiatus with the same old high spirits and fraternity house humor but with a partially new set of faces.

A group of the nation's largest business enterprises announced their financial results yesterday for the first quarter of 1971, indicating for the most part that prosperity has returned to the corporate world after a year's absence.
ROME, April 27 -- Pope Paul VI's vicar for Rome called today for a missionary effort in the city to win its "de-Christianized" masses back for the church.

ST. LOUIS. April 27 -- The New York Mets, who disposed of Bob Gibson inside of four innings last night, took a little longer with Steve Carlton tonight. But they still survived a hair-raising ninth inning to defeat the St. Louis Cardinals, 2-1, and send Carlton to his first loss of the season.

The First National City Bank, the largest in New York, announced yesterday plans to offer low-cost term life insurance to its 500,000 savings account depositors. First National City is the first major commercial bank to offer such a plan, but mutual savings banks for many years have operated life insurance departments.

TIENTSIN, China, April 24 -The husky young woman, a weaver at the No. 1 Tientsin Carpet Factory, lay watching placidly as Dr. Nyi Fu-jung pulled 12 acupuncture needles from her stomach, left leg and knee joint.

All sorts of record-book opportunities beckon the Milwaukee Bucks as they take on the Baltimore Bullets tonight in Milwaukee in the third game of the final four-of-seven series for the National Basketball Association championship. The game will be televised here at 9 P.M. on Channel 7.
A group of parents obtained a court order yesterday that temporarily blocks the state from closing a Lower East Side institution that houses their mentally retarded children.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 24 -- Ultraleftist revolutionary students plunged Ceylon into a guerrilla war this month after years of careful organization and planning. While they were planning their attempt to seize power, Government leaders appear to have viewed the students as harmless idealists at best and as juvenile delinquents at worst.
NEW DELHI, April 27 (AP) -- Some Pakistani soldiers who have been fighting separatists in East Pakistan reportedly crossed into India today and exchanged fire with Indian security forces.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The National Academy of Sciences, regarded as the nation's foremost scientific group, decided today to increase sharply its membership from the ranks of leaders in medical, social and behavioral research.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- President Nixon will hold a White House news conference Thursday at 9 P.M. that will be open to live radio and television coverage.

First-quarter earnings were up for the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., but down for the New York Telephone Company as the two giant utilities released their results for the period yesterday.

In any society, the quest for justice is an endless and often frustrating journey. In the middle of a war being waged against a cruel, elusive enemy in an alien country, this quest takes on nightmarish qualities. Yet in Vietnam, as in other wars in the past, the American armed forces have to measure their conduct against this country's laws and ideals. No other standard would be either practical or morally tolerable.

Peter Handke, the young avant-garde Austrian writer, has said that the basic idea behind his plays is "making people aware of the world of the theater -- not of the outside world." In his theater "objects are deprived of their normal function in reality.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -The House Foreign Affairs Committee warned today that there was virtually no chance that the President's $3.2-billion foreign aid reorganization plan would be passed in this session.

The thing that is most right about John Cranko's "Carmen," given its American premiere by the Stuttgart Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, is Marcia Haydee's spitfire performance of Carmen.

NEW DELHI, April 27 -- India, charging that Pakistan had virtually interned Indian diplomats in Dacca in their houses, ordered "strict police vigilance" today on the movements of Pakistani diplomats in Calcutta.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- The Justice Department said today that it would appeal to the Supreme Court the ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit that the Government may not wire tap domestic groups suspected of subversion without advance approval by a court.

In the stiff and poker-faced world of finance ministers and central bankers, witticisms are hard to come by -- and are endlessly repeated when somebody thinks one up. At the moment, the bon mot you hear from financial officials all over Europe has to do with their worries over coexisting with the mam moth American economy: "It is like being in a rowboat with an elephant."
FLEMINGTON, N. J., April 27 -- The Eastman Kodak Company demonstrated a new low-light-level, color motion-picture film here today, but promised an instant camera only for some future time.

KALAUPAPA, Hawaii -- The trade wind was strong enough to scuff up white caps in the sea, but it was reduced by the cliffs and the tress and the houses so that it became only a pleasant coolness to match the pleasant hotness of the tropical sun. The cool air carried the the scent of growthings and the sounds of distant motors and the rise and fall of pleasant friendly conversation beyond earshot.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI) -- Antiwar protesters buttonholed employes of the nation's draft headquarters today with the blessing of the director. A few other demonstrators were arrested after spending the night in the office of Senator Hugh Scott of Pennsylvania, the minority leader.

There is a type of singer, often first-class and often English, who seems happiest when presenting a program that rises to its blithest in such numbers as Purcell's "In the black, dismal dungeon of despair."
Thirty-thre leaders of religiout groups, representing virtually all the major faiths in the United States, have called for a three-day period of "repentance and renewal" over the war in Indochina.

HUNTINGTON, W. Va., April 27 (AP) George S. McGovern told a university campus audience here tonight that if he was elected President, he would never again commit American troops to Southeast Asia, even in the face of a Communist takeover.

Tournament veterans recall with limited nostalgia the days in the thirties when it cost 25 cents to play in a local duplicate game. They were greatly indebted at that time to Jim Holton, who died last month at the age of 72. He contributed greatly to the development of tournament bridge in the New York area, especially in Brooklyn.

The credit markets got jittery yesterday as they awaited the Treasury's announcement -scheduled today -- of plans to refinance $8.44-billion of maturing notes. Bond prices declined, interest rates climbed and two major corporate bond sales expected today were put off a week.

BILOXI, Miss., April 27 -- A three-judge Federal panel ruled today that Mississippi could not implement a new open primary law opposed by Mayor Charles Evers of Fayette and other Negro leaders in the state.

President Nixon's special revenue-sharing proposal for education is of considerably greater significance for the nation's school system than you suggest in your April 9 editorial. While you approve its promise of eliminating red tape and its priority on aid to the disadvantaged, your discussion of its other elements requires amplification in several important respects.
The stock market surged yesterday with alternating waves of speculation and profit taking but its main undertone was a yeasty strength not readily visible in the popular averages.
COLOMBO, April 27 (Reuters) -- The Government today fixed Saturday as the day for insurgents to surrender and accept the Prime Minister's pledge of "reasonable" treatment.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The Secretary of the Treasury and a member of the Federal Reserve Board both firmly rejected today a policy of "benign neglect" for the nation's balance of international payments.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The nation's surplus of exports over imports improved in March for the second consecutive month but did not return to the high levels of mid-1970, the Commerce Department reported today.

If, by a wild stretch of the imagination, the Brooklyn Museum and the Studio Museum in Harlem were reckoned as the pulsebeat and showcase of the contemporary art trend, realism would now be in high ascendancy.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -Congress got to work today on two major consumer protection bills with the Nixon administration renewing its opposition to both of them.
When the General Dynamics Corporation announced two months ago that it was moving its national headquarters out of the city, New York's loss appeared to be St. Louis's gain as the company announced:

Walter Felsenstein, director of the Komische Opera of East Berlin, will conduct seminars and opera demonstrations and introduce showings of two of his opera films on May 11 and 12 at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, L.I.

Howard R. Leary, former Police Commissioner of New York City, announced yesterday that he was leaving his job as vice president of security at Abraham Straus to become president of the Holmes Security Corporation, a newly formed subsidiary of Holmes Protection, Inc.

PINEHURST, N. C., April 27 (AP) -- The defending champion, Gary Cowan of Canada, led a parade of winning favorites through the second round of the North and South amateur golf tournament today on the 7,000-yard, par-72 No. 2 course at the Pinehurst Country Club.

It was a busy day yesterday for the men who paint the names on executive-suite doors as the White Motor Corporation, Texaco, Inc., the American Smelting and Refining Company and the Foster Wheeler Corporation announced major leadership changes.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 27 -- Gov. Ronald Reagan today called on a three-member commission to resign if it did not intend to follow his prescription for investigating California Rural Legal Assistance, a legal aid program for the poor.

DALLAS, April 27 (UPI) -- Cliff Drysdale of South Africa, Fred Stolle of Australia and Dennis Ralston of Bakersfield, Calif., scored straight-set victories in the first round of the $50,000 Rawlings tennis tournament today.

The petroleum industry continued to show improved earnings for the first quarter of 1971 as Texaco, Inc., the Phillips Petroleum Company, the Marathon Oil Company and the Getty Oil Company reported decidedly higher profits for the period.

JERUSALEM, April 27 -- Some members of the Jerusalem City Council demanded tonight the removal of Mayor Teddy Kollek's acting deputy for development and planning when it was reported that he had advocated returning part of Jerusalem to Arab sovereignty.
Pornography for the masses is for sale on 42d Street, but erotica for the moneyed classes went on auction yesterday at Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

ATLANTA, April 27 -- The military judge in the Army court-martial of Capt. Eugene M. Kotouc directed a verdict of acquittal today in one of two charges that the Government has brought against the stocky career officer.

HAMBURG, West Germany, April 27 -- Finance Minister Valerie Giscard d'Estaing, of France suggested at a 5-hour meeting of Common Market ministers that the dollar should be devalued through an increase in the official $35-an-ounce price of gold, sources at the meeting disclosed.

CANBERRA, Australia, April 27 -- Australia's 160,000 aborigines have no legal title to their ancient tribal lands, according to judgment handed down in the Supreme Court of the Northern Territory in Alice Springs today.

CANANDAIGUA, N. Y., April 27 (AP) -- A special grand jury, in a report made public today, sharply criticized the Ontario County Sheriff for his handling of an undercover agent and a disorder at Hobart College.
MOSCOW, Apil 27 -- The fourth volume of the new 30-volume Soviet Encyclopedia is out, and the game of second-guessing its editors on politically sensitive subjects continues.

A small bit of Americana died a couple of weeks ago, and stock-car racing is the poorer for it. The occasion, according to a report by Randy Laney, in The State, published in Columbia, S. C., was the Sandlapper 200, a race for late-model stock cars at Columbia Speedway.
LONDON, April 27 -- The heron, that stately bird of remote waters, has become a resident of London.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -Unlike most members of Congress who work to perpetuate their Washington service, Senator Mark O. Hatfield proposed today that no Senator or Representative be allowed more than 12 consecutive years in office.

Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally Jr. said yesterday that if the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation was to survive its financial troubles, there would have to be a Government guarantee of about $250-million in loans to he company.
In the first quarter of 1971 it was better to haul freight than to move people.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -President Nixon's long-awaited health care plan to cover 200 million Americans was introduced in the House today but not in the form that he had originally wished.

I read with puzzlement your editorial of April 2 labeling my campaign reform bill as "bland." It's unfortunate that you failed to stop by your newsroom the previous morning to ask about the most current compromise bill I drafted two weeks ago, which I revealed to newsmen on April 1.
QUITO, Ecuador, April 27 -President Jose Maria Velasco Ibarra today began setting up a framework to let the voters exchange his civilian dictatorship for representative democracy by next year.
NASHVILLE, April 27 -- A Presidential preference primary in Tennessee next May 4 to select and instruct delegates to the national nominating conventions was approved today by the state legislature.
Former Senator Charles E. Goodell will head a drive to raise $1-million to help meet the yearly operating costs of the New York Urban League. The drive will start today.
A Long Island lawyer who is awaiting trial on charges of plotting the murder of Herbert Itkin, a Government informer, was convicted of stock fraud conspiracy yesterday in Federal Court in Brooklyn.

MINNEAPOLIS, April 27 -- Charles S. Stenvig, the police detective who was elected Mayor of this city two years ago as a political independent, won renomination by a landslide today over two partisan opponents.
The state ordered a limit yesterday for the first time on both rent and length of stay for welfare recipients in hotels -- $5 a person a day as top rent, and six months as the allowable stay.
CHARLESTON, S.C., April 27 -- Mendel J. Davis, the godson and namesake of the late Representative L. Mendel Rivers, Democrat of South Carolina, won a special election for his seat here today.
Rutgers has joined Pennyslvania in considering Dick Phelps of Fordham as a candidate for basketball coach.

Donald S. Rugoff, the theater owner, spent all day yesterday giving away free movie admissions to celebrate the 50 years his family has been in the business. He was struck in the face several times by angry young people for his efforts.
NEWARK, April 27 -- Prisoners rioted today in the Essex County Jail, assaulting guards, destroying furniture and setting a series of small fires.
Profits reported yesterday by major corporations showed an irregular pattern.

Sales of copper futures reached a new high for the year of 2,322 lots of 25,000 pounds each yesterday on the Commodity Exchange (Comex) here. The previous high point was reached on April 13, when 2,139 lots were sold.
NEWARK, April 27 -- George Kentera, executive editor of The Evening News here, resigned today. He will be succeeded by James Idema, who resigned recently as editorial page editor of The Denver Post.

Federal Judge Joseph C. Zavatt rejected yesterday the Government's move to jail Anthony Augello and to revoke his $60,000 bail pending his appeal on 12-year sentences for extortion and possession of stolen goods.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass. -- The dramatic reversal in Sino-American relations is far more profound than mere Ping-Pong diplomacy. Current contracts are actually increasingly semiofficial in nature.

The final scene of the sometimes stormy drama involving city purchase of Joseph Papp's Public Festival Theater was played yesterday at City Hall -- the City Council voted to buy the theater's building at 425 Lafayette Street for $2.6-million.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 27 -- Preparations for a meeting of Yugoslavia's top Communists are taking place in an atmosphere mingling secrecy and alarm.
ALBANY, April 27 -- Governor Rockefeller called today for a substantial relaxation of the rent control laws covering New York City and the rest of the state.

DETROIT, April 27 -- The General Motors Corporation announced today that both unit and dollar sales for the first quarter of 1971 were the highest for any quarter in the corporation's history, while profits were the third highest.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange finished mixed yesterday for the second consecutive session in stepped-up volume.
An apprentice made his Aqueduct debut a winning one yesterday when Donald Maddock booted home Three Stable's I'm Your Boy in the fourth race.
LAKE HOPATCONG, N. J., April 27 -- "Fire Com, this is Greystone Tower. Smoke at 115 degrees about three and a half miles out."
When the Yankees loaded the bases and failed to score in last night's 11th inning, it looked like last Saturday all over again.
MOSCOW, April 27 -- The Soviet Union today called on developing countries to follow Chile's example and create united fronts of Communists and others favoring noncapitalist systems.
The United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steel producer, announced yesterday that first-quarter earnings rose 14.7 per cent from the year-earlier level on slightly lower sales.

SNEDEN'S LANDING, N.Y., April 27 -- Miss Edith Hale Harkness and Kenneth Perry McKinnon, a Washington lawyer, were married last Saturday afternoon at the home here of Mrs. Rebekah Harkness, mother of the bride and patron of the arts.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI) -- Curt Flood, the Washington Senators' center fielder, quit baseball today with the explanation to the team's owner, Bob Short, that he had "very serious personal problems mounting every day."
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 27 -- The South African Government today approved the introduction of a television service.
James R. Hoffa testified before a special grand jury for more than two and a half hours yesterday in the closely guarded United States Court House at Foley Square.

J. J. Newberry Company announced yesterday the election of Robert W. Conley as president of J. J. Newberry Canadian Ltd. Leslie A. Raphael was made vice president of the Sweet Sixteen Division; William C. Wright, to vice president of the Gault Brothers, Ltd. division; Lee Schwenk, named vice president of the United Stores of Canada division; and Sidney Harrison, will be vice president of the Harrison Famous Fabrics division.

Arthur A. Houghton Jr., president of Steuben Glass and chairman of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, was the recipient last night of the Skowhegan Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney Award.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -Democrats dealt President Nixon's revenue-sharing plan another blow today as they pushed through the House Education and Labor Committee their own program of public service jobs for the unemployed.
ALBANY, April 27 -- Democratic legislators made today what was described as an "unprecedented personal attack" against State Senator Roy M. Goodman, a Manhattan Republican.

WASHINGTON, April 27 The Justice Department's antitrust division believes that some "serious antitrust problems" could arise from the planned change in the rules of the New York Stock Exchange that would, in the future, permit an individual or corporation to invest in more than one member firm of the exchange.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission is getting a rising number of complaints that films and broadcast programs degrade or demean ethnic or racial groups, Commissioner Robert E. Lee said today.

MONTREAL, April 27 (UPI) -- Pete Mahovlich scored two goals tonight as the Montreal Canadiens took a 3-2 lead in the four-of-seven game National Hockey League Stanley Cup semifinals with a 6-1 victory over the Minnesota North Stars.

LONDON, April 27 (AP) -- The Royal Ascot, the annual horse race for high society, approved hot pants for women at this year's running. But then the Duke of Norfolk, the Queen's representative at Ascot, heard about it and today said absolutely not.
ALBANY, April 27 -- Ten thousand New York City employes came to the Capitol here today seeking restoration of budget cuts that have threatened many with the loss of their jobs.
CHICAGO, April 27 -Hockey's powder keg, Bobby Hull, finally exploded in the Rangers' faces tonight.

Siaka Stevens has tried to bolster his obviously shaky position by making Sierra Leone a republic and promoting himself from Prime Minister to "Supreme Chief of State" with sweeping powers. Matt Snell signed a contract yesterday to play fullback for the Jets for what he said might be his last season. The club also announced the signing of Al Atkinson, the defensive captain, and Coach Weeb Ewbank said Joe Namath had promised he would report to training camp on time.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Capt. Samuel Lee Gravely Jr., the first black American to be selected as an admiral in the United States Navy, according to naval aides, is a big, modest man who is considered an extremely proficient officer.
LONDON, April 27 (AP) -- Yachtsmen from Britain, France and Canada failed today to agree on a formula for elimination races to decide who will challenge the United States for the America's Cup.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -The campaign spending bill now headed for the Senate floor does not make some reforms that President Nixon has requested and includes some restrictions that the Administration has specifically opposed.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -The Center for Law and Social Policy, a public interest law firm, criticized today the proposals of a presidentially appointed council for the reorganization of the Government's regulatory agencies.

WASHINGTON April 27 (UPI) -- In a 2-to-1 decision, the United States Court of Appeals ordered a lower court today to hold full-scale hearings into whether the Army had overstepped its mission when it engaged in surveillance of domestic protest groups.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 27 -- A call by two French petroleum companies for a worldwide embargo against Algerian oil has evoked Arab warnings of countermeasures.

BUDAPEST, April 27 (AP) -- Eight incumbents in the Hungarian Parliament were unseated by newcomers in the general election Sunday, according to the official results, announced today. Two incumbent deputies were forced into runoffs.

There is a certain Alice-in-Wonderland logic in the legislative history of the proposed bridge across Long Island Sound from Oyster Bay to Rye. First, Governor Rockefeller asks authority to build the span. The Legislature, in order to push through an omnibus transportation bill, agrees. Next the legislators, hearing for the first time from their constituents, try to rescind the authorization and continue to try, unsuccessfully, for four years.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI) -- A $100,000 reward posted nearly two months ago for information on the bombing of the United States Capitol has failed to draw a single response, the Senate Democratic leader, Mike Mansfield, said today.

More than a million high-school students who annually take the college board scholastic aptitude and achievement tests will be able to have personal data sent to colleges along with their test scores starting next fall, the College Entrance Examination Board announced yesterday.

SEOUL, South Korea, Wednesday, April 28 -- President Chung Hee Park appeared today to be sweeping toward a convincing victory in his bid for a third term.

NORWOOD, Mass., April 27 -- Dr. Edwin H. Land, the man who invented the Polaroid Land camera, held a news conference today. That may not sound like a big news story, but for the shy 61-year-old scientist-businessman, it was something of an innovation.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The man in the middle of Washington's smoky-room gossip these days is Big Ed Muskie of Maine. WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- The Pentagon postponed indefinitely today its proposal to build a giant nuclear-powered aircraft carrier that was estimated to be the highest-priced warship in history.

MINEOLA, L. I., April 28 -- The new limit that the state will pay toward rent for welfare recipients living in hotels will mean that Nassau County taxpayers will pay almost $3-million more a year, Nassau County Executive Ralph G. Caso said today.

Merck Co., Inc., announced yesterday the election of Dr. Antonie T. Knoppers as president of the health-products firm. He succeeds Henry W. Gadsden, who was elected chairman of the board, succeeding the late Charles S. Garland.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The National Academy of Sciences accepted today a committee report calling the study of human racial differences "a proper and socially relevant scientific subject," but it rejected a recommendation for taking direct action on such studies.

A dismaying series of scandals, climaxed by the murder sixteen months ago of insurgent Joseph A. Yablonski, has long made it plain that the once proud United Mine Workers is in an advanced state of moral debility. But even the multiplicity of such evidences of decay could not take the shock out of the abuses a Federal judge has found in management of the union's huge pension and welfare fund.
The recent announcement of the elimination of the Welfare Education Plan for Aid to Dependent Children (A.D.C.) mothers by the State Legislature concerns me greatly.

American companies plan to increase their expenditures for plant and equipment by 4 per cent this year, it was reported yesterday by the McGraw-Hill Publications Company in its annual survey of capital spending.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- A Federal inquiry heard testimony yesterday on the financial qualifications of a group seeking to wrest control of television station WPIX.
Bill Graham, the dynamic, long-haired impresario of rock, announced yesterday that he would permanently close the doors on his twin citadels of rock culture -- the Fillmores East and West.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -The Vatican has ruled that Roman Catholic priests disciplined by Patrick Cardinal O'Boyle here in 1968 over a dispute in interpreting an encyclical on birth control must comply with the teaching norms set down by the archbishop and by the church.
There are times when the sheer volume of fly fishing literature threatens to depress me. There is so much of it the mind boggles.
MADRID, April 29 (UPI) -Curt Flood, who quit baseball Tuesday for the second time while his suit against the sport was still on appeal, checked out of his hotel here today and headed for the airport.
CHICAGO, April 29 (AP) -- A University of Chicago biologist announced today that he had resigned from the National Academy of Sciences in protest against its sponsorship of secret research.
The forthcoming demise of the Wabash Cannon Ball and scores of other famous trains has sparked renewed Congressional debate.

The Federal Reserve Board has largely completed a basic overhaul of its widely followed index of industrial production. According to Harold C. Passer, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Economic Affairs, the revised index -- which is now scheduled to be published in June -- could give a "very different" picture of the first quarter than the present measure.
The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation reported yesterday that it realized an increase of 12 per cent in earnings as well as sales and revenues in the first quarter this year.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -The House Foreign Affairs Committee has decided to put President Nixon's $3.3-billion foreign-aid reorganization plan in cold storage for this session of Congress.

ALBANY, April 29 -- At just about the time that the last chunk of dirt-encrusted snow melted in this refrigerated capital, Mayor Lindsay tries to melt the hearts and open the pocketbooks of Governor Rockefeller and the Republican legislative leaders.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -Representative Wilbur D. Mills, apparently fearful that his welfare reform bill is headed for trouble on the House floor, is moving on several fronts to win more votes.

CONWAY, Mass. -- Stephen Vincent Benet's "The Devil and Daniel Webster" is one more proof that myths are made of time as well as tales. It first appeared in The Saturday Evening Post in 1936, a short story of unusual delight but a short story notwithstanding. Today it is a fable from which men quarry plays.

WASHINGTON, Apr. 29 -The Securities and Exchange Commission issued today the proposed rules under which the sellers of front-end load mutual fund plans are to notify their customers when they are entitled to refunds if they decide not to go through with their investment.

The little girl who has come to be known as Baby Lenore remained with her foster parents under a Federal court order yesterday while lawyers sought to take the adoption dispute to the United States Supreme Court.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 29 (UPI) -- The United States command announced today that 45 Americans died in combat last week in Indochina, raising the total in the war since the beginning of 1961 past the 45,000 mark.
A 27-year-old policeman who has been cited for heroism in antinarcotics work foiled an ambush attempt and set off a manhunt early yesterday.
In the menus below dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

Ever since he became the Ivory Coast's first president, in 1960, Felix Houphouet-Boigny has been known as a political realist and one of the most able administrators in black Africa. Mr. Houphouet-Boigny, who urged black African nations on Wednesday to accept South Africa's invitation to establish a diplomatic dialogue, has adhered to a pro - Western stance despite occasional criticism from those who say he is not enough of a nationalist.
The Federal Government will allow the city to use money alloted for the Model Cities Administration to lower the cost of public housing, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- A strong increase in consumer plans to purchase homes and related items but otherwise no major change in consumer sentiment was reported today by the Commerce Department.

CAIRO, April 29 -- Egypt tonight completed the formalities of ratifying a plan for federation with Syria and Libya after several days of intensive discussions that led to the amendment of some statutes of the agreement.

WESTBURY, L.I., April 29 -- Dayan, last season's 4-yearold trotter of the year, will be making his debut tomorrow as the even-money choice in the one mile, $25,000 Su Mac Lad Trot at Roosevelt Raceway.
Officials holding a majority of votes on the Board of Estimate came out yesterday against a proposal to charge 25cent tolls on the four East River bridges that are now toll-free.
Michael Martin, a former city detective accused of selling confidential information to banks and airlines, was sentenced yesterday to 90 days and a fine of $5,000.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., April 29 -- There was a wild Stanley Cup finish here tonight, too.

HOUSTON, April 29 -- The national forces that have been pushing for a dispersal of the poor into the suburbs were demoralized by the Supreme Court decision Monday upholding state laws that give voters of a community the right to block construction of low-rent housing.

Today is Prof. Eli Ginzberg's 60th birthday, so the Columbia scholar is taking his wife to Atlantic City for what he regards as a weekend of relaxation. While there he expects to write four papers and put the finishing touches on his 43d book.

A twin - engine prop - jet carrying electronic and photographic detection gear developed for war began flying over New York waterways this week to see if the equipment could perform a peacetime job of detecting water polluters from the air.

In the early morning hours a tractor-trailer truck stops at a red light at a deserted street corner here. The driver pays no attention to the car that pulls alongside until four men jump out, one of them waving a pistol.

The Allied Chemical Corporation announced yesterday the apointment of Robert E. Mulcahy as president of the Fibers Division. Alan Belzer was named to succeed Mr. Mulcahy, who previously was president of the company's Fabricated Products Division. Mr. Belzer previously was general manager of that division's film department. The corporation also announced the appointment of Richard G. Sanders as president of Nodaway Valley Foods, Inc., a subsidiary.

PEKING, April 29 -- Prof. Chien Wei-chang, a researcher and lecturer at the California Institute of Technology from 1940 to 1946, says that he is a contented product of protracted and painful thought-remolding by students, workers and soldiers at Peking's Tsinghua University during the Cultural Revolution.
Following is a transcript of President Nixon's news conference last night as recorded by The New York Times:
OTTAWA, April 29 -- The Canadian Government decided today to let its special antiterrorist legislation expire on schedule at midnight tomorrow night.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., April 29 -- Lone Shark ($25.60), driven by Don Gillis, won a $1,600 handicap mile for trotters as Monticello Raceway opened its 14th season of harness racing tonight, but the result of the feature seemed to be of secondary interest to most of the 9,136 first-nighters.
PARIS, April 29 -- The dollar improved slightly against some of the continental currencies today, but the price of gold continued to climb, hitting an 18-month high of $39.45 an ounce in London.
The forces that are out to gain control of Twentieth Century-Fox today unleashed the first of a planned advertising blitz that will end with the embattled company's annual meeting on May 18.

A State Supreme Court justice yesterday dismissed a suit by a New York City taxpayer requiring Mayor Lindsay to dismiss H. Lee Rankin, the city's Corporation Counsel, on the ground of conflict of interest.

ALBANY, April 29 -- The 12 Republican Assemblymen from New York City accused Mayor Lindsay in a statement today of intentionally underestimating by nearly $150-million the amount of money existing taxes would produce for the city during its 1971-72 fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -More than 200 demonstrators were arrested late today as they attempted an unauthorized march from a building of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare near the Capitol to the White House, about a mile away.
QUANTICO, Va., April 29 -It has been suggested that women's track and field in the United States began with Willye B. White.

The Professional and Staff Association of the Museum of Modern Art, a group of employes that has been negotiating with the museum over salaries, working conditions and a voice in policy-making has voted to affiliate with the Distributive Workers of America, an independent, liberally oriented union affiliated with the Alliance for Labor Action.

ALBANY, April 29 (AP) -- A State Supreme Court justice today ordered a halt to all dismissals of state employes until he has ruled on the constitutionality of the methods in which the state budget was passed.
SEATTLE, April 29 -- Leslie Bacon arrived here tonight, under subpoena, to testify before a Federal grand jury looking into the bombing of the United States Capitol in Washington.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -Before a gathering of Jewish leaders, Representative Gerald R. Ford, the House Republican leader, today accused Senator Edmund S. Muskie and Senator J. W. Fulbright of undermining American support of Israel.

PORTLAND, Ore., April 29 (UPI) -The Justice Department has been given 27 pages of alleged abuses of llockey players and is looking into possible antitrust violations, Cm'tis Leichner, a lawyer representing tile Professional Hockey Players Association, said today.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -The Defense Department said today that while combat casualties in Vietnam declined 70 per cent between 1968 and 1970, noncombat casualties had remained almost constant.

ATLANTA, April 29 -- An Army court-martial jury cleared Capt. Eugene M. Kotouc of guilt today in the maiming of a Vietnamese prisoner three years ago at Mylai 4, an act the officer said he had committed by accident.
THE HAGUE, April 29 -- The Netherlands was in search of a new ruling majority today following substantial electoral losses for the center-right Government coalition.
UAL, Inc., the holding company that controls United Air Lines, the world's biggest airline, announced yesterday that it incurred a $33.2-million loss in the first quarter of 1971.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 29 -- President Suleiman Franjieh consulted through the day today with the 99 members of the Lebanese Parliament on what should be discussed with Secretary of State William P. Rogers during his visit here Monday.
PINEHURST, N.C., April 29 (AP) -- Lanny Wadkins, Bill Campbell, Vinny Giles and Eddie Pearce won two matches each today to advance to the semifinals of the North and South amateur golf tournament.
ANKARA, Turkey, April 29 (AP) -- Secretary Rogers arrived here today under security precautions tightened by Turkey's imposition of martial law in the capital and in 10 other areas of the country.

Twenty-three members of the militant Jewish Defense League were arraigned in Criminal Court yesterday on charges stemming from the league's invasion of the offices of the New York Board of Rabbis on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -President Nixon said tonight that a residual force of United States troops would remain in South Vietnam indefinitely -"no matter how long it takes" -- if Hanoi refused to release American prisoners of war.

A shake-up in Channel 13 was effected yesterday with the appointment of Jack Willis, coexecutive producer of "The Great American Dream Machine," to replace Christopher W. Lukas as program coordinator of noncommercial WNET.
ST. LOUIS, Apr. 29 -- The New York Mets completed a fourgame sweep of the St. Louis Cardinals today and in the bargain ended Joe Torre's hitting streak at 22 games.
PARIS, April 29 -- Rich West Germans are fleeing from marks, even as the rest of the world can't seem to buy enough of them.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -For railroad labor, the National Railroad Passenger Corporation's start of Amtrak service this weekend is the start of another painful series of job losses and disruptions.

A way to reduce the gap in next year's city budget by $276.9-million was described yesterday by the City Controller and promptly challenged as "unrealistic" by the City Budget Director.
