A program to rehabilitate 11 of the 13 PATH commuter railroad stations in New York and New Jersey is to begin soon with a design study financed in part by a $78,500 grant from the Federal Department of Transportation.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 29 -- Gen. Lon Nol tonight was named chief of the Cambodian armed forces and Lieut. Gen. Sisowath Sirik Matak was asked by Chief of State Cheng Heng to form a new Government. General Sirik Matak has requested time to consider the proposal.

BONN, April 29 -- Alexander Dubcek, the deposed Communist party leader of Czechoslovakia, is working in his hometown of Bratislava as a garage manager for the city's parks department, according to Quick, the illustrated West German weekly.

PITTSBURGH, April 29 -William J. Stephens, chairman and chief executive officer of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, emphatically denied the allegation of a stockholder here today that the steel concern was "ordered" to declare a dividend in the first quarter by Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc., which owns 81 per cent of J. L.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -The House Internal Security Committee was pictured today by one of its members as an "unauthorized secret snooper" that maintains files on hundreds of thousands of Americans.
ROME, April 29 -- The ninemonth-old Government of Premier Emilio Colombo appeared strained today by power struggles within the center-left coalition on which it rests.

PARIS, April 29 -- North Vietnam invited the United States today to open negotiations "this very day, or tomorrow, or another day" on setting a date for the withdrawal of all American troops from South Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -Freight traffic on United States railroads in the week ended April 24 was below the volume in the corresponding week of last year. Intercity truck tonnage in the same period was considerably higher because of work stoppages in the trucking industry last year.

ALBANY, April 29 -- A bill has been introduced in the Assembly to expand pension benefits for state legislators, the Lieutenant Governor, the Controller, the Attorney General, judges and many court employes.

Following are excerpts from letters contained in new Government indictments against the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan and others. According to the indictment, the first letter is from Sister Elizabeth McAlister to Father Berrigan, in prison in Lewisburg, Pa., and was sent about Aug. 20, 1970. The second letter was allegedly transmitted from Father Berrigan to an address in New York on Aug. 22, 1970.

A 125-foot-high stainless steel obelisk to rise from a block-long bed of flowers on the center mall of Park Avenue between 68th and 69th Streets will be donated to the city by George T. Delacorte if the Art Commission approves the proposal when it meets this month.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -A paddle wheel device being developed by the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation is intended to pick up heavy oil slicks off the coast. Patent 3,576,257 was granted this week to Robert L. Yates, a design engineer for Lockheed Missiles and Space Company, a division, of Sunnyvale, Calif. Oil on the surface of the water is scooped up by a revolving drum perforated with vanes that are connected to internal disks.

QUANTICO, Va., April 30 -- In a surprising appearance designed to strengthen him for his May 16 mile showdown against Jim Ryun, Marty Liquori won the 5,000-meter run today at the 15th annual Quantico Relays.

ALBANY, April 29 -- The acquisition of a new $700,000 conservation helicopter at the same time as the dismissal of 8,400 state workers is proving to be an embarrassment to Henry L. Diamond, the state's Commissioner of Environmental Conservation.
Mayor Carl B. Stokes of Cleveland said last night that he would go to Mississippi to help Charles Evers in his campaign for Governor.

BOSTON, April 30 (UPI) -- Senator William Proxmire said today that he was considering campaigning for the Democratic Presidential nomination and would make two trips to New Hampshire in May to appraise his chances in its Presidential primary, the country's first.

HARRISBURG, Pa., April 30 -- A Federal grand jury here today brought new indictments against the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan and five other persons on charges of conspiring to kidnap Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's national security adviser.

ANKARA, Turkey, April 30 -- Secretary of State William P. Rogers stressed today that the United States sought a "contractually binding and lasting" settlement of the Middle East crisis, in addition to its current efforts to promote an interim agreement between Israel and Egypt to reopen the Suez Canal.

LONDON, April 30 (AP) -- Karen Moras of Australia bettered the world record tonight for the women's 400-meter free-style swim with a time of 4 minutes 22.6 seconds in a 14-nation meet at the Crystal Palace.

HOUSTON, April 30 -- The New York Mets, who had won only two games under a roof in two years, won one tonight on the first try. But they had to go 12 innings before subduing the Houston Astros, 4-3, as they opened a weekend series in the Astrodome.

CAIRO, April 30 -- Any possibility that Syria and Libya could outvote Egypt in their planned federation has been eliminated. A crucial amendment in the statutes requires unanimity of the three presients for federal executive decisions and the selection of a federal president.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department officially announced today that a pilot program for eradicating wild-growing marijuana would be started this summer on farm land in 10 states.

LONDON, April 30 -- One of the most trying dilemmas for a country with moral notions in its foreign policy is what to do about awkward friends. People generally opposed to American intervention abroad will suddenly demand that the State Department do something when a friendly government behaves unjustly. But do what? In terms of practicalities as well as political wisdom the answer is seldom clear.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -The Securities and Exchange Commission obtained a court order today forbidding the Ecological Science Corporation from misrepresenting its technological achievements and business prospects in the file of pollution control.
Fred Patek, the smallest player in the major leagues, wielded a mighty big bat in making Kansas City Royals history last night.

A 300-year-old violin, inlaid with rubies and diamonds that was made for King Louis XIV of France by the master violinmaker, Nicolo Amati, has reappeared here five years after it was stolen from an auto in Brooklyn.
VIENNA, April 30 -- Soviet and American negotiators at the arms limitation talks here met for another two-hour session today.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -A known mafia member or other criminal figure would have a hard time opening a bank account in Switzerland, numbered or otherwise, a leading Swiss banker said today.
ALBANY April 30 (AP) -- An appellate judge delayed today the further layoff of state workers for at least a few more days.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Saturday, May 1 (UPI) -- Catherine M. Webb, United Press International bureau manager in Pnompenh, who has been missing since April 7, was freed today by her captors.

NEW ORLEANS, April 30 -Miller Barber and Hubert Green, a rookie, set the 36-hole pace at 137 today in the $125,000 Greater New Orleans open as a snake hunt and the withdrawal of Lee Trevino caused some dismay.

GALVESTON, Tex., April 30 (AP) -- In a stockholders meeting filled with anger and accusations, shareholders of the American National Insurance Company elected today a board nominated by its present management.

Dipping into repertory Thursday evening at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, Eliot Feld's American Ballet Company drew out three varied ballets; one of which, "At Midnight," predated the formation of the company by a year.

SEATTLE, April 30 -- Leslie Bacon, arrested in Washington, D.C., as a material witness in an investigation of the March 1 bombing of the Capitol, testified before a grand jury today. Her lawyers said she had not been asked about the Capitol bombing.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 30 -- The American Armed Forces Radio Network in Vietnam, "where the hits just keep on coming," has been told to stop playing "The Battle Hymn of Lieutenant Calley."
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The police arrested today 330 members of a civil rights and antiwar group conducting a week-long "peoples' lobby" in the capital.

DETROIT, April 30 (AP) -- The nation's auto makers planned to produce fewer cars this week than last week, but the output will still be substantially higher than during the year-earlier week, according to Automotive News.

Based on reports of favorable weather for the completion of field work, corn-futures prices dropped sharply yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Sellers far outnumbered buyers for a time.

DETROIT, May 4 -- New-car sales in the final third of April trailed the year before, and while sales for all April topped the 1970 month, the size of the gain wasn't impressive, it was learned today.

ALBANY, May 4 -- "I sent them an animal and I'm getting back a human being," said Marion Tabasco of Howard Beach, Queens, as she demonstrated near the Capitol today to protest cuts in the budget for state narcotics addiction programs.

Dean Acheson's article "On South Africa" (Op-Ed April 21) reveals an almost total misunderstanding of the international law issues involved in the Namibia (South-West Africa) question now before the World Court. Four young high school pianists will compete for cash prizes Saturday in the grand finals of the sixth annual WQXR Young People's Competition. The event will be broadcast that evening at 8:06 over WQXR, the radio station of The New York Times.
ALBANY, May 4 -- Governor Rockefeller signed into law today a bill requiring retailers to sell liquor at a price at least 12 per cent above its wholesale price.
High-grade bond yields climbed yesterday to the highest levels they have reached so far in 1971.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 4 -- There's nothing wrong with Minnesota's relief pitching that the Yankee relief pitching can't cure.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., announced yesterday that it had raised prices by from 4 cents to 22 cents a pound on Lucite acrylic resins in custom colors. The company also increased the size of minimum orders for custom colors from 300 pounds to 1,200 pounds.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -The State Department's leading official on Asian affairs said today that Communist China's support of insurgencies and "wars of liberation" remained a threat to United States interests despite hopes for improved relations.

PARIS, May 4 -- Europe's financial centers were buffeted today by the greatest wave of currency speculation in two years. Corporations, banks and others who control large sums of money exchanged unwanted dollars for West German marks, Swiss francs, Dutch guilders and other "strong" European currencies.

ROME, May 4 -- Italy's three major labor organizations started talks today with political parties in an effort to get longpromised social reforms.

A back-sliding little bill, which New York City Consumer Affairs Commissioner Bess Myerson correctly called "undistilled price-fixing," was signed into law by Governor Rockefeller yesterday. The volume of trading in the New York foreign-exchange market was exceptionally heavy yesterday, bankers reported, but changes in currency values were modest.
MINEOLA, L.I., May 5 -- Nassau County Executive Ralph G. Caso asked the United States Department of Labor today to declare Long Island a job-disaster area.
NEW ORLEANS, May 5 -- The Louisiana Legislative Mafia Investigating Committee denied today that the underworld dominated the state government but said there was suspicion of some corruption.

LONDON, May 5 -- This week's antiwar demonstrations in Washington have attracted wide but not overwhelming attention in Europe. Press comment has been relatively muted, though with some criticism of the Washington police for their mass arrest tactics.

The precious and semi-precious metals futures as well as the silver coins futures market took off here yesterday as a result of the news from Europe that dollars were being exchanged for marks and other "strong" European currencies.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- A teen-age boy, wandering aimlessly on the Mall today near the Capitol, got instructions on how to take part in an antiwar demonstration from an unlikely source -- a District of Columbia policeman.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -The Securities and Exchange Commission believes that the emergency $15 surcharge on smaller securities transactions will need to be continued for at least two more months. The commission has also informed the New York Stock Exchange that it finds a large number of defects in the accounting methods that the exchange has used to support its claim that its members must have the surcharge or lose money.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (UPI) -- At a cost of $75,000, The White House's back lawn is being transformed into a fairground to help President Nixon salute American farmers this Friday.

KARACHI, Pakistan, May 5 -- The chief of Pakistan's military intelligence service portrayed his nation today as facing large Indian military forces along the frontiers and said he could not discount the possibility of war.

ALBANY, May 5 -- The Senate approved a bill today permitting New York City to establish a housing finance agency with power to raise $700-million through bond sales. The funds would provide mortgages for the construction or rehabilitation of housing.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Mayor Lindsay appealed today for the creation of a unified Federal narcotics treatment and research agency with the goal of a $1-billion annual program within three years to fight drug addiction.

Net income of the Pittston Company tripled in the first quarter of 1971 to $15,498,000 from $5,039,000 in the yearearlier period, the hard-coal company announced yesterday.

By a 6-to-3 vote, the Court ruled that it is not a violation of due process for the states to give juries absolute discretion in imposing the death penalty. It further held that it is not necessary for the states to require juries, having decided that a prisoner is guilty, to hear additional evidence before determining sentence.
WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, called today on the Nixon Administration to release $226-million in health funds impounded for economy reasons.

DALLAS, May 5 -- One thing Jack Nicklaus would rather do than win golf tournaments is to beat Arnold Palmer head to head. And Palmer? "I'd just like to tie again with Nicklaus and beat him in a playoff."
CAIRO, May 5 -- Secretary of State William P. Rogers conferred for more than six hours today with Egyptian leaders over the specifics of the Egyptian proposal to reopen the Suez Canal.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- For 17 days, Washington has been the stage for a whole theater of antiwar protest. The demonstrators have been angry or sullen, triumphant or absurd. The reactions have been compassionate or tolerant, confused or dignified, weary or frightened.

The Copper Range Company, the nation's fifth largest producer of primary copper, announced that Chester O. Ensign Jr., president, was elected chief executive officer. He succeeds James Boyd who has retired but will remain as chairman. Mr. Ensign, 46 years old, was named president and chief operating officer one year ago.

KARACHI, Pakistan, May 5 -- A spokesman said today that the Government regretted the inconvenience caused newsmen by censorship but he sharply criticized foreign reporting of events in East Pakistan. He said censorship was necessary to preserve internal security.

ALBANY, May 6 -- The Assembly today deferred action until Monday on a bill to revise the Taylor Law and restrict the areas of negotiation that Civil Service labor unions could bring to the bargaining table.

When the New York Football Giants were first clawing and scratching for survival, they faced early disaster in 1926, the second season of their existence. A year earlier, a tantalizing glimpse of what the future might hold had been flashed to Tim Mara, the founder of the team.

Directors of Allegheny Airlines, Inc., and Mohawk Airlines, Inc., agreed yesterday on definitive terms that could lead to a merger of the two carriers. Under terms of the previously announced merger, Allegheny would be the surviving airline.

After meeting for about seven hours yesterday, club owners of the National Basketball Association adjourned without making any decisions about merger possibilities and set another session for this morning.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange took their worst beating in two and a half months yesterday as the list declined in more active trading.

PARIS, May 6 -- For the first time in its history, the French Academy today received the candidacy of an American. He is Julien Green, the novelist. By making an end run around the city's principal bar association in his two new appointments to the Court of Claims, Governor Rockefeller has failed to live up to his pledge that proposed judges would be investigated by their peers for qualifications. This is a dangerous misstep toward more politicizing of the judiciary.
PHILADELPHIA, May 7 -- The chief topic along Boathouse Row on the Schuylkill today was the failure of Marietta to qualify its varsity eight in the opening phase of the two-day Dad Vail Regatta.

GUATEMALA CITY, May 4 -- Almost six months after imposing a state of siege and suspending most constitutional rights, the Government of President Carlos Arana Osorio appears to be making headway in its battle against Guatemala's left-wing guerrillas.

During the academic year, I visit a college campus every ten days or so as a guest lecturer and listener. Two student preoccupations invariably become the core of our dialogues: "What am I here for? How does here connect with what I'm going to be doing out there?"

In this time of fiscal austerity, as unemployment rises and tax revenues continue to lag, the State Legislature in Albany waits for word from New York City on its budgetary priorities. It waits to hear precisely what new taxing authority the city expects to use to raise funds to meet essential needs. It waits . . . and waits. . . .
The New York Drama Critics Circle yesterday picked "Home," a British import, as the best play of the 1970-71 season and "Follies" as the best musical.

The New York Knickerbockers, who were dethroned as champions of the National Basketball Association last month after a one-year reign, traded Cazzie Russell to the San Francisco Warriors last night for Jerry Lucas, an authoritive source said. A Knicks' official, however, could not be reached for comment.
A Brooklyn man tried unsuccessfully to throw a Molotov cocktail onto the crowded rush-hour platform of the Broadway-Nassau subway station on the IND line at 5:45 yesterday afternoon, the police said.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, May 8 (AP) -- Two American fighter-bombers destroyed three antiaircraft guns in North Vietnam yesterday, the United States command reported.

According to press reports, President Nixon's recent blast at the "welfare mess" leaves the impression that many on relief are chiselers who are unwilling "to carry a bed-pan or scrub floors." I believe that this charge does a cruel injustice to the vast majority of the unemployed.
The New York Mets scored two runs in the eighth inning last night to beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 3-1, and defeat Bob Gibson for the second time in 12 days -- which is nice work if you can get it.

WHITE PLAINS, May 7 (AP) -- State Supreme Court Justice Frank S. McCullough of Westchester County has signed a show-cause order, returnable next Thursday, in a suit brought by four individuals and the Scarsdale Audubon Society seeking to bar state spraying of an insecticide from the air.

PEORIA, Ill. -- This medium-size, moderately affluent Midwest city, the symbol of Main Street normality in a thousand worn-out jokes, underwent a very atypical economic experience last year -- declining unemployment.
MOSCOW, May 7 -- Two Soviet demographers said today that a decline in the number of Jews reported in last year's census reflected a process of assimilation.
ALBANY, May 7 -- A bill that sharply reduces the penalties for possession and sale of marijuana was passed overwhelmingly by the Senate here today.

Mayor Lindsay has listed among his options in the present budgetary crisis the closing of the freshman class at City University next year, or the termination of the open admissions policy. Neither of these alternatives is either necessary or desirable.
When you give a gala give a gala. On Thursday night at the New York State Theater the New York City Ballet gave a gala. It was a gala.

The arrest of more than a thousand persons on the steps of the Capitol on Wednesday brought the week's antiwar protests to an ominous climax. In a crass display of arbitrary power, the constitutional rights of these citizens were ignored as they were hauled off to a makeshift detention center. It was a spectacle of lawlessness and repression hardly to be expected in a republic of free men.
SEATTLE, May 7 -- The Federal grand jury for this district was recessed today until next Wednesday, as Miss Bacon's lawyers tied up the Government's investigation with a series of legal moves.

The Board of Examiners, which is under attack by critics who say it should be abolished, released data yesterday that it contends demonstrate that its tests are not biased against blacks or Puerto Ricans.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The "fantastic growth" of textile imports did not abate in the first quarter of this year, a Government official dealing with the textile problem said today.

Yo-Yo Ma is said to have been a prodigy when he was a child, and although he is growing older now -- he is all of 16 -- one can well believe it. The cello recital he gave at Carnegie Recital Hall Thursday night was of a quality to make many an older man green with envy.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Automobiles will use more gasoline and be somewhat harder to drive when nonpolluting machines are introduced, witnesses before a hearing of the Environmental Protection Agency said today.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 6 -- Cambodia has quietly shelved consideration of a proposal by Nationalist China that the two countries exchange embassies and has delayed sending a permanent diplomatic mission to Taipei.

The principal antipoverty organization in Brownsville invited Governor Rockefeller and the entire State Legislature yeserday to come to the decaying, impoverished area of Brooklyn to see firsthand the "genocide" it said was foretold by proposed state budget cuts. The area has been racked by disorders this week.
JERSEY CITY, May 7 (AP) -- A Roman Catholic nun was released today after spending a night in jail because she refused on religious grounds to answer a grand jury's questions about a murder.

The quintet that Kenny Barron brought to Muse, Bedford Avenue at Lincoln Place, Brooklyn, Thursday night was drawn from some of the best jazz sources. In addition to Mr. Barron on piano, it consisted of Herbie Hancock's drummer, Billy Hart;

KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 7 -- The editor of The National Catholic Reporter, one of the most influential Roman Catholic publications in the United States, has been dismissed in a dispute over whether the weekly should continue its aggressively liberal policy.

ALBANY, May 7 -- Strong protests by leading educators led today to the recall from Governor Rockefeller's desk of a bill approved by the Legislature specifying the minimum number of hours college and university teachers should spend in the classroom each week.

MOSCOW, May 7 -- Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet party leader, today told the visiting French Foreign Minister, Maurice Schumann, that he intended to lead a Soviet delegation to Paris later this year, French sources said.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, May 5 -- A new realism pervades the economic-development plans of many Southeast Asian countries, according to participants in a ministerial development conference here.

EAU CLAIRE, Wis., May 7 (AP) -- District Attorney Lawrence W. Durning said today that a warrant charging Al Capp, the cartoonist, with a morals offense against a 20-year-old Eau Claire State University coed had been issued by County Judge Thomas H. Barland.

BONN, May 7 -- This week, as West Germany's mark grew shinier than ever under the massive rubbing of hot dollars pouring into the country, a Bonn journalist approached Economics Minister Karl Schiller with a wicked gleam in his eye.

The golden touch of Norton Simon, the Los Angeles industrialist who is liquidating part of his huge art collection at auction, was evident again yesterday as more of his holdings on the block brought $253,765, about $70,000 over estimate.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (UPI) -- The Commerce Department said today that retail sales increased in March for the fourth consecutive month. A Nixon Administration official hailed the rise as a sign that consumers are gaining confidence in the economy and loosening their purse strings.

TOKYO, May 7 -- Japan, which once exported about 7,000 tons of swordfish a year to the United States, will try to persuade the United States that the Federal Food and Drug Administration's warning against eating swordfish is unfounded.
PEKING, May 1 -- For foreigners Peking is still a tense and touchy place to live, though large areas of the capital long closed to them are in bounds again.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The Defense Department announced today that it would put into effect June 7 a new contract with the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation under which the Government will begin paying out $200-million to maintain production of 81 C-5A transport planes.

CLEVELAND, May 7 -- President Nixon never had a plan to end the Vietnam war and still does not, Representative Jonathan B. Bingham, Democat of the Bronx, said here today as he and nine other House members began a barnstorming effore in behalf of peace efforts.

DALLAS, May 7 -- Charles Coody, the Masters champion, finding his putting touch as keen in Texas as it was in Georgia, gained the lead with a 36-hole aggregate of 135 today in the $125,000 Byron Nelson Golf Classic.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., May 7 -- Two guards at the Matteawan State Hospital were arrested today on indictments handed up by a Dutchess County grand jury charging them with manslaughter in the death of a patient.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally Jr. said today it was "the view of the United States that maintenance of current parities could provide a basis for reopening the markets in various European countries."
Net income of the Quaker Oats Company including special charges moved lower in the quarter and nine-month period ended March 31, figures released yesterday indicated.
Ramon Rodriguiz, a suspended Bronx detective accused of receiving a $200-a-month bribe, testified yesterday that one of the major witnesses against him had threatened him with revenge.

BERLIN, May 7 -- The Western Allies sought to break the deadlock in the four-power negotiations on West Berlin today by engaging the Russians in discussion of practical improvements for this isolated city, leaving controversial issues of status aside.
The Treasury's effort this week to refinance a portion of the national debt fizzled, the Government's debt managers disclosed yesterday.

ROME, May 7 (UPI) -- Rod Laver of Australia shook off an erratic second set today to down Stan Smith of Pasadena, Calif., 6-1, 2-6, 6-2, and move into the semifinals of the Italian tennis championships.

Louise Nevelson's new exhibition, which opens today at the Pace Gallery, 32 East 57th Street, proves once again that the woman simply cannot be trusted. For several years now, from show to show, she has implicitly capped off her career with a final demonstration of her powers of invention, but each following year she comes up with something new.
If the library at the Manhattan House of Detention were open, which it is not, the 1,230 inmates there could read "Dining Out in Any Language."

BONN, May 7 -- The West German Cabinet today drew up a whole array of international monetary controls and stiff domestic reforms to put to the Common Market ministers summoned to an emergency meeting in Brussels tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (UPI) -- The Defense Department announced today that the Army would start Monday on its 48-week destruction of the Nation's entire stockpile of antipersonnel germ warfare weapons, all stored at the Pine Bluff, Ark., Arsenal.

TOULOUSE, France, May 7 -- President Pompidou, in an explicit challenge to critics of the French-British supersonic aircraft venture, flew at twice the speed of sound today in a Concorde. With the President aboard, the Concorde 001 flew at 1,315 miles an hour for 17 minutes.

HAUPPAUGE, L. I., May 7 -- The Magnetic Head Corporation is a tiny, precision-manufacturing company in this Long Island community that is preparing to manufacture modular computer units the company hopes to harness together in clusters powerful enough to compete with some of the largest computers in the world.
TEL AVIV, May 7 -- The United States and Israel found common ground today on crucial issues involved in negotiating a reopening of the Suez Canal, according to American and Israeli diplomats.
Five of six persons who pleaded guilty to a conspiracy to dynamite or fire-bomb several buildings in the city were sentenced to prison yesterday by State Supreme Court Justice Harold Birns.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 7 -- Two fractured ribs and a "dented" vertebrae will not keep Del Insko on the sidelines long. Insko, whose career as a harness racing driver began in 1946, when he was a week short of his 16th birthday, said today that he would return to Roosevelt Raceway tomorrow night to drive in five events.

The art of the 20th century in Mexico has primarily been an art of propaganda, an art that used the image as a kind of manifesto or platform for political messages. The pictorial propaganda of Oroszco, Rivera and Siqueiros were like giant tabloids with militant scare-heads about the abject human condition.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- A judge ruled here today that 600 persons arrested during antiwar demonstrations were being held under conditions that inflicted "cruel and unusual punishment."

CUMBERLAND ISLAND, Ga. -- After years of being coveted as a site for resort housing, a rocket-launching base or a state park, most of this wild, lush island with its 18 miles of flat, hard beach, is now assured of becoming the country's ninth Federally operated public seashore.
The new-issues market scored another strong advance this week although the number of companies going public declined.
LONDON, May 8 -- Since Christopher Plummer dropped out of its cast, rumors of rehersal conflict have dogged the National Theater's singularly incoherent production of "Coriolanus."
LONDON, May 7 -- Amid market expectations of floating rates on Monday, the West German mark and the Swiss franc strengthened further against the dollar today in active foreign-exchange trading.
The antiques show at the Westchester County Center in White Plains is one that appeals to old-fashioned collectors.

Trans World Airlines disclosed yesterday a lengthy series of terms and conditions it has presented to the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation. T.W.A. indicated that these were its requirements before it would "proceed, if possible, with the Lockheed L-1011 program.'

The only immediate practical result of the recent First General Assembly of the Organization of American States in Costa Rica was achieved outside the agenda and off the floor. It was the agreement of Honduras and El Salvador to resume talks looking to a definitive settlement of their brief armed clash in 1969.
Alice Cooper, a boy, played at Town Hall Thursday night with his rock group, which is also called Alice Cooper.

As he had conducted Haydn earlier in the season, so Pierre Boulez conducted the Schubert Sixth Symphony with the New York Philharmonic on Thursday evening. This means an emphasis on contour, steady rhythms, a classic approach with reduced orchestra, and under -- rather than overinterpretation.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 7 -- Well-placed unofficial sources reported the arrival here today of a Soviet military training mission and a shipment of East German police equipment.

The poet's trade, the writer's trade, is a strange one. Chesterton said: "Only one thing is needful -- everything." To a writer this everything is more than an encompassing word; it is literal. It stands for the chief, for the essential, human experiences. For example, a writer needs loneliness, and he gets his share of it.
The Columbia Broadcasting System's documentary, "Selling of the Pentagon," won an Emmy award last night for outstanding achievement in news documentary programing.

VIENNA, May 7 -- President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania today called for the expansion of Comecon, the East European economic community, "to other countries, socialist and non-socialist." He also underscored Rumanian interest in intensifying economic relations with capitalist countries on the basis of "mutual advantage," the official Rumanian press agency reported.
Sometimes you just can't win. Take, for example, the case of Mrs. Bunty Lawrence, chairman of last night's 25th anniversary ball of the Damon Runyon Memorial Fund for Cancer Research.
Representative Hugh L. Carey, Democrat of Brooklyn, said yesterday that the Nixon Administration's welfare-reform legislation should be "changed drastically."

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Republican Senators contended today that spending ceilings imposed by a campaign finance bill now heading for floor debate should be raised to reflect "the actual experience" of the 1970 elections.
The Brownsville section of Brooklyn, wracked by poverty for years and by two days of streets disorders this week, just about returned to its normal state yesterday.
Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that 500 public employes would be laid off by June 1 and 500 other jobs would be eliminated or go unfilled.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 7 -- Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans said today that consumers receive "full satisfaction" from nearly every one of the purchases they make from American businesses.

School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner told community school boards yesterday that they could not prematurely grant tenure, or job security, to teachers and supervisors in an effort to circumvent a new state law that takes effect tomorrow.

The Mobil Corporation and the Petroleum Trades Employes Association filed suits against each other yesterday as the gasoline delivery strike against six major companies by two unions completed its first week.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 7 (AP) -- The Kentucky Colonels held off a late rally by the Utah Stars tonight and posted a 116-110 victory in the third game of the American Basketball Association 4-of-7-game series for the championship. Utah won the first two games.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., May 7 -- The first of two spacecraft designed to orbit Mars was pronounced ready today for launching tomorrow night.

YIRRKALA, Arnhem Land, Australia, April 30 -- Gloom and anger have pervaded this isolated tribal settlement on the remote Gove Peninsula of Arnhem Land, in northern Australia, since a white judge ruled that the wilderness occupied by the dark-skinned aborigines for thousands of years does not belong to them.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 7 -- The French team served notice today that it would be a strong title contender in the 1971 world championships here by scoring a crushing victory over the Aces.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Dr. Seymour Z. Lewin, professor of chemistry at New York University, was granted a patent this week for a method of preserving limestone and marble. The process is being used to protect works of art and national monuments here and abroad.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today that more than 70 locations in 19 states were being studied as possible sites for assembling, testing and launching the proposed space shuttle vehicle.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Attorney General John N. Mitchell rejected tonight a plan for reapportioning Virginia's legislative districts on the ground that the plan discriminated against Negroes.
PARIS, May 7 -- The case of the Chinese physician closed inconclusively today with his departure for Canton.

Your April 23 editorial "The Mayors' Message" states with simple eloquence and clarity the plight of the nation's cities. Unfortunately, the symptoms of the urban cancer are beginning to be detected elsewhere as well.

Northwest Industries, Inc., a holding company with interests in railroads, chemicals, steel and apparel, announced a new acquisition yesterday that will give it a substantial stake in the Scotch whisky market. Ben W. Heineman, president, acting in response to clearance by the Justice Department, said that the company would hand over $120-million on Monday to Schenley Industries, Inc., for the stock of the Buckingham Corporation, importer of Cutty Sark Scotch.

Furnishings designs continue to look like anything but, judging by the exhibition of about 30 imported chairs and lighting fixtures that is now on view through June 12 at Sachs New York, Eighth Avenue at 35th Street.
The Franklin Simon Company, the New York-based ready-to-wear apparel chain, will shortly open another chain of minisize stores, selling dresses exclusively in leading shopping centers.
TOKYO, May 7 -- Japan announced today that she would lower her official discount rate by one-quarter of 1 percentage point, to 5.5 per cent, effective tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The United States formally cleared the way today for the resumption of direct trade with China for the first time in 21 years.

NEW ORLEANS, May 7 (AP) -- The United States cannot maintain its free-trade policies if individual nations and regional blocs continue to discriminate against this country's exports, Representative Wilbur D. Mills said today.

LONDON, May 7 -- Martin Woodhams is a 13-year-old boy who lives in Croydon, a modest London suburb. His farther drives a van. His mother works as a cleaning woman in Croydon Hospital, cleaning up the wards and bathrooms.

ALBANY, May 7 -- Governor Rockefeller's controversial proposal to end rent control of 1.3 million appartments in New York City as they are vacated hit a snag today when three Republican Senators expressed opposition to it and four others were reported to be undecided.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., May 7 -- Senator Edmund S. Muskie was given a warm reception today at the the convention of the International Ladles Garment Workers Union where he directed a barrage of criticism at the Nixon Administration's economic policy.
Stock prices moved slightly lower yesterday, as most investors remained stoic in the face of the latest international currency crisis.

SAN MARINO, May 7 (UPI) -- San Marino, the world's smallest republic, announced Friday night it was establishing diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The nation's unemployment rate edged up slightly in April but, over all, the job situation remained "essentially unchanged," the Labor Department reported today.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., May 7 -- Oyster Bay harbor was ordered closed this morning because of kerosene spills of an undetermined origin.

ST. LOUIS, May 7 (UPI) -- Sid Abel, affiliated with the Detroit Red Wings for more than 30 years as player, coach and general manager, was named coach of the St. Louis Blues today, replacing Scotty Bowman, who resigned one week ago.

T. R. Berner, chairman and president of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation, told shareholders at yesterday's annual meeting in Delaware, that 1971 does not look like a good year for the company because of conditions of the aerospace industry and business in general.
About 300 elderly people heckled Governor Rockefeller to protest state budget cuts as he began a speech yesterday at the 10th Annual Governor's Conference on Aging at the New York Hilton Hotel.

Whatever the Houston Astros pay Joe Morgan to play second base, he earned it last night. The 5-foot-7-inch, 150-pound Morgan, who naturally is nicknamed "Little Joe," rapped out four hits, scored three runs, drove in two and stole two bases as the Astros pounded out 13 hits in routing Jim Bunning and the Phillies, 8-1.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Public confidence in Richard M. Nixon's performance as President, which consistently declined during his first two years in office, has remained steady in the three months since the Laotian incursion, the Gallup Poll reported today.

PAMPLEMOUSSES, Mauritius -- This tiny country is notable for the botanical gardens of Pamplemousses (which means grapefruits), the last dodo bird (which died 300 years ago), the eighteenth-century French romantic novel, "Paul et Virginie," the ancestral forebears of France's former Premier Maurice Couve de Murvilie and a racially mixed society as complex as anywhere on earth.

KARACHI, Pakistan, May 10 -- A special military court sentenced to death Mohammad Feroze Abdullah, a truck driver for Pakistan International Airlines, today on charges of having killed four persons, including a Polish official. Rita Hayworth will not be the summer replacement for Lauren Bacall in the Broadway hit musical "Applause." The noted film actress, who had been scheduled to take over the star role as Margo Channing, the aging Broadway actress, on July 19, notified the producers Monday night that she was dropping out of rehearsals because she was having difficulty learning the part.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- So many plans have gone wrong for the United States in Asia in recent years that it is sometimes forgotten that other plans have gone very well indeed. For example, if Peking and Washington do finally agree to re-establish diplomatic relations, the U.S. Government will be ready with a new generation of China specialists.
When William E. Chatlos, an expert on stockholder solicitation, scanned the General Motors proxy statement, his eye quickly settled on stockholder proposal No. 5.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 11 -- Authoritative sources said today that Angkor Wat, Cambodia's national treasure and the most famous temple of the ruins of Angkor in northwestern Cambodia, had been severely damaged by a Cambodian Army artillery barrage.

Arthur G. McKee Co., announced yesterday the election of George McCuskey as chairman, succeeding Merrill Cox, who has retired and becomes chairman emeritus. The company also elected William F. Richards as group vice president and James A. Loughran as vice president, administration and secretary. Wilmot F. Wheeler Jr., chairman and president of American Chain Cable Company, Inc., was elected a director of the engineering and construction company.

Allegheny Ludlum Industries, Inc., the nation's largest producer of specialty steels, announced yesterday in Pittsburgh that it would raise published prices by about 6.5 per cent, effective May 17, on all stainless-steel products except pipe and tube.
If taste in choice of guest performers for a benefit concert is any indication, the Bloomingdale House of Music is an extremely high-class organization.

Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Bernstein, whose 1970 fundraising party for the Panthers Legal Defense Fund triggered widespread criticism, gave another civil liberties gathering Monday night -- this time in behalf of the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan and his five codefendants.

BRUSSELS, May 11 -- There was progress today -- and some difficulties -- in Britain's negotiations to enter the European Economic Community. The six Common Market members agreed to special arrangements for Britain to continue importing newsprint, plywood and 10 other industrial products at low tariff rates after joining. for developing Commonwealth countries that grow sugar cane.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- A brief ruling today in the House may have opened the way for a historic court test of President Nixon's pocket veto of a medical training bill during the Congressional recess last Christmas.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -Postal rate increases scheduled to go into effect this Sunday cleared a major hurdle today when a Federal judge refused to issue an order blocking them.

A bribery indictment against a young narcotics suspect who had been charged with trying to "corrupt" a policeman with $50 was dismissed yesterday after findings that the money was paid to induce the policeman "to tell the truth."

HONG KONG, May 11 -- Neat, well-furnished and shiny, the big international section of the Hungjao Air Terminal in Shanghai is mostly an empty showpiece.

SYDNEY, Australia, May 11 -- Peking today invited the Australian Labor party, which leads the opposition to the proAmerican Government of Prime Minister William McMahon, to send a delegation to China next month "for discussions concerning relations between the two countries."

Record sales and earnings were achieved by Pet, Inc., in the fiscal year ended March 31, "despite generally unfavorable business conditions during the period," Boyd F. Schenk, president, reported from St. Louis headquarters yesterday.

GENEVA, May 11 -- Yielding to pressure from other members of the disarmament conference, the United States and the Soviet Union agreed today to sponsor talks here by experts on how to verify proposed bans on underground nuclear tests and on chemical weapons.

MOSCOW, May 11 -- Leading Soviet moviemakers called today for more films on current themes and everyday problems after the recent outpouring of productions portraying Lenin, the Revolution and World War II.

NEWARK, May 11 -- A Federal grand jury indicted a 48-year-old Parisian today on charges of smuggling 96 pounds of pure heroin in a Volkswagen camper bus being shipped from France to the United States.

We older citizens who traveled to Washington on April 24 to protest once more our Government's continuation of the Vietnam war, made a grievous error. We should have stayed in Washington and added our support to those younger citizens who were trying by nonviolent methods to turn the policies of this nation around.

Cheryl Toussaint of the Atoms Track Club of Brooklyn, one of the outstanding women middle-distance runners in the nation, will receive the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union's Meritorius Award tonight at the Downtown Athletic Club.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (UPI) -- Federal mediators met today with negotiators for the railroads and the railway signalmen in an effort to avert a nationwide strike next Monday, but the president of the union said prospects for a settlement were dim.
Steve Dunning, the Cleveland Indians' $60,000 bonus baby who was the No. 1 draft choice last June in the free-agent sweepstakes, was supposed to do his pitching in the minor leagues this year.

A cluster of four-story brick apartment buildings in the East New York section of Brooklyn were dedicated by Mayor Lindsay yesterday and praised as examples of how community participation can speed, rather than slow, new construction.

NEW DELHI, May 11 -- Switzerland has agreed to try to resolve the two-week-old dispute between India and Pakistan over the repatriation of their staffs at their closeddown diplomatic missions in Dacca and Calcutta.

Add Nolan Ryan and Dave Marshall to the list of not-previously-canonized New York Mets who are carrying the club on its current streak. Ryan pitched a three-hitter and Marshall hit a grand-slam homer in last night's 8-1 victory over the Houston Astros at Shea Stadium.
The stock market staged a mild rally yesterday, somewhat to the surprise of Wall Street analysts, who keep repeating that a correction appears overdue and that May often sees prices going down.

The trial of a police lieutenant on departmental charges of conspiring with members of his command about the division of bribes was halted yesterday after a police surgeon said the primary witness was not able to take the witness stand.

Edward Durrell Stone, the architect, and Lowell Thomas, the commentator, were among 10 winners of the 1971 Horatio Alger Awards announced yesterday by the American Schools and Colleges Association.

VIENTIANE, Laos, May 11 (AP) -- Laotian Government soldiers and policemen assaulted four North Vietnamese diplomats who walked out on a speech today by Premier Souvanna Phouma when he denounced the Hanoi Government for having sent troops into Laos.

BALTIMORE, May 11 -- C. Oliver Goldsmith's Leematt, a roan speedster, was withdrawn today from the $150,000-added Preakness on Saturday, leaving 11 3-year-olds pointed for the middle jewel of the Triple Crown at Pimlico race course.

A group calling itself the People's Bureau of Investigation reported yesterday an unsuccessful attempt to break into and steal documents from the Federal Bureau of Investigation's office in Garden City, L. I.

Four young pianists played for about an hour apiece before a Carnegie Hall audience yesterday afternoon in the finals of the 27th Leventritt International Competition, but no top winner was chosen. Four other times since the prestigious music award was first offered in 1940, the judges have decided against naming a single winner.

In defiance of their club owners and league commissioners, the players of the rival National and American Basketball Associations announced yesterday they would play an All-Star game in the Houston Astrodome on Friday night, May 28.
When Peter R. Gimbel was a little boy, he put a bucket over his head with a hose coming out the top, dived into a swimming pool and tried to breathe underwater. He has since improved his ways.

ALBANY, May 1 -- Signaling that adjournment must be near, five New York City Democratic legislators spent part of their lunch break today basking in unaccustomed warm sun and tossing a football about the Capitol front lawn.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 11 -- The administrator of Alabama's Alcohol Beverage Control Board acknowledged today that the telephone of an employe of the state agency had been tapped in order to permit recording of conversations.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- A group of former high Government officials, including William McChesney Martin Jr., retired Federal Reserve Board chairman, said today that "decisive action" to bring the United States balance of international payments "to or close to equilibrium is a national and international responsibility of critical priority."
Representative Paul N. McCloskey has backed up his repeated threat to oppose President Nixon in the Presidential primaries unless the President changes his Southeast Asia policy.

Governor Rockefeller's proposal to decontrol vacant apartments will surely hasten the city's decay.
Somerset Hills, Piping Rock and Round Hill won their district series as the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub team matches were completed yesterday.
LONDON, May 11 (UPI) -- Mrs. Billie Jean King of Long Beach, Calif., led an advance of four American women through the first round of the Bio-Strath clay-court tennis tournament today.

One choreographer above all suitable for the one-man show is George Balanchine, and indeed the programs of the New York City Ballet that are simply and purely Balanchine are not infrequently better than those that attempt more variety.
The head of the world's largest full-service ad agency doesn't like that tag "full- service" too much, "because it is basically nondescriptive."

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 11 (UPI) -- Vice President Agnew today described the thousands of antiwar demonstrators who recently crowded the nation's capital as "the same scruffy individuals that caused the disruptions in Chicago in 1968."

TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 11 -- The world champion Aces increased their lead in the qualifying stage of the world championship here today, winning, 20-0 in matches against Brazil and Taiwan. The French team, which had led earlier in the event, had a harder time, losing, 8-12, to the second North American team and beating Brazil, 12-8.

A few weeks ago the Sports Car Club of America changed its qualifying procedure for professional road races. It discarded the custom of timing all cars throughout the practice sessions and adopted the one-car-at-a-time pattern from the oval tracks of other racing clubs.

Elina Mooney likes to work against the grain. If music is fast, she finds ways to be intelligently slow while dancing to it; if a situation suggests all-out fullness of attack, she tends to withhold commitment slightly. It sets up an interest in her dances and puts severe demands upon her dancers, Janet Aaron, Phoebe Neville, Christopher Back and Billy Siegenfeld.

Twenty-six enormous new garbage trucks are expected to be in operation around the city this summer, and although the general public will rarely see them -- sanitation experts hope that the trucks -- which do more than just haul garbage -- may soon revolutionize trash collection.
ROME, May 11 -- In an apostolic letter scheduled to be made public Friday, Pope Paul VI urges Christians to take part in the search for a new kind of democratic society.

The Episcopal Diocese of New York approved a controversial series of resolutions yesterday that will require virtually all of its churches to pay their own way within five years and to triple the money they must contribute to the diocese.

Mayor Lindsay, who has persistently criticized the Nixon Administration for allegedly ignoring the problems of the cities, said yesterday that he did not believe that the President's proposed Gateway National Recreation Area signified a new Federal commitment to the cities.

Four dance companies that generally perform outside the traditional proscenium stage will be presented by the City Center in a special free series in all five boroughs, beginning Saturday and running through May 28.

LONDON, May 11 (AP) -- Ken Buchanan of Scotland, the world lightweight champion, scored a technical knockout over Carlos Hernandez of Venezeula in the eighth round of a scheduled 10-round nontitle tight tonight.

The roadways in Central Park and three other large parks will be closed to vehicles during midday hours for five days later this month as part of what Mayor Lindsay said yesterday was "our effort to get the public to use the parks."
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Total business inventories rose only moderately again in March, though the increase was larger than in January and February, the Commerce Department reported today.

LONDON -- Announcers of the British Broadcasting Corporation escape the fate of the Ephraimite -- but at times, one suspects, narrowly, and only then because they are not within immediate striking distance of the listener. BRUSSELS, May 11 -- The United States threatened implicitly to withdraw its troops from West Germany three years ago if the German central bank did not renounce its rights to convert surplus dollars into American gold.
LONDON, May 11 -- Britain's school policies on black children have come under bitter criticism by an American-educated social worker and teacher.

Time seemed to turn backwards on Monday night at Alice Tully Hall. From some of the sounds that filled the auditorium, from the enthusiasm with which the enthusiastic young audience leaped to its feet, cheering, at every extended climax, it might have been 20 years ago and the band on stage might have been Stan Kenton's brassy juggernaut.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Mike Mansfield, the Senate majority leader, proposed today that the United States cut in half -- to 150,000 men -- the number of its troops in Europe by the end of the year to ease the dollar outflow abroad and economize at home.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, May 12 (AP) -- A North Vietnamese MIG-21 interceptor attacked an unarmed United States reconnaissance plane twice over the Plaine des Jarres in northern Laos while a second MIG-21 circled overhead Sunday, the American command disclosed today.
A Penn Central executive said yesterday that June 1 was the "goal date" for the signing of an agreement for a state take-over of the railroad's Hudson and Harlem Divisions' commuter lines.
SINGAPORE, May 11 -- Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew has charged that Chinese agents in Hong Kong have given a newspaper owner here almost $1.35-million to gain influence in his publication.
TOKYO, May 11 -- The dollar crisis that threw the Western European money markets into chaos last week is driving Japan's financial leaders to the brink of a choice beset with risks.

PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., May 11 -- A scientist who for several years has been arguing that very low levels of radiation affect the survival of the newly born contended today that nuclear reactors at Indian Point on the Hudson River and at Brookhaven National Laboratory on Long Island appear to have increased infant mortality in surrounding areas.

Mayor Lindsay's $892.4-million package of proposed taxes was sent to Albany by the City Council yesterday, unchanged, but with warnings that the Council might not vote into law the full extent of whatever taxes Albany authorized.

MONTREAL, May 11 -- In a festival of five goals and four quarrels that produced 86 minutes in penalties shortly before the finish, the Montreal Canadiens squared the Stanley Cup championship hockey series with the Chicago Black Hawks at two games each tonight with a 5-2 triumph.
The National Retail Merchants Association, the largest trade group in the department store field, appointed a retailer yesterday as its new president and chief staff officer.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The Communications Satellite Corporation told stockholders today that its business would grow another 20 per cent in 1971, after the nearly 50 per cent growth in 1970 that produced the first Comsat dividend last October.

PHILADELPHIA, May 11 -Frank L. Rizzo, the selfdescribed "tough cop" who seemed a sure thing only a month ago in his campaign for Mayor of Philadelphia, appears to have lost most of his lead with a week remaining until Primary Day.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday another reorganization of its Electronic Systems Center, which is responsible for the Big Board's extensive automation programs.

A group of nine of Charlie Chaplin's best-known feature and short films, which the comedian has kept off the general theater market for more than six years, now will be available for worldwide theatrical, television and video cassette showings. The theory of Dr. Arthur R. Jensen, a California psychologist, that blacks are inherently less intelligent than whites, was attacked yesterday by four professors who said it was causing a "grave negative effect" on how black children are taught.

PHILADELPHIA, May 11 -- Formation of the Council for the Advancement of Legal Education, a national nonprofit organization to spur changes in legal training and the profession, was anounced here today by Bernard G. Segal, past president of the American Bar Association.

Fred J. Borch, chairman and chief executive officer of the General Electric Company, has bluntly told the Nixon Administration that the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation should not be granted loan guarantees by the Government unless American-made engines are used in Lockheed's L-1011 Tristar jet airbus.

BALTIMORE, May 11 -- Milton S. Eisenhower, the 71-year-old educator who retired four years ago as president of Johns Hopkins University, was back at his old desk the other day in Homewood House, the graceful Georgian mansion that dominates the lush green campus.

MOSCOW, May 11 -- Nine Soviet Jews went on trial in Leningrad today, charged with organized anti-Soviet activity. Tass, the Soviet press agency, said that eight of them were accomplices of the 12 wouldbe hijackers convicted of treason last December.
ALBANY, May 11 -- A bill creating the state-regulated positions of physician's and specialist's assistants was passed overwhelmingly by the Senate here today.

BRUSSELS, May 11 -- The Belgian Government, nfter n nine-hour Cabinet meeting lasting until 5 A.M. today, decided to stick by its decision reached Sunday not to allow the value of the Belgian franc worth 2 cents to float.
Fresh from a million-dollar debut on the Kentucky Derby, the city's Offtrack Betting Corporation will start taking action today on Saturday's Preakness.

The fighting has died down for the time being, with the Bengali resistance largely routed, but what may become known as the year of the vulture in East Bengal is not ended. Famine now stalks this tragic land of chronic disaster.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 11 -- Thomas A. Shaheen offered testimony today in the bankruptcy proceedings of Lammont du Pont Copeland Jr. that differed sharply from Mr. Copeland's recollections of their business relationship.

The monetary storm that buffeted Europe has shaken the German mark and the Dutch guilder loose from their moorings, blown the Swiss franc and the Austrian schilling higher, increased the sale of coffee, aspirin, and electricity in Brussels, Bonn, and Washington, and ruined the telephone and Telex budgets of several newspapers.

GREENVALE, L. I., May 11 -- C. W. Post College won its third consecutive Collegiate Track Conference outdoor championship today. The host team had 97 points, Adelphi 59 and Southern Connecticut State 38.

ATLANTA, May 11 -- The Executive Council of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. said today that President Nixon's decision to withhold $12-billion appropriated for domestic programs by Congress betrayed "a firm determination to manipulate the Federal Treasury as a political tool in preparation for the 1972 election campaign."

The six-day strike of technicians in the long-lines department of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company ended last night when the company and Local 1150 of the Communications Workers of America settled their dispute.
LONDON, May 11 -- Activity in the European foreign-exchange markets was light today as traders waited for a trend to develop on new currency values.

In a landmark decision, Mr. Justice Samuel A. Spiegel in the Supreme Court of the State of New York, County of New York, expressed a "deep rooted sympathy" for tenants faced with conversion of their apartment houses into cooperatives. Mr. Justice Spiegel urged immediate tightening of the regulations and, specifically, the increase of the number of tenants required from 35 per cent to 51 per cent before conversion could be approved.
ANKARA, Turkey, May 12 (AP) -- An earthquake struck the opium-growing lake country around Burdur in southwest Turkey today. At least 100 were killed, the semiofficial Anatolian news agency said.
LONDON, May 12 -- British mental hospitals were pictured today as severely overcrowded, understaffed and antiquated.

The following account of captivity among Communist troops in Cambodia was written by Kate Webb, chief of United Press International's bureau in Pnompenh. She, a Japanese newsman and four Cambodians disappeared on April 7 while covering fighting along Route 4 about 55 miles southwest of Pnompenh. On April 20 she was reported dead when the body of a woman fitting her description was found in the area.

Jim Bedell, Adelphi's athletics director, and the students who hope to save that university's athletic program may be settiing a pattern that could avoid a trend toward the abolition of sports programs.

MOSCOW, May 12 -- Tass, the Soviet press agency, said today that the Israeli authorities had been consulted by the group of Soviet Jews accused of plotting last year to hijack a Soviet plane to flee the country.

ATLANTA, May 12 -- The Executive Council of the A.F.L.C.I.O. urged Congress and the Administration today to pass new legislation and to reform laws governing trade to better protect American workers and industry from foreign competition.

Continuing the new trend toward schlock nostalgia for the 1940's James Goldstone's "Red Sky at Morning," which opened yesterday at the Beekman and Paramount Theaters, proves with sad clarity that you can almost instantaneously have too much of a bad thing.

GENEVA, May 12 -- Red Cross experts have recommended that an international conference of government experts convening here May 24 consider broadening the guarantees of the Geneva conventions to include giving rebels in a civil war the status of belligerents.
ALBANY, May 12 -- Governor Rockefeller said today that additional state taxes would be necessary to finance new state aid to parochial schools and localities, including New York City.
The City Planning Commission approved yesterday a major sewage treatment plant that will cost $420-million and is intended to help clean up the Hudson River.

MIAMI BEACH, May 12 -Delegates to the convention here of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union approved today a broad legislative program in the social and labor field, including a proposed increase in the minimum wage to $2.50 an hour.
The wedding yesterday of Mick Jagger, lead singer of the Rolling Stones, was a wild scene, somewhat reminiscent of one of the Stone's more hectic concert appearances.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The House Ways and Means Committee completed action today on an $8.8-billion bill that would completely revise the nation's much-criticized welfare system and make significant changes in Medicare and Social Security.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -Even if Congress permits President Nixon's authority to draft most men to lapse July 1, thousands of men who will graduate from college this summer can still be inducted.

ALBANY, May 12 -- Citing the financial problems of the major airlines, Governor Rockefeller announced today that his plan to develop the former Stewart Air Force Base in Newburgh into a commercial jetport would be slowed considerably.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -Representative Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas and chairman of the House Banking Committee, announced plans today for a "full scale investigation" of the international monetary crisis, with the aim of finding out how it had "specifically affected the dollar and the United States economy."

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Two Democratic members of Congress clashed heatedly today with a top official over the Nixon Administration's record in consumer legislation.

ALBANY, May 12 -- After an emotional debate coupled with appeals to respect a colleague's right to seek what is best for his district, the Assembly today rejected a bill affecting a group of condemned homes in Corona, Queens.

ORLANDO, Fla., May 12 (AP) -- A $5-million suit against spacecraft builders by the widow of Lieut. Col. Virgil L. Grissom, one of three astronauts killed in a fire on the Apollo launching pad Jan. 27, 1967, was dismissed yesterday.

An experiment in the use of methadone to detoxify narcotics addicts in the Manhattan House of Detention for Men was termed an "outstanding success'' yesterday by Correction Commissioner George F. McGrath.

The first break in the 12day-old strike by gasoline truck drivers, mechanics and warehouse workers occurred yesterday when 400 striking employes of the Humble Oil and Refining Company (Esso) accepted a new two-year contract with the company.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -There's a touch of unreality in the capital air these days, mostly because the politicians seem to be running a year ahead of the calendar. The impression that Government has run out of things to do, therefore, seems less a case of 1971 spring fever as of 1972 Presidential palpitation.

PRINCETON, N. J. -- Sam's BP Gas Station on U.S. 1 five miles north of here, has a diner in the building behind the pumps. Like most diners, "A Kitchen," as it is called, serves hamburgers, hot dogs and french fries. Most of the menu, however, is given over to Chinese dishes -- shrimp fried rice, beef chop suey and various chow meins.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -Postmaster General Winton M. Blount announced today a sweeping reorganization of the Post Office Department that will affect more than 6,000 postal employes here and in regional offices during the next few months.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The Federal Trade Commission sought today to stop the advertising of grocery "specials" that are not available to customers when they get to the store. It issued a regulation listing such advertising as a violation of Federal laws against unfair or deceptive trade practices and against unfair competitive tactics.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 12 -The string shopping bags of working-class housewives are bulging these days with food and household goods picked from supermarket shelves and street-market stalls.

In a generally bullish market, futures prices of grains and soybeans rose yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (UPI) -- The Government proposed marine waste treatment standards today that it was estimated would cost pleasure boat owners $200 to $300 each.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -The House Ways and Means Committee, in completing action on the welfare bill today, refused to accept the Administration's proposals to reduce Medicare and Medicaid benefits by more than $800-million.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 12 -- President Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan has told Secretary General Thant that United Nations emergency help for East Pakistan is not needed now but he left open the possibility of accepting international aid in the future.
