Rabbi Meir Kahane and six other members of the Jewish Defense League were arrested last night by United States Treasury agents and charged with conspiracy to violate Federal gun and bomb regulations.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 12 (AP) -- The United States command said today that Air Force Phantom jets had destroyed 13 antiaircraft guns around the Mugia Pass in North Vietnam.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 12 -- Mrs. A. Sherburne Hart of Baltusrol and Mrs. DeWitt Alexandre of Somerset Hills took a two-stroke lead in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association 36-hole better-ball-ofpartners tournament today over the 6,048-yard, par-74 Round Hill Club course.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -Representative Paul N. McCloskey Jr. of California, who is preparing to challenge President Nixon in at least four Republican primaries, accused the Administration today of lying to the American people and concealing information from them.
MIAMI, May 12 -- It was almost like a class reunion here today at the annual meeting of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey).

Thousands of customers of Blair Co., an insolvent member firm of the New York Stock Exchange, will be able to obtain their long-frozen cash and securities as a result of a court action yesterday. The United States District Court here granted an application for a stay of ordinary bankruptcy proceedings and authorized Patrick J. Scorese, an exchange-appointed liquidator, to continue transferring accounts.
Brian McElroy, the only runner who has trained with Jim Ryun and Marty Liquori during the last year, believes that Sunday's Dream Mile at Franklin Field will be closer than most people think.
A Staten Island ferryboat carrying 3,000 passengers was tossed by a sudden shift in the current into the end of a Manhattan terminal Slip during the morning rush hour yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Daniel Z. Henkin, Assistant Secrectary of Defense for Public Affairs, criticized in Congressional testimony today the content and editing of the Columbia Broadcasting System's controversial program, "The Selling of the Pentagon."

John Cranko's "Romeo and Juliet," which had its final two performances of the Stuttgart Ballet season at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday, is a most powerful dance drama. Of all the major workings of the Prokofiev score -- and in more than 30 years they have become innumerable, this one is the best.
A reduction in Medicaid benefits that was scheduled to start this Saturday for hundreds of thousands of New York State residents was temporarily prevented yesterday by two Federal judges.

Running just as fitly as in a glittering workout last Friday morning, Rest Your Case of the Cragwood Stable scored by a neck yesterday in the $35,250 Youthful at Aqueduct, the first stakes race of the year for 2year-olds at local tracks.

ALBANY, May 12 -- Governor Rockefeller and Governor William T. Cahill of New Jersey announced today that they would seek legislation to make possible tighter security of cargo on the New York waterfront.
A Federal judge ruled yesterday that a construction union must give compensatory pay to Negroes deprived of work because of the union's discriminatory practices.

NEW HAVEN, May 12 -- Mrs. Ericka Huggins testified today that she "didn't know what was happening" when she saw Alex Rackley being taken at gunpoint from Black Panther headquarters here on the night he was murdered.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -The National Trust for Historic Preservation presented awards yesterday for outstanding work in the preservation of historic sites.
The United States Gypsum Company said yesterday that it will raise gypsum prices by 5 per cent to 6 per cent, effective June 7.

Writers like to talk about getting away from it all, turning their backs on the world to confront their work, isolating themselves in a snug cocoon of contemplation and creation. They are forever setting out for small towns on the southern coast of Spain where no tourist ever ventures. Some even like to imagine themselves in prison for a short term.
What makes one man's make-up technique and hair styling worth $150 a session?

The New York Mets' hot streak was interrupted yesterday by Tom Seaver, of all people, when the Houston Astros scored four runs in the sixth inning and defeated him for the second time in two weeks, 5-4.
The excitement began a couple of weeks ago.

Mike Cuellar, one of the three good pitching reasons why the Baltimore Orioles have won two straight pennants and are favored to make it three, returned to form last night by hurling a one-hitter -a third-inning single by Jerry May -- and posting a 6-0 triumph over the Kansas City Royals.
The bipartisan House effort to resurrect the supersonic transport program began right after Congress killed the project seven weeks ago and was kept at a low key so as not to alert the opposition.

BRUSSELS, May 12 (Reuters) -- Paul W. McCracken, chairman of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers, said today the United States and other countries must explore ways of better coordinating economic policies.

LONDON, May 12 (AP) -The Lockheed chairman, Daniel J. Haughton, left for the United States today to face what he called "the last big hurdle" in the path of the Rolls-Royce RB-211 engine deal for his company's Tristar jet -- the loan guarantee from Congress.

Despite statements to the contrary, 2.5 million Vietnam veterans have not dropped out or disappeared. With few exceptions, they are pursuing their interrupted careers and education, free of self-induced breast-beating, proud of their contribution to American defense and the Vietnamese future.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -Personal income rose $4.5-billion in April, well below the average monthly rise in the first quarter of $6.5-billion, the Commerce Department reported today.
MILWAUKEE May 12 -- Unlike several of the Yankees who made quick one-day visits home earlier this week, Mel Stottlemyre remained with the team and let his wife come to him.
Interest rates on high-grade utility bonds were raised ever so slightly yesterday, and the small increase in yield seemed to spark a modest recovery in the corporate sector of the capital markets.

In connection with your recent editorial on the subject of "Phantom Pensions in Industry," it will be of interest to you and your readers to know that I recommended the introduction of a bill in the State Legislature on Jan. 13, (S. 1671, A. 1865), to establish vested pension rights for employes in private industry and to regulate and administer such employe pension funds.

Patrolman John Corliss stood in the basement of the 32d precinct station on West 135th Street yesterday and watched a crowd of Harlem schoolchildren milling around exhibits on drugs and police work that he had designed and built.

The Columbia Daily Spectator, the student-run newspaper at Columbia University, announced yesterday that the Internal Revenue Service had decided to abandon its attempt to revoke the paper's taxexempt status.

No evidence of a significant upturn in the business of the International Paper Company or in the paper industry has been seen, Paul A. Gorman, chairman and president of International Paper, told more than 700 stockholders at yesterday's annual meeting in the Biltmore Hotel here.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- The Nixon Administration supported today an increase in the minimum wage from $1.60 an hour to $1.80 next January, but urged a two-year delay before it is moved to $2.

SALT LAKE CITY, May 12 (AP) -- Zelmo Beaty led Utah's balanced offense with 32 points tonight as the Stars downed the Kentucky Colonels, 137-127, to take a 3-2 lead in the American Basketball Association championship playoffs.
An impressive collection of dog art was on view yesterday in the McAlpin Hotel during the Dog Fancier's club's last meeting until next fall.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -From a tactical standpoint, the critical element in the House turnabout on the SST was the organized shift of nearly a score of Republicans from opposition to support for the project or to nonvoting neutrality today.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange finished mixed yesterday in light trading.
Ninety court reporters walked off their jobs in Criminal Courts throughout the city for more than an hour yesterday after a Brooklyn Criminal Court stenographer was jailed for alleged contempt.

While the Montreal Canadians and Chicago Black Hawks await the resumption of their Stanley Cup championship series in Chicago tonight, Emile Francis, the general manager-coach of the New York Rangers is plotting next year's downfall of the winning team.

CANNES, France, May 12 -- The Cannes Film Festival is celebrating its twenty-fifth birthday with as much starspangled folderol and oldtime glitter as the festival director, Robert Favre Lebret, could muster.

BONN, May 12 (UPI) -- The American dollar inched upward on the European money markets again today, but trading was light as most speculators held onto their money and waited to see what would happen next.
SEATTLE, May 12 -- Leslie Bacon refused today to tell a grand jury what she did March 1, the day the United States Capitol was bombed, her lawyers said.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -Senator Alan Cranston, Democrat of California, proposed today that the board of directors of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation be forced to resign as a condition of the company's receiving a Government guarantee for $250-million in loans that it needs to continue operating.

" Life. Liberty. And whatever became of the pursuit of happiness?" That's one of the questions being asked this evening on "Tomorrow's People," written, produced, directed and narrated by Warren Wallace for Columbia Broadcasting System's Channel 2.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (Reuters) -- The United States Court of Appeals upheld today a Federal Communications Commission ruling abolishing special preferential press rates that news services have long received on private-line telegraph and telephoto transmission.

The dollar eased somewhat in the New York foreign exchange market yesterday. The pound sterling, the German mark, the Dutch guilder and the Japanese yen all gained in relation to the dollar in trading that dealers described as "starting to get back toward normal."

TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 12 -- The world champion Aces now seem certain to meet France in the final of the 1971 Bermuda Bowl competition scheduled to begin here Saturday. A brave bid by the Australian team to move closer to second position failed tonight when France pulled back from a 19-point deficit at half-time to tie the match, 10-10, in victory points.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 12 -- Thomas A. Shaheen, a money broker who has been testifying here at the bankruptcy proceeding of Lammot du Pont. Copeland Jr., denied today that he had siphoned funds from their enterprises to Europe.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (UPI) -- The Federal Communications Commission was asked tody to deny a brodcast license to Charles Evers, Mississippi civil rights leader, and associates, because of Mr. Evers's description of himself as a former "pimp, bootlegger and numbers racketeer."

LOS ANGELES, May 12 -- The Environmental Protection Agency acknowledged today that observations reportedly indicating excessive amounts of lead in the Los Angeles atmosphere had been withheld from public dissemination for more than a year.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., Democrat of North Carolina urged the Justice Department today to put aside the "vain and false panacea of preventive detention" and to support legislation to secure speedy trials of Federal criminal cases.
BRUSSELS, Thursday, May 13 -- The negotiations on enlargement of the Common Market made major progress early today that brought final agreement into view.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (UPI) -- Representative Bella S. Abzug, one of four legislators severely criticized by their colleagues for welcoming 1,500 antiwar protesters to the Capitol May 5, greeted participants in a 24 - hour peace vigil on the Capitol steps today.

Citizens of the Bronx, a borough not known for its artistic riches, woke up yesterday to find the Metropolitan Museum of Art in their midst. In the massive rotunda of the Bronx County Courthouse, the Manhattan institution has hung a show of 28 important paintings from its own collection -- works by Van Gogh, Courbet, Monet, Winslow Homer, Benjamin West, and contemporaries such as Milton Avery, Romare Bearden and Robert Motherwell.

FLEMINGTON, N. J., May 12 -- Thomas F. Patton, chairman and chief executive officer of the Republic Steel Corporation, told its annual meeting here today that Republic suffered a profit decline in the first quarter largely because of its heavy involvement in stainless and alloy steels, which have been battered by competition from imports.

JERUSALEM, May 12 -- Foreign Minister Abba Eban assured a restive hard-line opposition today that Israel was not yet committed to any with drawal from the Suez Canal cease-fire line, but he defended the current search for an interim settlement as a step toward the "attainment of peace."

The Police Department yesterday displayed publicly for the first time its newest device for keeping an eye on things: A helicopter-mounted television camera that can relay pictures instantly to Police Headquarters or anywhere else on the department's closed-circuit TV network.
PARIS, May 12 (Reuters) -The Laotian pro-Communist Pathet Lao called today for an immediate halt of United States bombing and an unconditional cease-fire in Laos.

The economic recession has intensified a chronic problem for the less skilled people looking for work. Federally financed programs provide them with training, but once they have finished their course, they find few jobs where they can make use of their new skills. This mismatch occurs because the subprofessional jobs for which they have been trained exist largely in the public service, but cities and counties are financially too strapped to hire them.
Gary Gentry of the New York Mets flew home to Phoenix, Ariz., yesterday after he received word that his 3-year-old son Chris had almost drowned in the family's swimming pool.

Andrew Soltis, one of America's most promising young players, has won the championship of New York's Marshall Chess Club for the fourth time in five years. Soltis posted a 10-1 score and Dr. Orest Popovych was second.

Two works new to New York were introduced at the Composers Theater Concert given at the New School on Tuesday night by Robert Helps, pianist, and Rudolf Kolish, violinist. One of the pieces was Mr. Helps's Quartet for Piano, and the other was Roger Sessions's Piano Sonata No. 3.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 12 -The ultraleftist revolt has badly disrupted tea exports, long Ceylon's pride and her prime source of foreign exchange.

The Madison Avenue Magic Promenade, a program designed by the Lindsay administration to bring people together in the city after dark, seems to have done the opposite for some.

PARIS, May 12 -- Jacques Rueff, whose latest book quotes Washington's past monetary prognoses for ironic effect, had kind words for the United States this week. But they were the kind words of a mourner, grieving not alone for the United States but for the economy of the West as a whole.
Parents supporting Donald Barr in his fight to remain as headmaster of the Dalton School won a victory yesterday in State Supreme Court here.

The National Securities and Research Corporation, which has more than $900-million in mutual fund assets under management, announced yesterday that it had completed arrangements to insure investors in its Fairfield Fund against long-term financial losses. Fairfield is a growth fund not designed for current income.

Northwest Airlines, Inc., reported yesterday for the first quarter of this year a net loss of $11,811,866, the first loss for the period since 1962, largely because of reduced revenues resulting from the lengthy clerks' strike that ended last Dec. 31.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Will somebody please turn off the 1972 Presidential election campaign? I., May 13 -- East Berlin is a world apart from east Long Island, but Walter Felsenstein, an opera impresario who is used to having a foot in two worlds, easily made the transition this week when he brought the expertise of the Komische Oper to the Stony Brook campus of the State University of New York.

The Pacific Lighting Corporation said it has agreed to buy Blue Goose Growers, Inc., a fruit packer and marketer for about $22,600,000. Under an agreement approved by the Board of Estimate yesterday, the drafty, cavernous barns that served ocean-going travelers in the heyday of steamships will at long last be superseded by a modern terminal on the Hudson.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The Democratic Policy Council proposed today the complete federalization of the nation's welfare program over the next three years and urged the immediate enactment of a family assistance program that would provide for a minimum family income averaging about $4,000 a year.

CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., May 13 -- A citizens' group won a postponement today of safety hearings on Consolidated Edison's nearly completed second nuclear power generating plant at Indian Point until July 13 to 18.
Aggressive trading in consumer-oriented health-care issues caused sharp fluctuations in these stocks yesterday as the general market took a slight dip.

Former President Lyndon B. Johnson describes his forth-coming White House memoirs as a book reflecting his own personal and political point of view rather than as an attempt at "a complete and definitive history of my Presidency."

Business and industry were warned yesterday of the cost of continued sex discrimination at the opening sessions of a two-day national conference on equal pay and promotion for women. And women were told that they were not applying enough pressure.

The Super Bowl Game returned to the television screen Wednesday night in living, breathing color and once again a field goal in the final five seconds gave the Baltimore Colts a 16-13 victory over the Dallas Cowboys. Sounds exciting, eh? You should have seen it in the telescoped, half-hour version. Wow!

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The new game in the capital is called G-man, and it consists of guessing who will succeed J. Edgar Hoover as director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The favorite among those playing the game, inside as well as outside the Nixon Administration, is Supreme Court Justice Byron R. White, whose supporters include career men at the F.B.I.

Hal Wissel, who rebuilt Lafayette's basketball team into a tournament contender during the last tour years, was named yesterday as Fordham's head basketball coach. His first comment was: "I intend to honor my four-year contract at Fordham."

The National Basketball Association struck back at players of the N.B.A. and rival American Basketball Association yesterday by citing possible contract violations in their decison to play an all-star game in Houston May 28.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The nominations of six federal judges for courts in the New York area were screened today by a Senate Judiciary subcommittee and sent to the full committee for approval, possibly next week.

Polce Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy announced yesterday that Robert Daley, a freelance writer and former correspondent of The New York Times, would replace Wilfred N. Horne as the Police Department's deputy commissoner in charge of press relations on June 11.

Governor Rockefeller of New York and Gov. William T. Cahill of New Jersey are expected to announce Sunday the details of legislation that would require the Port of New York Authority to build rail links between Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan and Kennedy International Airport, and between Pennsylvania Station in Newark and Newark Airport.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The nation's total output of goods and services rose a little more in this year's first quarter than the preliminary estimate a month ago had indicated, the Commerce Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, Va. -- The town water system has been acting up lately, so the Mayor of this small Virginia Blue Ridge Mountain community trudged into the soggy hills the other afternoon to see about the cracks in the reservoir and the town's elusive underground mountain spring.
VALATIE, N. Y., May 13 -- Virginia O'Hanlon Douglas, who as a child was reassured that "Yes, Virginia, there is a Santa Claus," died today at the age of 81.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- Federal officials have decided to permit an indefinite delay in the reporting of 51 types of industrial waste discharge into waterways, Nixon Administration sources said today.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The Nixon Administration expects Congress to approve welfare reform legislation on the ground that the new program is less objectionable than the present system.
A new cycle of songs by Vincent Persichetti entitled "A Net of Fireflies" was given its first performance by Carolyn Reyer, mezzo-soprano, at Tully Hall on Wednesday night.

GENEVA, May 13 -- The 25-nation disarmament conference ended its winter session today. The co-chairmen, James F. Leonard of the United States and Aleksei A. Roshchin of the Soviet Union, expressed cautious hope that it would be possible to complete work on a treaty prohibiting biological weapons when the conference reconvened June 29.

ROCHESTER, May 13 -- Two of the fathers of photojournalism, Felix Man and Stefan Lorant, have come together on American soil to pour the wine of triumphant recollection. The men thrust news photography into its modern format in Europe 40 years ago.

The SCM Corporation announced yesterday that it has combined its electrical consumer products into a new consumer appliance division. The division which will include Smith-Corona Typewriters, Proctor-Silex appliances and Shetland - Lewyt vacuum cleaners, will be headed by George F. Burns as president. Mr. Burns was in charge of SCM's Smith-Corona Marchant Division.

KANSAS CITY, May 13 (UPI) -- Carl Taylor, the Kansas City Royals outfielder who removed himself from last night's game in Baltimore and then burned his baseball equipment in the locker room, notified the Royals today that he was in Sarasota, Fla., where his mother was ill.

PARIS, May 13 -- The dollar crisis has created tremendous frictions in Europe, but it also may be the catalyst that brings Europe closer together. There are chances that the Europeans may gang up against the United States to get their points across. WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- The Army refused today to let First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. go free while his conviction for murdering at least 22 South Vietnamese civilians at Mylai is reviewed all the way up to President Nixon.

BONN, May 14 -- The West German Government cautioned today that an abrupt reduction of American troop strength in Europe would seriously upset the balance of power there, threatening not only Western Europe but also the United States.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Industrial production rose a little in April as further evidence of a gradual recovery of the economy from last year s recession, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

NEW DELHI, May 14. -- Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Government, apparently to demonstrate its commitment to the socialist platform on which it was elected last March, has taken over the management of all private general insurance companies in India, including the 42 foreign ones.

PITTSBURGH, May 14 -- Union printers walked off their jobs early today, forcing this city's two daily newspapers to cease publication. The strike was the second to shut down newspapers here this year.

CANNES, France, May 14 -- Luis Bunuel, who rarely attends his own conferences at film festivals, astonished everyone here today by coming to one held by Dalton Trumbo, whose first film, "Johnny Got His Gun" had just been screened.

The Soviet Grand Master, Viktor Kerchnoi, defeated a countryman, Yefim Geller, in Moscow on Thursday in the first game of their challengers' quarter-final for the world chess Championship. Geller exceeded the time limit on the 36th move and Korchnoi was declared the victor.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 14 -- The Federal Trade Commission's proposed penalty of "corrective advertising" could well kill off certain products, a commission official told some of the nation's leading advertising agency executives here today.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 14 -- The Arab world seemed stunned today by the political crisis in Egypt. Supporters of Cairo's policies expressed deep concern, while more conservative Arab groups appeared pleased.

SCARSDALE, N. Y. -- Nestled near some young saplings on a broad field outside the Quaker Ridge School is a festive-looking play structure. It is painted red, yellow and blue, has two slides, a climbing platform and a fire pole and during school recess is covered with a blur of rapidly moving children.
The Coastal States Gas Producing company reported yesterday gains in revenues and net income for the nine months ended March 31.

The Faculty Senate of the City University of New York -- representing the 15,000 faculty members of the University's twenty colleges and professional schools -- is deeply disturbed by questions that have recently been raised regarding faculty "productivity."

OTTAWA, May 14 (Canadian Press) -- Canada recorded another $70-million surplus in her international balance of payments during the first quarter of 1971, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today.

The New York Yankees came back home with a five-game winning streak last night, but it was promptly ended when Ray Lamb pitched the Cleveland Indians to a 2-1 victory before 10,541 customers at Yankee Stadium.

The voice of industry, outlining current programs on equal opportunity for women and some of the problems still to be faced, was heard yesterday at the final session of a two-day conference on equal pay and promotion for women.

NHULUNBUY, Australia -- A $38.6-million modern town, completely air-conditioned and with real gems embedded in the walls of every home, is rising here on the hot red earth of the remote Gove Peninsula of Arnhem Land.

MOSCOW, May 14 -- Soviet nuclear physicists reported today that they had achieved an energy of two billion electron volts by colliding beams of electrons and positrons head on. This is the highest energy achieved so far in such collisions.
John D. Rockefeller 3d will retire June 30 from the board of trustees of the Rockefeller Foundation, after 40 years of service, nearly half of them as board chairman.

Mohawk Airline jet pilots will receive pay increases averaging 11.8 per cent a year over a 37-month period under a contract settlement between Mohawk and the Air Line Pilots Association announced yesterday.

BALTIMORE, May 14 -- The backstretch at Pimlico was bathed in sunlight at 7:30 this morning, more than enough light for the curious and the rival trainers to look at and wonder about Canonero II, the Kentucky Derby winner from Venezuela who isn't even the favorite for tomorrow's $189,900 Preakness.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange ended lower yesterday in slightly heavier trading.

Four New York policemen and a policewoman were promoted to detective yesterday for their campaigns against police corruption. Among those honored by Police Commis sioner Patrick V. Murphy with the presentation of the gold badge of a detective was Frank Serpico.

Rogers conveyed a single, unmistakable impression last week to the reporters traveling with him on his Middle Eastern tour: He is enjoying his job these days as never before.

ACROSS the country, some 20,000 blue- and white-collar workers are demonstrating that the four-day week is no longer a figment of a union organizer's imagination. They are members of the Thank-God-It's-Thursday Club: they get every Friday off in addition to Saturdays and Sundays.

In answer to Richard Hudson's question, "Whatever Became of the Travel Sticker'' (Travel section, April 18), let us reassure him that they are alive and doing very well, thank you. We produce millions of self-adhesive stickers each year with glues that not only stick to plastic suitcases but also are engineered to withstand the rapid temperature changes involved in jet travel -- an even greater challenge.

Ralph S. Saul, president of the American Stock Exchange, suggested yesterday that the abolition of fixed sales commissions for stock transactions would destroy the central securities markets as they are known today.

The metropolitan area's railroads were striving early this morning to resume full service following the end last night of the signalmen's strike, which had curtailed service for 145,000 rail commuters here.
The sounds of warm Pacific waves rolling up a Samoan beach swirled through the newest exhibition hall at the American Museum of Natural History yesterday.

SARASOTA, Fla., May 18 (AP) -- William P. Tavoulareas, president of the Mobil Oil Corporation, told stockholders today that concern about ecology is the main barrier to expanded oil exploration, especially in promising offshore areas.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 18 -- American Airlines "will be in the black" this year, even though it operated at a net loss of $25.6-million in the four months ended April 30, George A. Spater, president, said today. In calendar 1970, the airline operated at a net loss of $26.4million.

TRENTON, May 18 -- Gov. William T. Cahill today ordered Robert Dilts superseded as prosecutor of Bergen County and announced that Mr. Dilts was being investigated for his "official conduct in office."

One facet of your editorial policy seems to be completely inconsistent and wholly contradictory. You state that the modern conscience deems capital punishment revolting and barbaric. You further add that the hangman, the electric chair and the gas chamber have no place in a civilized society.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (UPI) -- The United States Chamber of Commerce warned today that antipollution laws could kill entire industries and that the Government should be ready to pay for the economic consequences.

PARIS, May 18 -- When President Pompidou and Prime Minister Heath hold seven hours of intimate conversation on Thursday and Friday, they will have to use interpreters because neither knows enough of the other's language to speak for himself.

Agnes Mongan, a brilliantly rational woman who relishes her sobriquet, "La folle du Fogg," was the recipient of festive tributes Monday night upon the occasion of her retirement as director of Harvard University's Fogg Art Museum.

HANOVER, N. H., May 18 -The Dartmouth College undergraduate faculty has voted overwhelmingly to ask the Dartmouth board of trustees to review in June a recent decision to consider establishing an associated school for women here rather than admitting women directly to the college.
Donald Barr, the embattled headmaster of the Dalton School had won a large measure of support early this morning withe election of a new president and new member of the board of trustees.

Put this in your locomotive and smoke it: There can be little doubt that shareholders and creditors of the Penn Central Company are playing an elaborate game of poker over the few remaining assets of this holding company.
BERKELEY, Calif , May 18 -The Berkeley City Council rejected last night a bid to appoint a University of California graduate student, Richard Brown, to a vacancy on the Council.
A $678.2-million New York City school construction program for 1972-73 was tentatively proposed yesterday by Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner.

PARIS, May 18 -- An official of the European Economic Community has suggested that the monetary crisis has been aggravated by West German officials who talk too much and while not mentioning him specifically has pointed the finger at Bonn's Economics and Finance Minister, Karl Schiller.

ROME, May 18 -- Italian authorities acted today to halt further pollution of the country's west coast and to alert the public against what they described as grave and continuing deterioration of the environment.

NEW HAVEN, May 18 -- In six hours of argument -- using shouts, sarcasm and sometimes insults -- the three lawyers in the Seale-Huggins murder trial today summed up for the jury their different versions of the kidnapping and killing of Alex Rackley in May, 1969.

The Firestone Tire Rubber Company achieved record sales and earnings in the second fiscal quarter ended April 30. This lifted the half-year sales to a new peak and earnings to the second highest in the company's history, the company's report disclosed yesterday.

SEATTLE, May 18 -- Leslie Bacon, who has been in custody for three weeks as a material witness in an investigation of the bombing of the United States Capitol, was offered a limited immunity by the Government tonight so that she might be required to answer questions put to her by a grand jury.

The convict who confounded prison officials by slipping past the supposedly escape-proof gates of the Attica Correctional Facility was captured yesterday morning in Greenwich Village. "He was so surprised he couldn't say anything," said John J. McCarthy, the head of the Correction Department bureau that coordinated the more than month-long man-hunt for the fugitive, Joseph Sullivan.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -President Nixon's plan to merge the Peace Corps, VISTA and four smaller volunteer antipoverty programs into a new agency survived its first important test in Congress today.

ALBANY, May 18 -- The Assembly today approved by a vote of 88 to 59 a measure sponsored by Governor Rockefeller to create the office of Welfare Inspector General with broad powers to investigate state and local welfare operations.

There is no easy approach to "Part of the Family." Revolving around the deaths of three young persons "caught in the crossfire of our nation's political and social crises," it is really -- somewhat like Edward Albee's fine "All Over" -- about life, about the lives of the surviving family and friends.

An expected victory by Kosgrove Stable's unbeaten Bold Reasoning in the $20,000 feature and father-and-son winning daily doubles rides by Robert Woodhouse and his dad, Hedley, provided sparkling moments at Aqueduct yesterday.

And is the solution of this nation's international financial problems a realignment of currencies? A sharp conflict exists within the Nixon Administration over what the balance of payments policy is and should be.
The nation's economy was hit hard by the rail strike yesterday before Congress voted to halt the strike, as thousands of workers were laid off in the auto, coal and food industries.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 14 -- In the second month of the Ceylonese student rebellion, a self-styled spokesman for the rebels has emerged here. His code name is "Tilak," which means jewel in Sinhalese, and he is busy looking up Western journalists here while the Ceylonese authorities are trying to hunt him down.

William R. Forman, chairman of Cinerama, Inc., announced yesterday an agreement by Cinerama to sell 3 million shares of the company's stock to Newport Industries, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of National Bulk Carriers, Inc., at $3.125 a share and to grant a five-year option to the pur-purchaser to acquire an additional 1 million shares at the same price.
The second mixed bill of the Stuttgart Ballet, which was unveiled at the Metropolitan Opera House on Monday night, proved markedly less effective than the company's earlier mixed program.

The J. C. Penney Company had a 13.7 per cent gain in net income on a 9.9 rise in sales in the first quarter ended May 1, William M. Batten, chairman, told the annual meeting here yesterday. Penney's is the country's second largest departmentstore and catalogue chain after Sears, Roebuck Co.
TRENTON, May 18 -- A special three-judge Federal Court refused today to nullify existing public school district lines in New Jersey to force racial integration.

Mrs. John V. Lindsay officially unveiled architectural plans for the new Brooklyn Children's Museum yesterday, while many on hand for the ceremony speculated as to when and whether it would actually he built.

The New York Film Festival, scheduled for Oct. 1 to Oct. 15 at Lincoln Center's Vivian Beaumont Theater, will present perhaps 12 fewer films this year than it did last year. It has reappointed Richard Roud as director.

" All I could talk about was babies and recipes!" This is the headline of a recent advertisement on the plight of the woman who is intellectually out of it. While no one would call Mary McCarthy intellectually out of it, the line comes to mind in connection with her new novel, "Birds of America."

Bausch Lomb, Inc., announced yesterday in Rochester, the election of Daniel G. Shuman as chairman and Jack D. Harby as president of the optical goods and scientific instruments company. William W. McQuilkin, who has been president since 1959 and chairman since 1969, was elected chairman of the executive committee, succeeding Carl S. Hallauer, who will continue as a director of the company.

HONG KONG Wednesday, May 19 (Reuters) -- Eight British soldiers inadvertently drove across the Chinese frontier yesterday, were held for several hours and released early today, a Government spokesman said.

With casual grace and an air of genuine pleasure in what they were doing, the Madrigal Singers of C. W. Post College strode, singing, on to the Tully Hall stage Monday night to open the concert they shared with the college's Chamber Singers.
The State Supreme Court annulled yesterday a state directive that barred Medicaid payments for abortions to all but "medically indicated" cases.

The Board of Education was asked yesterday by Controller Abraham D. Beame to withdraw a "completely unnecessary" proposed lease for a district school board office that would cost the city $413,294 over five years.
A 19-year-old deaf youth was charged yesterday in the death of the wife of a Bronx patrolman and his two infants, killed when they were struck by an auto while walking on a Bronx sidewalk.

MOSCOW, May 18 -- The lawyers for the nine Soviet Jews on trial for anti-Soviet activity asked the Leningrad court today to take account of the defendants' backgrounds and hand down lighter sentences than those demanded by the prosecutor yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -Four rehabilitated drug addicts told a Presidential commission today that compulsory elementary school instruction on the dangers of drug abuse -- including prekindergarten indoctrination -- would be the greatest preventive to future addiction.

The first formal and official announcement of the industrywide program of advertising self-regulation was made yesterday at the first international meeting of the Council of Better Business Bureaus in Miami.

Pusillanimous is the word to characterize the conduct of the Korean "police action" by President Harry S. Truman. Wretched characterizes the conduct of the Vietnam conflict by Presidents Kennedy, Johnson and Nixon.

A need for more moisture in the Florida citrus belt, a strong demand for concentrated orange juice and expectations of further cash price increases sent prices of concentrate futures up as much as 1 1/8 cents a pound yesterday on the Cotton Exchange here.
Frank Mankiewicz, the Washington columnist who was press secretary to the late Senator Robert F. Kennedy, is expected to join George S. McGovern's presidential campaign this week.

LOS ANGELES, May 18 --Several studies described here today indicate that relatively simple screening programs can detect breast cancer at an earlier, more curable stage, producing a much better chance of surviving the disease, the most common cancer that can be fatal to women.
SALT LAKE CITY, May 18 (AP) -- The Utah Stars, behind the 36-point shooting of Zelmo Beaty, routed the Kentucky Colonels, 131-121, tonight to win the American Basketball Association championship.
The Lindsay administration's welfare budget, its job-cutback claims and its projected taxyield figures were attacked yesterday by City Councilmen.
The credit markets weakened more yesterday, and interest rates continued their relentless climb.
Are Boy scouts being used as "informers" by the Federal Bureau of Investigation?
WASHINGTON, May 18 -The Nixon Administration won a preliminary skirmish today in its fight to keep alive a key part of the President's proposal for revenue sharing with the states and localities.

The Bank of America finally admitted yesterday that its $100-million issue of 6 1/4 per cent capital notes -- which were first offered through its nearly 1,000 branches in California in early April -- has been a flop. The bank said that the issue would be withdrawn on Friday, with $30-million of the bonds still unsold.

WASHINGTON, Wednesday, May 19 -- The nation's railroad workers began returning to their jobs early this morning after Congress passed and the President signed a bill ordering an immediate end to a strike by signalmen.

The publication of the first issue of [more], a critical review of the national and local news media by well-known professional writers, was announced here yesterday by Richard Pollak, editor of the new journal, and William Woodward 3d, its publisher.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Administration officials have disclosed that the Soviet Union is pressing ahead so rapidly with its new missile program that test firings are expected within the next few months.
Following a brief mid-session rally, prices closed somewhat lower yesterday on the American Stock Exchange in stepped-up trading.

Once again it would be the Baltimore Orioles and the Cincinnati Reds. So superior did each appear to be that there was no way of preventing a repeat confrontation.

The recently revised indictment against the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan and five other persons suggests that the Justice Department prepared this potentially important criminal case in an extraordinarily careless and irresponsible manner.
The stock market made a strong effort to get back to its winning ways yesterday and almost succeeded in steppedup trading.
A major furniture and appliance store in Harlem was indicted yesterday on charges of using a fradulent collection device to dupe customers.

PLEIKU, South Vietnam, May 12 -- "They're always threatening to close the place down," said Specialist 4 Robert Canberra, a 20-year-old Army medical corpsman who once used heroin and who now runs Highland House where addicts in the 52d Combat Aviation Battalion at Camp Holloway can come to try to get off drugs.

CHICAGO, May 18 -- With spectacular goaltending by a rookie, Ken Dryden, and two dramatic goals by a gray-haired star, Henri Richard, the Montreal Canadians won the Stanley Cup tonight with a 3-2 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18 -Former Police Commissioner Frank L. Rizzo crushed Representative William J. Green today in Philadelphia's Democratic mayoral primary. State Representative Hardy Williams placed a distant third.

CAIRO, May 17 -- The excitement of conspiracy and political upheaval that has gripped Egypt for the last several days was dying down rapidly today, with people reverting to the more mundane aspects of daily life.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 18 -The spring joint computer conference opened here today in an aura of cautious optimism about an upturn in the industry's immediate prospects.
A relative calm came to the trash-littered streets of the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn yesterday, following a series of disorders there on Monday.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 18 -- After two months of constant vituperation, frenzied solicitation of proxies and widely publicized legal challenges, management and an insurgent group of stockholders of the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation ostensibly brought their battle to a quiet close at the annual meeting here today.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -Chief Justice Warren E. Burger called upon the legal profession today to develop stronger disciplinary procedures to deal with ill-mannered lawyers who employ "more adrenalin than judgment" in court.

The domestic petroleum industry faces a shortage of refining capacity and will need to import almost half its petroleum products by 1980, according to Charles E. Spahr, chairman of the Standard Oil Company (Ohio).
SAIGON, Wednesday, May 19 (Reuters) -- Four United States supersonic jets attacked antiaircraft gun sites in North Vietnam in the last 48 hours, the United States military command reported today.

Mitchell, in an affidavit submitted in United States District Court here, concedes that the Government used electronic survillance in gathering evidence against Sister Elizabeth McAlister, one of eight antiwar activists indicted in an alleged kidnapping and bombing plot.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -The Nixon Administration, a day after responding to demands for more aid to minorities, strongly defended its civil rights record today.
The bond market turned around yesterday, and prices advanced for the first time in more than a week, dispelling some of the gloom that had hung over the credit markets for the last several days.
The indictment of a Harlem man on homicide charges in connection with the shooting of an off-duty narcotics detective on May 5 was announced yesterday by Bronx District Attorney Burton B. Roberts.

Alvaro Cassuto, a Portuguese conductor who made his debut here in 1968 as assistant conductor of the Little Orchestra Society, was the podium guest of the orchestra of the Manhattan School of Music for a concert given in Borden Auditorium on Tuesday night.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- The Senate Judiciary Committee approved yesterday President Nixon's nominations of three judges for the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, which covers New York, Connecticut and Vermont.

Precisely because of their poignant situation, their treatment is a test of how humane any society really is.

The Collins Radio Company, which broke off merger negotiations on Tuesday with TRW, Inc., has a new suitor -- the North American Rockwell Corporation. North American Rockwell announced yesterday that it had begun preliminary discussions to purchase a significant interest in Collins and was seeking an affiliation of the two concerns.

DALLAS, May 19 -- Some signs developed here today that the once-solid front of apparel manufacturers demanding quota legislation to protect the domestic industry against imports from low-wage countries is no longer a universally-accepted attitude.

BOSTON, May 19 -- The Boston Red Sox, enjoying the rarified air of the top spot in the American League's Eastern Division, maintained their 2 1/2-game lead over the Baltimore Orioles tonight by bombing two New York Yankee relief pitchers in the late innings to fashion a 7-2 victory before 21,077 fans at Fenway Park.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 19 (UPI) -- Thousands of South Vietnamese troops moving in the Ashau Valley reportedly fought a six-hour battle today with large enemy forces entrenched there.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- No simple box score can record the gains and losses that were registered today in the Senate's rejection of a move to reduce by half the American forces in Europe this year, or even the next three years.

BRUSSELS, May 19 -- United States officials said here today that the Atlantic alliance would not insist on a satisfactory settlement of Berlin's future as a condition for talks with the Soviet Union on mutual and balanced reductions of forces in Central Europe.

BATTLE CREEK, Mich., May 19 -- George Romney, standing outside a gleaming factory that sprang up in a cornfield during the last few months, pushed a button today, and out rolled a housing module looking like a boxcar with picture windows.
AUSTIN, Texas, May 19 -The state of Texas trimmed its oil production again today, as a number of major companies indicated lessened demand for domestic crude oil.
A well-known New York merchant who headed three leading New York-based chains has become a merger specialist and investment banker.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The Federal Reserve Board opposed today a proposal in Congress to give banks the automatic right to "discount" export-related loans with the Reserve. The board also opposed a provision in the same legislation that would exempt export - related bank loans from the present program of controls over bank lending abroad.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- President Nixon's promise to ignore a proposal that marijuana be legalized will not inhibit the National Commission on Marijuana and Drug Abuse from making such a recommendation if the facts support that course, Raymond P. Shafer, chairman of the commission, said today.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, supported today the Nixon Administration view that raising interest rates was not the right way "to improve the international position of the dollar."

DALLAS (UPI) -- The life style in the house of H. L. Hunt, the billionaire, was one of learning by doing.

Carmello J. Zumatto, a suspended New York policeman, pleaded guilty yesterday to lying to a Bronx grand jury that is investigating payoffs to the police by numbers-game racketeers.

This spring there is only the stench of death in the mango groves of East Pakistan/ Bangla Desh as many hearts are maddened by massacre.

He obviously had in mind the debate in Washington over a proposal to withdraw some American troops from Europe, and he left no doubt about his Government's interest in the "problem."

But it is not at all clear that the President's reversal of a four-year-old policy of restraint in providing arms to the southern hemisphere will advance American interests, as the Administration claims.

Julian Huxley's "Memories" is such an exemplary story, so rich in accomplishments and pleasure, that it reads like a children's book for adults. Other men have led lives of almost uninterrupted achievement, but very few of them have known how to relax as nobly as he does. These days, when everyone is talking about the quality of life, one can only feel nostalgia at the quality of Sir Julian's.

CHATTANOOGA, May 25 -Squads of young Negroes, some of whom may have been involved in previous disorders, filtered through housing projects in slum areas here tonight trying to restore calm after four night of racial violence.

YONKERS, May 25 -- Stanley Tananbaum of Harrison, N. Y., was named today to succeed his late brother, Martin, as president of Yonkers Raceway. The track's board of directors also announced the election of Sidney Roth of Manhattan as vice president and Murray Nadler of Lido Beach, L. I., as secretary.

Earlier this month, Blossom Dearie retrieved Trude Heller's, Avenue of the Americas at Ninth Street, from 11 years of rock, returning the room to the intimate supper-club aura it had in its pre-rock days. WASHINGTON, May 25 -Following the Louisville Orchestra's Constitution Hall concert in the Fifth Inter-American Music Festival currently in progress here, a perplexed middle-aged woman explained somewhat apologetically to a friend with her, "Well, I had thought that since the composers were Latin-American the music would be lively -- you know, like the things we heard when we were on the cruise."

The American steel industry has told Vice President Agnew and the Cabinet Committee on Economic Policy that recent sharp declines in steel earnings had "already had an adverse effect on the credit rating of at least one major steel company."
