Mayor Lindsay, charging that he was being shut out of the Albany discussions that will determine the size of next year's city budget, called reporters into his office yesterday to comment on an Albany rumor that he had heard from another reporter.

Mrs. Dollree Mapp, the defendant in a criminal case that resulted in a 1961 landmark decision of the United States Supreme Court barring the admission of evidence seized without a warrant, was sentenced yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Paul Balsam to 20 years to life for the illegal possession of heroin.
LONDON, May 26 -- The City Center Joffrey Ballet, in its first London season, is attracting large audiences but has had only a lukewarm response from the critics.
PHILADELPHIA, May 26 -- The Philadelphia 1976 Bicentennial Corporation decided today that the city wants to host an international exposition for the nation's 200th birthday after all.
The slaying of 12 itinerant farm workers in Yuba City, Calif., yesterday recalled several mass killings of the past.

ALBANY, May 26 -- A special legislative committee that studied allegations of brutality at the Auburn Correctional Facility concluded today that there was "little doubt" such activity existed, though it was described as mental harassment rather than physical abuse.
An 18-year-old student from Brooklyn who allegedly saw the gunmen who shot two policemen in Harlem Friday night was held in $50,000 bail yesterday as a material witness.
DREW, Miss., May 26 -- A Negro girl was shot to death from a passing car last night on her way home from high school graduation exercises, and three white men were charged today with her murder.

Undefeated Harvard's 29-29 "victory" over Yale in 1968 and the 1931 Rose Bowl game, which Alabama won, 24-0, from Washington State were among the rememberances invoked yesterday as the Touchdown Club of New York honored John Yovicsin, retired Harvard coach, and Mel Hein, supervisor of officials for the National Football League.
LONDON, May 26 (Reuters) -- Britain will double the quota for immigrants of Asian origin from her former East African colonies, it was announced today.

The inauguration of Dr. Theodore Powell as president of Kingsborough Community College, which was scheduled for today, has been postponed by the Board of Higher Education following complaints brought against the president last week by some Kingsborough department chairmen.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 26 -- Several of South Africa's top Air Force officers were killed today when three jet planes crashed on the slopes of Table Mountain at Capetown.

TEL AVIV, May 26 -- Defense Minister Moshe Dayan said last night the political situation in Cairo made it unlikely that President Sadat would meet Israel's conditions for a partial pullback from the Suez Canal to permit the waterway to be cleared for international shipping.
ROME, May 26 -- Wanted -- small Italian island without direct-dialing telephones and with landlords willing to let rooms to suspected Mafiosi on a year-round basis.

The Southern Company expects earnings this year "in the range of $1.78 to $1.83 a share," Alvin W. Vogtle Jr., president, told stockholders at yesterday's annual meeting at Macon, Ga. He based his estimate on the possibility of no further rate increases being approved this year.
The reason for the division of the world into man's place and a woman's place is not anatomical, psychological or temperamental differences but a vast and centuries-old superstructure of myths.
More than 8,000 rush-hour subway riders were trapped beneath the East River for nearly two hours last evening after a short circuit cut off power to five IRT Flushing line trains in the tunnel.

Kurt Vonnegut Jr., the madcap scientist of American letters, addressed a gathering of renowned artists and writers yesterday and confronted a crucial question: "Where is the happiness that used to come from riding the cowcatcher of an Indiana locomotive?"
Sex discrimination was charged to the Board of Higher Education yesterday by 20 women teachers who were brought to a City Hall news conference by Councilman Carol Greitzer.
The team owners of the National Football League agreed yesterday to three rules changes and an improved method for breaking ties in the standings.

Ellie Hendricks, Bob Montgomery and Jerry McNertney, hardly known for their hitting prowess, got their chances at the limelight last night. The catchers for the Baltimore Orioles, the Boston Red Sox and St. Louis Cardinals, won games for their respective teams.
The General Foods Corporation announced yesterday record earnings for the fiscal year ended April 3.
NEWARK, May 26 -- A strike by news department employes forced The Evening News of Newark, the state's second largest daily newspaper, to shut down today.

YUBA CITY, Calif., May 26 -- A stocky farm labor contractor was being held here today on charges of murdering 12 itinerant workers whose bodies were uncovered from the rich loam of peach orchards in this peaceful Sacramento Valley agricultural city.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, May 27 (AP) -- Gen. Creighton W. Abrams said today that a "herculean effort" was needed to keep United States troops as alert as they need to be during the American disengagement from the Vietnam war.

A cartoon that appeared in a chess magazine some time ago shows two men, one rather boorish-looking, and the other looking annoyed. The caption (it is, of course, the boorish-looking one who is speaking) runs: "I seen in the papers you played in a chess meet.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Defense Department officials said today that the 60 new missile silos detected in the Soviet Union recently might be intended for two new types of intercontinental missiles rather than one, as suggested earlier.
Tournament time for big-game fishing along the northern reaches of the East Coast is near at hand.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- After being criticized in the past for not enthusiastically embracing the idea of sharing Federal tax revenues with the states and cities, a majority of the Democratic Representatives from New York rallied today behind a revised revenue-sharing proposal they said would provide the greatest benefit to New York City and State.
Sooner or later we must decide who is to run our lives -- ourselves, or self-appointed social theoreticians.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, May 26 -- Shut out by a vastly underrated British side in four morning foursomes, the United States came on strong in the afternoon today to take a 6 1/2-5 1/2 lead as the Walker Cup matches for amateur players opened at this shrine of golf.

Some war-protester tactics employed in Washington, D.C., during and since the Mayday weekend seemed wholly incompatible with the public well-being. The official reaction appeared to include many elements which were infinitely worse -- which were, in fact, a flagrant threat to free government in this country.
The credit markets yesterday made an effort to bring interest rates back down a bit, and the attempt met with some success.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange rose slightly yesterday after declining for three consecutive sessions. However, declines again outpaced advances, with 449 down and 406 up. A total of 266 issues were unchanged.

At a special meeting held yesterday in Chicago, stockholders of the Aurora Corporation of Illinois, which has headquarters in New York, approved an agreement under which Aurora would acquire the precision-castings division of the Allied Products Corporation of Chicago.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- This is the season when people write to newspapers about their gardening problems and when newspapers respond with unintelligible, confusing or terribly bad advice. Here, for example, is a man writing from Chadd's Ford, Pa. He has a very large shrub, which he thinks is a yew, and he wants advice about pruning it.

George Meany, president of the A. F. L.-C. I. O., warned the Nixon Administration yesterday against any move to interfere with the collective bargaining process in critical negotiations that lie ahead.
A brief fight broke out in the New York Mets' dugout last night between Ed Kranepool and Tim Foli, but it was quickly quelled and distracted few of the 22,409 persons in Shea Stadium.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- President Nixon summoned his senior advisers on law enforcement to a meeting today to discuss what he called the "tragic" and "reprehensible" slayings of policemen in New York and Washington.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- The Food and Drug Administration says the same medicine frequently is advertised to consumers as "new" to increase sales but is described to the F.D.A. as "old" to sidestep Federal clearance.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- An academic specialist in Chinese affairs told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that recent changes in China's foreign policy offered the United States an opportunity for a "genuine, face-saving resolution of the Indochina war."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 26 -- The United States and Britain warned the Security Council today that they must have greater cooperation from other members if they are to continue their heavy contributions to finance the peace-keeping force in Cyprus.

DES MOINES, Iowa (UPI) -- Herbert G. Klein, Communications Director for the Executive Branch, said today that the Nixon Administration would take no part in attempts to intimidate the broadcast industry.

ITHACA, N. Y. -- On my sixteenth birthday while visiting Los Angeles, I crossed Wilshire Boulevard against the light. I was arrested. The judge let me off with a lecture, on account of my age, and because I had come from New York where people don't know that laws are to be obeyed.

Suburban and upstate Republicans, in charge of the state's governmental machinery in Albany, are putting together what must be described as a baling-wire budget for New York City. If the carefully leaked reports from the master strategists prove accurate, the package will contain some of the new taxing authority requested by the city -- but this authority will not extend to taxing commuters.

Clayton Knowles and Charles Grutzner, who are retiring this week after several decades as reporters for The New York Times, were honored by their colleagues last night at a party at The Lambs, 128 West 44th Street.
CANBERRA, Australia, May 26 -- Australia is preparing to seek informal contacts with Chinese diplomats as a step toward improved relations, according to authoritative information here.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia ordered city officials tonight to suspend prosecution of demonstrators arrested in the capital earlier this month in those cases where they did not have "adequate evidence to support probable cause for arrest and charge."

WASHINGTON, May 26 (UPI) -- Labor Secretary James D. Hodgson told Congress today that a Democratic proposal to raise the minimum wage to $2.25 an hour was so drastic it could add to unemployment and damage the economy.

Plans for a "cluster housing" development involving the construction of 440 condominium apartments around a large common green in the Grasmere section of Staten Island were approved by the City Planning Commission yesterday.
CLEVELAND, May 26 (AP) -- Floyd Patterson, former heavyweight champion, gained a unanimous decision tonight over Terry Daniels of Dallas in a 10-round bout at the Cleveland arena.
Two women and 20 men were arrested by the Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday on charges of participating in a gambling operation believed to have handled more than $45-million a year.

BONN, May 26 -- Defense Secretary Melvin P. Laird has reassured West Germany that it need not fear any loss of United States interest in a Berlin settlement in favor of deals with the Russians on troop reductions and strategic-arms cuts.

DEER PARK, L. I., May 26 -- Policemen massed in silence here today for the funeral of Patrolman Joseph A. Piagentini of the New York City Police Department, who vas slain last Friday night. They came from 80 depart ments in about a dozen states, nearly 5,000 men in all, gathering much as they had yesterday in the Bronx to honor the white policeman's murdered black partner, Patrolman Waverly M. Jones.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Government's composite index of "leading indicators" of the economy rose in April for the sixth consecutive month, the Commerce Department reported today on the basis of preliminary figures.

A formidable array of anti-discrimination laws, court orders and "plans" -- both Government-enforced and voluntary -- has brought only modest progress toward eradicating employment bias in the once lily-white construction trades. That progress may be speeded up considerably by the decision of Federal Judge Marvin E. Frankel requiring a New York metal lathers union to give compensatory pay to blacks shut out of jobs by its discriminatory practices.

The Consolidated Edison Company announced yesterday the signing of an agreement to ease two nuclear fuel cores totaling $26.3-million from C.N.A. Nuclear Leasing, Inc., a subsidiary of the C.N.A. Financial Corporation of Chicago. This was the second major nuclear-fuel lease made by C.N.A. Nuclear Leasing in two days.

Tonight at 10 o'clock WOR-TV (Channel 9) will present a half-hour documentary called "Methadone: Escape From Heroin." Written and produced by Stanley Friedman, public affairs producer for the station, the program ticks off various objections to the controversial question of methadone but its general approach strongly imples an endorsement of the drug-treatment program.

The Boeing Company, whose supersonic transport project was recently shelved by Congress, has taken initial aim at a different market of the future -- that of short take-off and landing (STOL) airliners.

Six months ago when Rudi Gernreich showed his spring collection, he had his mannequins carry guns. They looked like street fighters. Yesterday, with his fall collection for women, he introduced men's clothes.

Your May 15 editorial urging the rejection by the New York State Senate of an Assembly-approved bill requiring state agents, public authorities and local governments to refuse bids in excess of $2,000 from any foreign company contains all the familiar shibboleths of "protectionism," "retaliatory action," etc.

NEWARK, May 26 -- Robert L. Vesco, chairman of the International Controls Corporation, was ordered in the Federal District Court here today to appear before the Securities and Exchange Commission to tell the Government what he knows about his and other companies' dealings with Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., an offshore mutual fund complex of which he is chairman.
" John Lindsay doesn't have a party -- he's a man without a party," Governor Rockefeller told a group of suburban Democratic legislators last Friday.
PARIS, May 26 (UPI) -- Arthur Ashe survived a shaky start against an unknown Russian in the $95,000 French open tennis championships today.
LONDON, May 26 -- For the 50th time, hordes of garden enthusiasts invaded the grounds of the Royal Hospital in Chelsea yesterday for an annual tribute to the British national pastime.

CHICAGO -- Once again Congress has dashed itself against the hard rock of reform. Senate reformers hurtled against the cloture rule and may once again alter it in some small and useless way. The effort in the House was more fascinating because it was a rare campaign against the "seniority rule."

ALBANY, May 26 -- The State Court of Appeals ruled today that the right of a parolee to be represented by an attorney in a parole revocation hearing was retroactive and that a new hearing should be held if the parolee could show that he had been denied due process.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (UPI) -- The Justice Department filed a civil antitrust suit today accusing the Aluminum Company of America, the nation's largest producer of aluminum, of illegal reciprocal agreements.

District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn reported yesterday the indictment of 22 persons accused of 63 counts of conspiracy, forgery and other charges for allegedly cheating three major credit card companies out of $1-million since October, 1969.
FILICUDI, Italy, May 26 (AP) -- This sleepy fishing island, which has been seeking tourists, got a bunch of big spenders today.
MUNICH, West Germany, May 26 -- An international bankers' forum was told today that "dangerous practices" exist in the market of borrowing and lending overseas dollars.
SALT LAKE CITY, May 26 -- Plans for the biggest coal-fired power plant in the world were exhaustively debated today by utility executives and conservationists at a Congressional hearing.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Federal Communications Commission opened today a new competitive era in he growing business of specialized miocrwave and cable services, a field that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Western Union Corporation have long monopolized.
VANCOUVER, British Columbia, May 26 -- Bobby Fischer of Los Angeles defeated his Soviet opponent, Mark Taimanov, for the fourth game in a row in their quarter-finals knockout chess match.
Virtually all of the water from one of the city's major reservoirs has been shut off for the last three weeks because of a contaminant that makes the water taste musty.

At a seminar on how technology can help the police, courts and jails fight crime, a high police official urged scientists and city managers yesterday to go beyond the question of whether the new technology works and find out whether its use is morally proper.
So important are dogs to Al and Patricia Korn that they built their kennel before their house.

Since both Gustav Husak and Leonid I. Brezhnev are intelligent men, neither can take very seriously the current charade at the fourteenth Congress of the Czechoslovak Communist party in Prague. References to the "international assistance" the Soviet Union gave Czechoslovakia in 1968 are unlikely to convince anyone aware of the facts that what happened was anything but a brutal invasion -- one that robbed a small country of its sovereignty.
The Continental Can Company said yesterday it would increase prices on grocery bag, sack and merchandise bag paper, effective June 1.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 26 (AP) -- Twelve-man teams of Cambodian troops, trained by Central Intelligence Agency personnel at a base in Laos, successfully infiltrated deep into Communist-held territory in Cambodia two months ago, according to Western sources here.
CHICAGO, May 26 -- Thieves beware: The technology of the second half of the 20th century, the detection devices of Vietnam and the modern miracles of communication are zeroing in on you.

" Sometimes we're above the fog," said Mrs. Albert Sanchez with a touch of excitement in her voice as she stood on the balcony of her 33d-floor apartment and gestured at the view -- pinlike masts of sailboats at City Island, a haze-softened Long Island Sound, the grayish building sprawl of the north Bronx and, nearby, the rest of Co-op City.

The opening round of Prime Minister Heath's drive to build parliamentary and public backing for Britain's entry in the European Economic Community has served mostly to sharpen the uncertainties about the outcome. For one thing there has obviously been more erosion than anticipated in support for entry among Mr. Heath's Conservative colleagues in the House of Commons.

PITTSBURGH -- Thousands of college students are getting their B.A.'s at this time of year -- and having a devil of a time finding their first full-time job. Rachel Schwartz, 21, whose spanking new history degree comes from Pittsburgh's Carnegie-Mellon University, is looking for work, but not in anything remotely connected with history.
PHILADELPHIA, May 26 (AP) -- A Polish seaman who jumped ship in Camden, N.J. was released today in the custody of Philadelphia's Polish-American Society.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- A House subcommittee issued a new subpoena to the Columbia Broadcasting System today demanding the appearance of the network's president, Dr. Frank Stanton, and key materials that went into making the documentary "The Selling of the Pentagon."

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 26 -- Prime Minister Brian Faulkner pleaded today with Roman Catholics in Belfast to break the pact of silence that has protected terrorists of the outlawed Irish Republican Army.

One may strive for better environmental quality, and one may even maintain that swordfish is a somewhat over-rated sea food (compared, for example, to fresh cod fillets dredged in butter), and yet wonder if swordfish lovers aren't getting a raw deal from the Food and Drug Administration's mercury warning.

Misty Noon came along in the stretch under the guidance of Heliodoro Gustines to win the $20,000 feature event at Belmont Park yesterday. Herbert Allen's campaigner scored by two lengths over Knight of the Road, with Hydronaut next in the slim field.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 26 -- The "Charles River Gang" -- a disarming band of Harvard and M.I.T. professors who run an arms-control operation that stretches right into the White House -- have found themselves pleasantly disarmed by President Nixon.
The Singer Company's annual report displays something for everyone: pretty girls, pizazz, imagination and candor -- especially candor.
Nationalist China's Minister for Economic Affairs, Yun-suan Sun, asserted yesterday that his country offers larger, more certain business for America than does Communist China.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- It was pointed out in this space on Nov. 11, 1970 -- and as early as April 30, 1969, by Neil Sheehan in The New York Times -- that the 1968 Gun Control Act was being to some extent thwarted because domestic firms were importing and reassembling the individual parts of cheap handguns, which were themselves barred by the act from importation.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Nixon Administration was accused by House Democrats today of failing to provide vigorous enforcement of the Voting Rights Act and permitting Southern states to diminish black political strength as a result.
CAIRO, May 26 -- Both Egypt and the Soviet Union emphasized the positive today as talks began between President Anwar el-Sadat and President Nikolai V. Podgorny.

The campus of Manhattan Community College lies in crowded corridors scattered among four office buildings in a midtown neighborhood of whores, hustlers and drug dealers. The two-year college has had, and apparently still has, a serious narcotics problem that has touched the athletic department as surely as any other. Students have chosen drugs over intercollegiate competition, dropped off teams rather than quit drugs, and, in several cases in several sports, competed while stoned.
The stock market ended almost where it started yesterday as advances outnumbered declines by a slight margin, but leading market averages finished with small losses.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 26 -- The U. S. military command has declared all Vietnamese pharmacies off limits to American servicemen in South Vietnam.

The New York Mets were one out -- in fact, one pitch -- away from a 2-0 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies last night in Shea Stadium. But they got neither the pitch nor the out and, one hour later, were defeated by the Phillies in 12 innings, 3-2.

Rexford E. Tompkins, president of the New York City Real Estate Board, asserted yesterday that "continuous efforts" by the real estate industry to increase integration in housing had been blocked by the City Commission on Human Rights.
CANNES, France, May 26 -- Surprise has been the leitmotif of the 1971 Cannes festival, which is celebrating its 25th birthday.

ALBANY, May 26 -- Governor Rockefeller and Republican legislative leaders have agreed to back legislation that would permit New York City to evade the constitutional limit on real estate taxation and increase city real estate taxes by about $130-million, legislative sources reported today.
The election of Gardner Cowles as a director was announced yesterday by The New York Times Company.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The nation faces the possibilities of racial war and of becoming a lawlessly repressive police state, the chairmen of two Presidential study commissions testified today at a Senate subcommittee hearing.

BANGKOK, Thailand, May 26 -- The Precision international touring team posted a thrilling last-board victory over a powerful Thai group here last night. The home team led virtually all the way, and with three deals remaining in a 40-board match had a lead of 19 international match points.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- In furtherance of his wish that "the growing partnership between Government and the arts continue to be developed to the benefit of both," President Nixon today sent a memorandum to the heads of executive departments and agencies asking them "to look into new ways in which their agencies can more vigorously assist the arts and artists can be of additional help to the agencies and their programs."
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Nixon Administration won a major victory today when the Senate rejected a massive increase in military pay and allowances.
Two economists who freqently differ in public appeared on the same platform here yesterday and offered remarkably similar and generally gloomy forecasts of the business climate for the rest of 1971.

The New York and American Stock Exchanges yesterday issued their latest reports on changes in stock ownership by leading stockholders, directors and officers of listed companies. The reports include the following:
MOSCOW, May 26 -- The Latvian prosecutor today asked for relatively mild sentences ranging from one to four years for the four Soviet Jews on trial in Riga for anti-Soviet activity.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Arnold Bernhard, head of the Value Line investment complex, was penalized by the Securities and Exchange Commission today for one group of alleged violations of the securities laws and made the subject of a Federal court injunction for another group.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Opposition appeared to be building today to the possible Presidential appointment of Albert S. Watson, former Republican Representative from South Carolina, to the Court of Military Appeals.

Lanerossi Vicenza, a First-Division soccer team from Italy, had difficulty getting under way for a tour of eight United States cities, but in the first stop at Yankee Stadium last night it had only minor problems in defeating the New York Cosmos, 5-3, before 4,100 fans, the largest crowd to watch the two-month-old Cosmos.
TORONTO, May 26 (UPI) -- The Steel Company of Canada, the nation's leading steel producer, announced today price increases that could increase the cost of cars and appliances.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- United States exports to the Soviet Union and other Communist countries of Eastern Europe rose last year by slightly more than $100-million to $353.3-million, the Commerce Department reported today.

Lenny Bruce made obscenity into a fine art and it killed him. What is obscenity: Loose and vulgar talk about human genitalia, or kids starving in ghettos, humorous celebrations of sexual intercourse or men getting blown to pieces by grenades? Obscenity is usually in the mouth of the listener.

As a reader of The Times for more than 45 years, I have witnessed the once splendid objectivity of its editorials degenerate to the point where their sense of fairness is open to question. Insofar as their attacks on President Nixon are concerned, at times they even seem to lack reason.

NEWARK, May 26 -- John J. Kenny, former Hudson County Democratic chairman, testified today that he had turned over to Mayor Thomas J. Whelan of Jersey City $15,000 collected from a gambler as protection money.

YUBA CITY, Calif., May 26 (UPI) -- Court records in Marysville showed that a year ago Mr. Corona and his brother Natiividad were named in an $800,000 damage suit filed by Jose R. Raya. Mr. Raya charged that he was severely beaten in February, 1970, in Natividad's bar in a slum section.

DETROIT, May 26 (AP) -- The Chrysler Corporation, following the lead of the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company, announced today that it was making power steering and automatic transmissions standard on all its full-sized cars.

A 23-year-old honors graduate of Columbia College, Fulbright scholar and doctoral candidate at Rockefeller University was sentenced yesterday to six months in prison and 18 months of supervised civilian employment for his refusal to enter the Army.
Two Queens grand juries have indicted five men in two separate murders at Kennedy International Airport in 1970, the Queens District Attorney announced yesterday.
TOKYO, May 26 -- Premier Eisaku Sato today described comments by Americans that the Japanese yen was undervalued as "interference to the nth degree in our domestic affairs."

WASHINGTON, MAY 26 (UPI) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today disciplined Daniel S. Brier Co., a New York brokerage firm, and ordered hearings on charges that two other brokerage houses had sold unregistered stock.

Miss Carol Browning Moon and Patrick Denis Cardon, who are studying for doctorates at New York University's Institute of Fine Arts, were married here yesterday. The ceremony in the Brick Presbyterian Church was performed by the Rev. Dr. William H. Hudnut Jr.

First Leonard Bernstein was severely criticized for having held a fund-raising gala for the Black Panthers. That got him in so much hot water that when he decided to hold a similar affair for the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan, the antiwar priest, he did it so decorously that it took two days for the public to find out.

INDIANAPOLI, May 26 -- Authorities from 17 countries, meeting under auspices of the Nixon Administration and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, sought today to find some common solutions to the deterioration and agony of the cities.
Profit taking on the heels of recent advances sent soybeans and soybean oil prices down yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.
State Supreme Court in Manhattan ordered the Secretary of State of New York yesterday to restore a real-estate salesman's license to Joseph A. Colombo Sr.

TOKYO, May 26 (Reuters) -- Leading Japanese car manufacturers are planning to raise their export prices in the United States. They said their purpose was to slow down a sharp increase in American imports of Japanese cars.

MIAMI, May 26 (AP) -- The Havana radio said today that Heberto Padilla, the award-winning Cuban poet who was jailed and then confessed to antirevolutionary crimes, has attacked 60 foreign intellectuals who came to his defense, calling them "cynical enemies of socialism."
LOS ANGELES, May 26 (AP) -- The Times Mirror Company will continue to reduce costs and increase productivity during 1971, Franklin D. Murphy, chairman, told stockholders today at the annual meeting.

Michael V. Forrestal was elected chairman of the board of the Metropolitan Opera Guild and Laurence D. Lovett was elected to succeed him as president at the guild's annual board of directors meeting held this week. Mr. Forrestal, who succeeds Langdon Van Norden, held the office of president for four years.

Delinquent charge and credit accounts amounting to over $6-million remained uncollected for at least a year at Gimbel Brothers' flagship store here as a result of "computer problems and poor supervision," stockholders were told here yesterday at the annual meeting.

ALBANY, May 26 -- As angry city Democrats charged Governor Rockefeller and Republican legislative leaders with double-dealing, the State Legislature gave final approval tonight to a bill that would end rent control on apartments in New York City when present tenants voluntarily vacated them.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 26 -- Laurence H. Bender, 25 years old, went to his first wine auction today and came away one bottle heavier -- and $5,000 lighter.

LONDON, May 26 -- In the new-model Conservative party of Prime Minister Heath -- a party of individual enterprise and competition, stripped of the old privileged image -- Peter Walker is a perfect symbol.
The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation yesterday reported a 1970 loss of $86,282,000. This compared with a $32,642,000 loss in 1969.

The widespread and ever-increasing coverage of workers by group life insurance has caused a problem that many middle-aged persons should worry about. A gap in financial planning occurs when a person retires at age 65 and finds that his group life coverage either ends, drops sharply, or must be converted at high premiums to straight life.
Bob Nevin has heard his last boos as a Ranger.

GLASGOW, Scotland, May 18 -- At the unemployment office on Muirhouse Street, the men sit on benches in silence. They light cigarettes and stare at the posters on the wall that say: "Careers in the fire service . . . Join the Royal Navy."

ROCHESTER, May 26 -- The United Presbyterian Church ended its general assembly here this afternoon after making significant decisions in the areas of the women's liberation movement, civil rights and Protestant unity.

Tootsie Roll Industries, Inc., announced yesterday the election of Charles S. Larmon as president. Before joining the Chicago-based company in 1969 as executive vice president and chief operating officer, he was an executive with Alberto-Culver and General Foods International.

SEOUL, South Korea, Thursday, May 27 -- President Chung Hee Park's Democratic Republican party retained a reduced but safe majority in the National Assembly today as a result of Tuesday's general election.
Herder and Herder, long noted for prestigious, high-quality books on Roman Catholic theology and philosophy, is riding the wave Germans call Die Sexwelle.
The State Supreme Court's Appellate Division granted a stay yesterday of a lower court's order that would have closed the Abortion Information Agency, Inc.

A fifth candidate for the Democratic nomination for Surrogate in New York County joined the field yesterday with the announcement of Civil Court Judge Orest V. Maresa that he was going to run for the post.

SYDNEY, Australia, Thursday, May 27 -- Qantas, the Australian international airline, paid $560,000 in cash yesterday to a hoaxer who had convinced airline officials that there was a bomb on a plane bound for Hong Kong with 116 passengers and 12 crew members.

Albert Shanker, president of the United Federation of Teachers, said yesterday that his union would have to use "the ultimate weapon" in September if class sizes were increased and the $21-million More Effective Schools program was dropped.
The president of the N.B.C. Television Network said yesterday that he sees an end to agency commissions on network television buys during this decade.

ALBANY, May 26 -- The Court of Appears today delayed a reduction in rates for customers of the New York Telephone Company ordered by the Public Service Commission in September, 1970, pending the outcome of an appeal by the company.

The management of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation has apparently defeated an insurgent bid to take control of the giant motion picture company. However, the dissidents seemingly be lieve that the vote is close enough for them to pursue their legal challenges against certain of the management proxies and intend to continue the hard-fought battle in the courts.

MUNICH, West Germany, May 26 -- A governor of the Federal Reserve Board has swung his weight behind a proposal that would enable Americans to use their savings accounts for automatic payment of household bills.
A controversy has developed over the Board of Education's pioneering project to measure the effectiveness of schools and their teachers.
ALBANY, May 26 (AP) -- Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas DeMartino were turned down by the Stats Court of Appeals today in another attempt to keep "Baby Lenore," the child the are seeking to adopt.
ATHENS, May 27 -- The Government is preparing to try more than a score of prominent Greeks who are said to have been involved in the organization of an underground anti-Government network.

Two Rockefeller University scientists have reported that they have successfully inhibited the sickling of red blood cells taken from patients with sickle cell anemia, the incurable, hereditary blood disorder that affects blacks almost exclusively.

ALBANY, May 27 -- Angrily charging that Governor Rockefeller and the Republican leaders were depriving them of their constitutional rights, the Democratic members of the Assembly rebelled today and took the unusual step by refusing to vote yes or no on a bill being hurried through the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- A Congressional investigating team urged in a report made public today that the Army be required to identify and rehabilitate the 26,000 to 39,000 American heroin addicts in South Vietnam before returning them to civilian life.
MEMPHIS, May 27 (AP) -Larry Ziegler matched the best round on the pro tour this year with an eight-under-par 62 today and took the first-round lead in the $175,000 Danny Thomas Memphis Golf Classic.
PHILADELPHIA, May 27 -- Marty Liquori returns to the site of his finest track and field triumph tomorrow and Saturday in the 95th annual I.C. 4-A outdoor championships at Franklin Field.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 27 -- The British Army, anxious about "a new phase" of major guerrilla violence over the next few months, is quietly shifting tactics in the six counties of Northern Ireland.

Six Negro Wacs assigned to Fort Meade, Md., "will fight any effort to have them discharged" following a racial conflict at the big Army base on May 17, their lawyer said last night.

The Times on May 24 ran a news story about an article in the New York Law Journal by William J. vanden Heuvel, Chairman of the city's Board of Corrections. In this article Mr. vanden Heuvel advocated, among other things, that courts give up the traditional summer recess, and that judges not take more than four weeks of vacation.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The United States Bureau of Mines was accused in a report released today of failing to enforce strictly the 18-month-old Federal law designed to reduce injury and death in the nation's coal mines.

Endowed with the riches of this virgin continent, Americans have always been a wasteful people. But the attitude -- "there's plenty more where that came from" -- no longer corresponds to the hard reality. From electric energy to ocean beaches, from clean air to green space, everything is now in short supply.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 31 -- North Vietnamese troops reportedly drove a South Vietnamese task force today from the Cambodian town of Snoul, which United States troops captured more than a year ago.
Two patrolmen investigating a car-stripping report were fired on by one of a group of men surprised by the officers while dismantling an auto at 8 East 110th Street in Harlem early yesterday.

MOSCOW, May 31 -- The Soviet Union has been pressing forward with a sweeping reorganization of its network of scientific institutions in an attempt to focus basic research more effectively on regional needs.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 31 -- Willie Mays beat the Mets with his bat, glove, arm and legs today as the New Yorkers got their first look at the wonder team of 1971, the San Francisco Giants.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 31 -- The Jordanian Government said today that Palestinian guerrillas were engaged in a program of sabotage in an attempt to undermine Jordan's economy and provoke the army.

PRAGUE, May 31 (AP) -- The Czechoslovak Communist party made public today the final resolution of its 14th congress, which said that the long crisis had been overcome, that Czechoslovakia was locked firmly in the Soviet bloc again, but that the struggle against "rightist" and Western influence must be continued.

CHERRY HILL, N. J. May 31 -- While waiting for a showdown with Canonero II, Bold Reasoning proved he was more than a sprinter today by capturing the $134,400 Jersey Derby and remained unbeaten in seven starts.
STOCKHOLM, Tuesday, June 1 (AP) -- The Swedish newspaper Dagens Nyheter said today that Premier Golda Meir of Israel met secretly with two Soviet officials in Finland over the weekend.
The Consolidated Edison Company has elected Mrs. Marian Sulzberger Heiskell to its board of trustees, thereby increasing the membership to 15, it was announced yesterday by Charles F. Luce, chairman.

FOURTH MUSQUACOOK LAKE, Me.--After flying toward the setting sun for half an hour from Presque Isle, Phil Walters set our single-engine float plane gently down on this forest-encircled lake in northern Maine.

George Washington High School, a battered institution at 193d Street and Audubon Avenue in upper Manhattan, began the 1970-71 school year in a state approaching anarchy and in a pervasive climate of fear. It nears the end of the year on a high note of hope.

DETROIT, May 31 -- Is clean air more important than the Government's battle against monopolies? Does the drive toward a better environment mean even greater concentration for the business world, because only the rich can afford the vast spending necessary to create that bet ter environment quickly?

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- The Bureau of Customs reported today the seizure of 201 pounds of pure heroin, worth $30,300,000 at estimated street prices, in San Juan, Puerto Rico. There were two arrests.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- William L. Cary, former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has agreed to help plan the broad study of the securities industry that is to be done by a subcommittee of the House Commerce Committee.

Since the critics of the American medical system are always extolling the virtues of Britain's National Health Service, they should read the report of the Hospital Advisory Service, a group of doctors examining the British Government's health facilities.

With scarcely a moment to take a breath after returning from its six-week spring tour Saturday, the Metropolitan Opera began its two-week June Festival last night at its Lincoln Center home with a crackling "Aida."

Full of action in going through his paces in the finale, Ch. Argus of Greywitch, a 4-year-old blue brindle greyhound owned by Dr. Elsie S. Neustadt of West Hanover, Mass., was named best in show at the Queensboro Kennel Club's all-breed event yesterday.

Leaders of community and antinarcotics groups in Harlem and the Bronx expressed angry opposition yesterday to a proposed city experiment that would give maintenance doses of heroin to selected addicts in a rehabilitation program.

Twenty-two black clergymen and community leaders, acting as "jurors in a People's Tribunal," are scheduled to return a verdict tomorrow in the killing on May 17 of a Bedford-Stuyvesant man by the police.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- A stiff new Federal labeling regulation has failed to break up a thriving black market in unsafe automobile tires.

Ivan Illich's suggestions for abolishing schools (Op.-Ed., May 3 and May 4) serve a useful purpose. They make us think. However, in offering his radical suggestions Mr. Illich seems to have overlooked several lively trends on the educational scene today: (1) There is great activity directed toward making some forms of education more relevant to the life of the student.
BATON ROUGE, La., May 31 (AP) -- A state court of appeals ruled today that the state had no right to sue Life magazine for damages for its article alleging Mafia influence in state government.

FILICUDI, Italy, May 31 (AP) -- Filicudi's doctor and telephone operator packed today to follow the rest of the residents of this tiny island in protest against the exiling here of 15 reputed Mafia leaders.
A total of 7,761 persons, more than 90 per cent of them high school and college students, will participate in work-study programs this summer in Israel.
Twenty widows of policemen and firemen killed here in the line of duty gathered in Manhattan yesterday with their 53 children to announce the formation of a foundation aimed at helping them.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 31 -- Economic giants -- Brazil, Mexico and Argentina -- are stirring in Latin America. To face them together and to avoid becoming economic satellites separately, five nations in the west of South America are trying economic integration within an authoritarian regional plan.

" Sandy Koufax came to me just before he was to interview Vida Blue," said Dick Williams, the Oakland manager and one-time Koufax teammate on the Dodgers. "'Whom does he remind you of?' he asked me. 'The guy I'm talking to,' I said. Naturally enough, Sandy blushed."

LONDON, May 31 -- A thousand United States servicemen stationed in Britain announced their opposition to the Vietnam war today. It was the largest antiwar protest among American military personnel stationed here.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Prospects are growing that Congress this year will enact a law requiring for the first time the extension of credit by the Federal Reserve System to a specific sector of the economy.

In third place with four events remaining, Archbishop Molloy of Queens finished with a string of 18 points to take the team title yesterday in the 43d annual Catholic High Schools Athletic Association track and field championships at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.
Two unions representing 20,000 employes struck Western Union today, halting the acceptance and delivery of domestic telegrams, overseas cables and money orders across the country, the company said.

The Independent Neighborhood Democrats in the Cobble Hill section of Brooklyn announced yesterday that they would hold their inaugural party next Saturday night despite a bomb explosion that blew the windows out of its storefront headquarters early Sunday morning.

GLACE BAY, Nova Scotia, May 21 -- Three of the younger members of this tired coalmining town stood at the corner of Commercial and Main Streets one recent evening and exchanged news.

ALBANY, June 1 -- Governor Rockefeller's proposed legislation creating a state agency to oversee the development of the six-million-acre Adirondack Park may be dead for this session because of the opposition of upstate legislators, apparently stirred by pressure from land developers.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- The Pan American World Airways jetliner detained in Cuba for four days is expected to be allowed to continue its flight to Miami tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (UPI) -- Not all the guests gave practical kitchenware at Tricia Nixon's wedding shower today. There was a filmy white negligee with white feathers from an old family friend and a white and gold French telephone from Martha Mitchell.

MOSCOW, June 1 -- A leading Russian Orthodox prelate has called for the removal of the church's 300-year-old curses on the Old Believers, the Russians who refused to accept changes in Orthodox ritual and formed a major dissident group. There are believed to be several million of them here.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., June 1 -- More than half of the licensed physicians and pharmacists in the Town of Huntington have agreed voluntarily to stop prescribing and dispensing amphetamines except in two "medically required instances."
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- Tricia Nixon's wedding cake will be a White House extraganza, six tiers high, towering more than 6 feet tall and weighing more than 350 pounds.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- In the sharpest news conference exchange since he assumed office, President Nixon praised tonight the behavior of District of Columbia police during the recent Mayday antiwar protests and said charges that constitutional rights had been violated by the mass arrests were an "exaggeration."

The roaring success enjoyed by Andrew Wyeth and his son Jamie infuriates a coteri of American artists and critics who, while they may be at one another's throats on other subjects unite to bay like a pack of frustrated wolves without coming within snapping distance of the Wyeths' heels.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, June 1 -- Policemen in bulletproof vests today stormed an apartment where the 14-year-old daughter of a Turkish army major was being held hostage by two leftist guerrillas and rescued the girl after a gunfight.
Ramsey Clark told graduating students and their parents at Brooklyn College yesterday that "things aren't working well in America any more . . . and human attitudes and institutions have to change."
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- United States industry has revised downward somewhat its earlier announced plans for investment in plant and equipment this year, the Commerce Department reported today.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 1 -- A 20-year-old Minnesota soldier received a brief respite from Vietnam duty today when Federal District Judge Earl Larson delayed a hearing on his contention that his orders were illegal because war had not been declared.

A continuing strike of Massey-Ferguson, Ltd., plants in the United States that began March 22 primarily was responsible for the sharp decline in earnings for the second quarter and the half year ended April 30, A. A. Thornbrough, president of the company, disclosed yesterday.

Creditors of the King Resources Company tried to collect $8-million on a note due yesterday from Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., but were rebuffed at both the Bank of New York and the First Jersey National Bank in Jersey City.

The action that the physicians and pharmacists in Huntington, L. I., took yesterday to restrict the use of amphetamines reflects what Americans are now learning about this form of drug abuse -- a lesson that the Japanese learned about 25 years ago.

Linda Bird Johnson Robb, oldest daughter of former President Johnson, will be a special guest on the Columbia Broadcasting System's news coverage of the June 12 nuptials of Tricia Nixon and Edward Cox.
Hoping to be the first pilot to fly over the North Pole from Equator to Equator in a light plane, Sheila Scott flew off from London yesterday in her Piper Aztec, first stop Nairobi.
OTTAWA, June 1 -- The Liberal party of Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau lost one of House of Commons seat in four federal by-elections yesterday.

ALBANY, June 1 -- A fact-finding panel has rejected a proposal by a state Civil Service union that would make its retirement benefits similar to those recently negotiated between New York City and District Council 37, the union representing the bulk of city employes.
After a two-year battle between the Department of Consumer Affairs and members of the food industry, unit pricing went into effect in all the city's large supermarkets yesterday.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 1 -- Informed sources said tonight that Tran Thien Khoi, brother of Premier Tran Thien Khiem, had been removed as chief of the National Customs Investigation Division.

READINGTON TOWNSHIP, N. J. -- Despite a continued reluctance on the part of the Western Electric Company to comment, it now appears that the company plans to move a large portion of its corporate headquarters from New York City's financial district to a 440-acre rolling, grassy tract here in the historic hunt country.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- President Nixon pledged tonight to undertake a "national offensive" to counter the problem of drug addiction among young Americans, including servicemen who have become addicted while in South Vietnam.
MOSCOW, June 1 -- "I am a Zionist!" a young Soviet Jewish woman defiantly told a Riga court last week, according to an official account of the case that reached Moscow today.

Interest rates on long-term bonds are at or near their peaks at the present time, and should decline substantially by the end of the year, the investment firm of Donaldson, Lufkin and Jenrette predicted yesterday.
"It has been a good year at Columbia," the university's president, Dr. William J. Mcgill, said three times in his commencement address yesterday.
MANILA, June 1 -- Leaders of the Philippines regard Communist China's apparent new openness toward the non-Communist world with suspicion and are determined to make no hasty approaches toward Peking.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (Reuters) -- Total new construction spending rose 2.3 per cent, or $2.3-billion in April to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $104.5-billion. This reversed March's $400-million downward revised rate of $102.2-billion, the Commerce Department said today.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff, who tried unsuccessfully last year to help the Nixon Administration's welfare bill through the Senate, came out today for an extensive liberalization that would add billions of dollars to this year's measure.

Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner has recommended, despite some admitted misgivings, that the Board of Education award a $96,000 contract to a concern headed by former Superintendent of Schools Bernard E. Donovan for an evaluation of the city's More Effective Schools program.

It's good that Anton (Tony) Hulman Jr., the president of Indianapolis Motor Speedway, was in that pace car when it struck the photographers' stand at the start of the Indianapolis 500. He suffered no injuries, but he was seriously shaken.

A Federal mediator failed yesterday to get contract talks going in Washington between Western Union and 20,100 of its employes, whose strike closed offices across the nation in a contract deadlock over wages and job security.

Mrs. Martin Luther King Jr., the widow of the civil rights leader, told graduates at the City College commencement exercises last night that they had become "significant political actors with amazing power to influence the course of societies all over the world."

JERUSALEM, June 1 -- Israeli spokesmen formally denied today reports from Scandinavia that Premier Golda Meir had met secretly with high Soviet officials, during a private weekend visit to a remote hunting lodge in Finnish Lapland, less than 100 miles from the Soviet border.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, June 1 -- The 23d Royal Danish Ballet Festival in Copenhagen is presenting many works of interest but one is a supreme novelty that is now just 100 years old and has not been seen for more than two decades, August Bournonville's "The Life Guards on Amager Point.
HONG KONG, June 1 -- A leading British businessman said today that it would take time for the establishment of trade relations between the United States and China.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., June 1 -- In the Helen Hills Chapel at Smith College here this afternoon. Miss Otis Ann Thompson, who was graduated from Smith on Sunday, became the bride of Jeffrey Horn, an instructor in Smith's French department.

A one-night conference of ultra-Orthodox Hasidic Jews of the Satmar movement -- a group named for the Austro-Hungarian town in which it was formed -- held a 100th anniversary meeting in Brooklyn yesterday.

Two things seem sure about all the 1971 negotiations between the United Steelworkers of America and employers in the four major sectors of the basic metals industries -- steel, copper, aluminum and cans.
