CHADDS FORD, Pa., June 1 -- Nine new paintings by Andrew Wyeth, never before seen in public, will help open a new museum, converted at a cost of a million dollars from a century-old grist mill.

PEKING, June 1 -- At Peking's heavy electric machinery plant, Wei Ching-shen, the 50-year-old chairman of the Revolutionary Committee that runs the big factory, listened patiently as a young woman worker criticized his record.

Your' editorial conclusion (May 20) that enactment of the vacancy decon. t?ol bill in the Governor's housing recovery program would result in harass. merit of tenants to vacate is conjectural. It is not supported by recent New York experience.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company set a $4 dividend rate on its offering of 27.5 million convertible preferred shares to shareowners through subscription rights. This would be a yield of 8 per cent or somewhat higher than the minimum of 7.75 per cent that had been reported unofficially last week.

LOS ANGELES, June 1 (UPI) -- Thirteen Black Panther party members, including the former deputy defense minister, Elmer Pratt, went on trial today on charges that included conspiracy to murder Los Angeles police officers.
MANCHESTER, England, June 1 (AP) -- American women advanced in five of their six first-round matches today in the Northern lawn tennis tournament.
Copper future prices dropped yesterday on the Commodity Exchange (Comex) here in moderate trading.

TRENTON, June 1 -- A stringent law that requires most of New Jersey's sewage sludge and industrial wastes to be dumped 100 miles out into the Atlantic Ocean was signed today by Gov. William T. Cahill.

HARTFORD, June 1 -- With only eight days remaining before mandatory adjournment of the Connecticut General Assembly, neither a state budget nor a tax program has been agreed upon by the Republican Governor and the Democratic-controlled legislature.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 1 -- The New York Mets "held" Willie Mays to a walk, single and home run tonight as they defeated the San Francisco Giants, 5-4, and ended the Giants' winning streak at five games.

ALBANY, June 1 -- Another "summit meeting" between Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Lindsay over the Mayor's proposed New York City tax package is highly unlikely, Rockefeller administration sources reported today.

The Rev. Reinhold Niebuhr, the Protestant theologian who had wide influence in the worlds of religion and politics, died last evening at his summer home in Stockbridge, Mass., after a long illness. He was 78 years old.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, June 2 -- The South Vietnamese task force that withdrew from the eastern Cambodian town of Snoul on Monday is still inside Cambodia, a Saigon spokesman said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (Reuters) -- The Supreme Court refused today to hear the appeal of a small bank in the state of Washington challenging the authority of state officials to set reserve requirements for state banks that were not members of the Federal Reserve System.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Supreme Court ruled 5 to 4 today that cities cannot make it a crime for small groups of citizens to loiter in an "annoying" manner in public places.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Supreme Court gave Federal judges broad authority today to issue antistrike injunctions against railroad and airline unions that fail to make "every reasonable effort" to negative disputes before going on strike.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Supreme Court took the following actions today.

SEMARANG, Indonesia, May 29 -- The rainy season is ebbing in central Java and the banana trees, mangoes, sugar cane, coconut palms, rice shoots and misty slopes of dormant volcanos assault the eye with a dozen spectacular shades of green.

Clark Terry's 17-piece jazz band, which has been inactive for almost a year, reassembled Monday night at the Half Note, at Spring and Hudson Streets, for the first of a series of Monday night appearances there that will be a continuation of the weekly sessions the band held for two years at the Club Baron in Harlem.

BOSTON, June 1 -- Random House tonight received the Carey-Thomas Award for creative publishing in 1970 for its "Picasso 347," a book of Pablo Picasso's erotic drowings which sold less than 3,000 of the 10,000 copies in print.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Speaker of the House Carl Albert lost a round today in his attempt to halt work on a new $90-million Library of Congress building.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The White House described President Nixon today as "disappointed" by yesterday's wage and price increases in the aluminum industry and cautioned the steel industry not to follow the pattern set by the aluminum companies.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- The Justice Department moved today against school districts in Virginia and North Carolina that the department said had discriminated against black teachers during the process of desegregation.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- The Army said today it was investigating charges that United States airborne troops killed 24 to 40 Vietnamese women and children on a beach near Bongson in September, 1968.
LONDON, June 1 -- A vast camping site for 2,000 tourists will open in three weeks in West London to cope with the record influx of young visitors expected here.

Play began last night in the Reisinger Knockout Team-of-Four, with 106 squads competing in the most important New York team championship of the year. The Reisinger is the final regular event in the Eastern States Regional tournament, which began last Friday at the New York Hilton Hotel, but there will be two special one-session charity events next Sunday open to all players.

HAVANA, June 1 (Reuters) -- The Cuban Government today was silent concerning the hijacked jetliner, and the official newspaper Granma made no mention of either the plane or its 69 passengers and crew members.

A holiday weekend at the shore. Rain. The television set. The little box does provide occasional compensations, even if only in reruns of movies with deliciously insipid plots. There is something atrociously comforting in watching "Night and Day" for the 17th time, in marveling at tall, handsome Cary Grant playing the diminutive Cole Porter and at Alexis Smith doing her familiar commercial for the Good Woman.

The well-advertised appearance of Vida Blue at Yankee Stadium last night produced two imposing results: a crowd of 30,052 and a 5-2 victory for the Oakland Athletics, the 11th complete-game victory of the season for the exciting left-hander.

The 1971 Schaefer Music Festival, which offers New Yorkers the top names in jazz, rock, blue and pop music for the nominal prices of $1 and $2, will get under way at the Wollman Rink in Central Park June 24.

When the State Legislature resumes its session today following the Memorial Day recess, it will confront a sizable amount of unfinished business. Much of it concerns the City of New York: its budget, the administration of its rent control and housing code enforcement programs, the conduct of its elections.

YUBA CITY, Calif., June 1 (UPI) -- Sheriff's deputies stopped digging today along the banks of the Feather River, where they had excavated the bodies of 23 slain farm workers in the last week, but kept looking for more grave sites.

A State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that the records and books of four commercial abortion referral agencies subpoenaed by the State Attorney General should not contain the names and addresses of women who sought or obtained abortions through their services.

Reinhold Niebuhr blended theology and practical politics as articulator of the concept of "liberal realism." His writings provided the intellectual underpinning for much of what was most constructive in the antitotalitarian left.

Columbia University will set up a "troika" system, with two executive vice presidents as key assistants to the president. One will be provost, in charge of academic affairs, and the other will concentrate on administration, including preparation of the budget.
The American Stock Exchange posted its best gain in two-and-a-half months yesterday as the list advanced in stepped-up trading.
PRAGUE, June 2 (Reuters) -- China has completed one phase of its efforts to restore its relations with Eastern Europe by appointing a new ambassador to Czechoslovakia.
CENTEREACH, L. I., June 2 -- Suffolk County Executive H. Lee Dennison announced today that he would not seek re-election to a fourth four-year term as the county's top elected official.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- President Nixon has decided he would like to hold the 1972 Republican National Convention in San Diego, according to well-placed sources in the party.

Three young gunmen and the driver of a getaway car escaped with $170,000 in currency yesterday after holding up the Baisley Park branch of the National Bank of North America, at 152-80 Rockaway Boulevard, in the Springfield section of Queens.
There have been times when Mrs. Pauline Withers, a mother of five who lives in one of the worst crime areas in the city, has been so afraid walking home after dark that she has talked to herself.
Offtrack support for Canonero II in the Belmont Stakes was so heavy here yesterday that special $50 win tickets may have to be printed.
ROME, June 2 -- Leaders of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith urged Pope Paul VI today to intercede on behalf of the Jews in the Soviet Union.

District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn announced yesterday the arrest of four men charged with cheating the State Division of Employment out of more than $250,000 in fraudulent claims over a five-year period.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that Albany was provoking massive public outrage here because it made a "travesty" of the city's "calamitous" financial plight.

GENEVA, June 2 -- The International Labor Organization opened a three-week meeting here today by electing an employer representative as its presiding officer for the first time since it was founded in 1919. The Soviet Union lodged an immediate protest.
The odds are that before long hemorrhoid remedy commercials, absent for a decade, will be back on television.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company disclosed yesterday that it was planning to move part of its general office in Manhattan to a rural, wealthy area in Bernards Township, N. J.

A group of cutters of men's and boys' clothing walked off their jobs at various shops in the city yesterday and picketed the national headquarters of their union in protest against the terms of a new national contract.

A State Supreme Court justice here ruled yesterday that a community school board in Manhattan had the right to use Federal funds intended to aid poverty-stricken pupils without being subject to controls of the Central Board of Education.

The New York and American Stock Exchanges yesterday issued their latest reports on changes in stock ownership by major stockholders, officers and directors of their listed companies. The reports include the following:

Distinguished citizens of nine NATO countries have organized what they call the European-Atlantic Action Committee on Greece in an effort to help end the military dictatorship and restore democracy "in the land of its birth." Their initiative could not have come at a better time.

The four-year sentence of a convicted gambler who has been arrested 16 times and has been described as a major corrupter of the New York Police Department has been reduced to two years by the Appellate Division, First Department.
YUBA CITY, Calif., June 2 (UPI) -- A light plane equipped with infrared photographic equipment made several passes today over the peach orchards where the 23 victims had been found.
CAIRO, June 2 -- President Anwar el-Sadat reported today to the People's Assembly, formerly the National Assembly, on the 15-year treaty signed with the Soviet Union last week.

BOSTON, June 2 -- A Seattle businessman inadvertently crashed a top secret White House meeting at the height of the Berlin crisis of 1961, Pierre Salinger, who was President Kennedy's press secretary, said today.
District School Board 25 in Flushing, Queens, voted last night to adopt a compromise proposal modifying its ban on the book "Down These Mean Streets" from student libraries.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Manufacturers' new orders fell more than $1-billion, or 1.9 per cent, in April with a bigger drop in orders for durable goods than had been estimated previously, the Commerce Department reported today.

The General Foods Corporation announced yesterday the appointment of James W. Andrews as corporate group vice president in charge of the company's Maxwell House and Institutional Food Service Divisions and its Canadian operations. Joseph F. Abely Jr. was named vice president finance and becomes chief financial officer and controller of the company.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Senate Rules Committee defeated today a Republican attempt to increase by 40 per cent the proposed ceiling on radio and television spending for national and Congressional candidates in the 1972 campaign.

It seems to be generally assumed (by the Government, the press and by various and variously motivated self-proclaimed war criminals) that a soldier who participated in a war crime in Vietnam, but who was honorably discharged from the service before the facts came to light, is constitutionally immune from prosecution. I do not share this opinion.

SAIGON, South Vietnam -- It should be noted that the horrible massacre at Mylai was first brought to light by the Americans themselves. It was denounced by American G.I.'s back from Vietnam and it was brought before American and world public opinion by the American press.
NEW DELHI, June 2 -- In India these days, anyone who volunteers his thoughts for a penny may wind up getting a post card instead.

NEWARK, June 2 -- An automobile dealer told the Federal Court jury in the Jersey City corruption trial today that he had paid a kickback 10 years ago to the man now leading the city's reform movement.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The United States was reported today to be planning to contribute $10-million to $15-million more to care for East Pakistani refugees fleeing into India.

Seventeen black clergymen and community leaders, acting as "jurors" in a Brooklyn "people's tribunal," found two white policemen "guilty of murder in the first degree" last night in the shooting of a black man on a Bedford-Stuyvesant street corner on May 17.

Studebaker-Worthington, Inc., announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire 50.4 per cent of the outstanding common shares of the Pan American Sulphur Company, owned by the Susquehanna Cor poration, for approximately $35.5-million.

BONN, June 2 -- West Germany's central bank, anxious to reduce the inflationary effect of speculative foreign funds transferred to this country, decided today to increase by 15 per cent the commercial banks' reserve requirements on domestic liabilities.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Democrats pushed through the House today their own program of public service jobs for the unemployed, dealing President Nixon's special revenue-sharing plans a severe blow.
One of the most gratifying and revealing developments of the New York City Ballet's current season has been the marked improvement in its standards of male dancing.

LISBON, June 2 -- Manlio Brosio, Secretary General of the Atlantic alliance, said here today that the recent Soviet overtures for negotiation of troop cuts in Central Europe "require, of course, further clarification."

The trustees of the bankrupt Penn Central Transportation Company announced yesterday that they were offering for sale 23 parcels of land and several buildings in the heart of midtown Manhattan. This could result in the largest real-estate deal single owner.
MOSCOW, June 2 -- A question period after a lecture this afternoon provided an opportunity to hear ordinary Soviet citizens speak their minds on problems of the day.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- Lieut. Col. Anthony B. Herbert said today that a military investigator had tried unsuccessfully to stop him from filing war-crimes charges by threatening to accuse him of assault in an alleged massacre of civilians at Bongson, South Vietnam.

A 65-year-old physician convicted of running an amphetamine "supermarket" in his office at 40 Central Park South was sentenced by a Federal Judge yesterday to five years in jail and ordered to pay a $10,000 fine.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Federal National Mortgage Association announced today a special "auction" next week aimed at reducing or eliminating the overhang of mortgages in the hands of mortgage bankers that has been acting as a depressant on market prices.
PARIS, June 2 -- Relations between the French police and newspapermen here, never very friendly, have sunk to a new low as a result of the charges that a journalist was beaten Saturday.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Textile imports in the first-four months of this year were 42 per cent above the record levels of 1970, the Commerce Department reported today.

There were no major upsets in the first-round of the Reisinger knockout team championships that ended yesterday morning at the New York Hilton. The four-player event, the feature of the Eastern Regionals, will move into the round of 32 tonight, but no upsets were possible in the second round last night since the top 11 teams drew byes.

In a 10-minute address that was interrupted six times by applause and cries of "Right on!?" Dr. Edyth J. Gaines, pioneer in African and Afro-American studies here, urged graduating students at the Bronx Community College yesterday to place their education and technical skills at the disposal of their communities.

The long battle for statewide branch banking in New York should end this week. Informed observers of the Legislature in Albany said yesterday that a key political compromise -- which was worked out in behind-the-scenes negotiations over the long holiday weekend -- could well clear the way for favorable action by the Assembly tomorrow and thereafter by the Senate.

SANTA ANA, Calif. -- Growth, the snowballing, leapfrogging growth that for so long held out to the suburbs the promise of an endlessly prosperous future, has suddenly developed into a shadow across that future.
A dozen new fire-alarm boxes, which require the person turning in an alarm to speak into the box instead of pulling a lever, have been installed in Central Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Pan American and Sabena cut the cost of airplane tickets to Europe the other day, but only for students.

ALBANY, June 2 -- The Ethics and Guidance Committee of the Assembly is looking into the propriety of a letter sent by a Democratic Assemblyman to a number of business concerns in which he was offering his services.
Grey Advertising had its annual meeting yesterday. There was one speaker, no reel of commercials and no questions. It was over in 15 minutes flat.
PEKING, June 2 -- The Chinese Government has put into effect a welfare system designed to assure every family a minimum standard of living.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., June 2 (AP) -- A homosexual clergyman has been suspended from the Methodist ministry in an emotional meeting that followed a plea in his behalf by the Gay Liberation Front.
MIAMI, June 2 (UPI) -- The passengers and crew members of a hijacked Pan American World Airways jet were released today after having been held for four days in Havana.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Officials of the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers Union today accused the Labor Department and the Allied Chemical Corporation of tolerating occupational hazards that a union medical consultant contended had brought symptoms of chemical poisoning to scores of workers.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Army accused Brig. Gen. John W. Donaldson today of murdering six Vietnamese civilians and assaulting two others in the winter of 1968-69.

GOLDEN, Colo., June 2 (AP) -- Considerable stores of natural gas are waiting to be uncovered in the United States, but most will be deep in the ground, beneath the oceans, or otherwise expensive to find, according to a report issued today from the Colorado School of Mines.

LONDON, June 2 -- The Treasury reported today another high in Britain's once-denuded official monetary reserves. However, the inflow of funds has slackened from the pace of recent months. It was the eighth consecutive monthly gain.

A new arts center in the Berkshire Hills of western Massachusetts, where musical plays, jazz concerts, poetry readings, chamber music and workshop presentations will be given, is opening this summer under the co-direction of Lyn Austin and Oliver Smith, veteran Broadway producers.

ATLANTA, June 2 -- Dave Hill, the 34-year-old professional who finished second in the 1970 United States Open golf championship, was placed on probation for a year today by the tournament policy board of the Tournament Players Division of the Professional Golfers' Association.
DEVON, Pa., June 2 -- Mrs. L. B. Cobb's Nicodemus won the preliminary jumper class at the Devon horse show today, and most of the riders in the event asked:

WEMBLEY, England, June 2 (Reuters) -- Ajax of Amsterdam, the Netherlands, playing fast, attacking soccer, scored a 2-0 victory over Panathinaikos of Athens, Greece, with a goal in each half of the European Cup final tonight.

An investigation of companies in this area that sell future services on a contractual basis, such as correspondence schools, computer-training programs and health clubs, was announced here yesterday by the Federal Trade Commission.

Gulf Western Industries, Inc., increased earnings in the third fiscal quarter by 20.8 per cent and 8.5 pr cent for the nine months ended April 30 ever the corresponding periods a year ago, according to figures issued yesterday by the diversified industrial company. The results were exceeded only by the second highest earnings in 1967 and the record posted in the 1968 periods.
Before the opening of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday morning, analysts were contending that greater volume was necessary for a continuation of the market advance.
Trading yesterday was brisk, as expected, in both the new preferred shares and subscription rights of American Telephone and Telegraph. Both were traded on a "when-issued" basis.
ROME, June 2 -- Italians celebrated today the 25th anniversary of the founding of the republic with a two-hour military parade along the Fori Imperiali here.
ROME, June 2 (UPI) -- Vatican sources said today that Pope Paul would allow local Roman Catholic courts around the world greater freedom to nullify Catholic marriages.

The United States Catholic Conference made public yesterday a set of Vatican guidelines calling for more effective use of the mass media by church spokesmen and a minimum of secrecy in the conduct of church affairs.
In June parents and other relatives of teen-agers think about summer jobs for the children and graduation gifts. There are tax advantages worth remembering in both categories.

JACKSON, Miss., June 2 -- Robert D. Ladner, a relative of Theodore G. Bilbo, an anti - Negro politician of the nineteen-thirties and forties, announced today his candidacy for Governor and said he had asked Charles Evers, a Negro, to run for Lieutenant Governor on his ticket.
Almost 4,000 merchants throughout Brooklyn closed their stores for an hour yesterday morning to protest a one-cent increase in the state sales tax that went into effect on Tuesday.
The Defense Department yesterday put the cost increase for the Navy's F-14 fighter-plane program at about $2-billion.

Robert L. Vesco, chairman of the International Controls Corporation, told shareholders here yesterday that the company would persist in its efforts to obtain a strong position in Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., the ailing offshore mutual fund of which Mr. Vesco is also chairman.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. -- Jenny White got out the candy thermometer and put it in a cup of warm water. She wanted to make sure the water was not merely lukewarm, but as close to 110 degrees as possible. Anyone who has baked bread will have guessed that Jenny was getting ready to activate yeast, which works best at that temperature.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., JUNE 2 -- The sign "HEMPSTEAD PLAZA," advertising a new six-story apartment development, was hammered into place six months ago on the corner of a vacant lot in Hempstead Village. Within a week, the developer, Samuel J. Lefrak, had letters from 700 families wanting to know how to rent one of the $150 to $350 a month apartments.

DENVER, June 2 (AP) -- John M. King and his wife, Carylyn, have asked the courts to protect them from their creditors while they attempt to resolve their financial difficulties. They have filed proceedings under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 2 -- The United States Army has printed during the Vietnam war 6,245,200,000 propaganda leaflets for air drops in Indochina.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 2 -- Charlie Williams pitched his first victory in the major leagues today as the New York Mets defeated the San Francisco Giants for the second time in a row, 5-2.

CARNOUSTIE, Scotland, June 2 (AP) -- Steve Melnyk, a 24-year-old former United States Amateur titleholder, scored an 8-and-6 victory over Andy Wightman of Scotland today in the third round of the British Amateur golf championship.

HARRISBURG, Pa., June 2 (UPI) -- A Baltimore priest today followed the pattern set by his seven co-defendants and refused to respond to charges of plotting to kidnap Henry A. Kissinger, the Presidential adviser, and to raid draft boards in three states.
Three major corporations named senior officers and announced other executive-suite changes yesterday. The principal appointments were the following:

YUBA CITY, Calif., June 2 -- Juan V. Corona, a husky Mexican-American farm labor contractor, pleaded not guilty today to murder charges in connection with the slaying of 23 men whose bodies have been dug from graves in peach orchards outside this city.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, June 3 (AP) -- Responding to a South Vietnamese request, hundreds of United States bombers and helicopter gunships struckt at what were reported to be troops of three enemy divisions in eastern Cambodia yesterday.
"Big Allis," Consolidated Edison's million-kilowatt electric generator at Ravenswood, Queens, went back into service officially at 8 A. M. yesterday after a shutdown for repairs since last July 21.

It is clear that times have changed, but our national holidays have not changed with them. As an example, I suggest that the traditional notice paid to Washington and Lincoln on their respective birthdays is not really in keeping with the sentiments of many people.

The trial of a police lieutenant on charges of conspiring with members of his command over the division of bribes was postponed until July 13 after the Police Department introduced a letter from a neurosurgeon recommending that a key witness not testify for at least another month.
The novel, that hardy perennial whose often predicted demise is predictably premature, is about to flower again under the unlikely aegis of network television.

TEL AVIV, June 2 -- Premier Golda Meir declared tonight that the Soviet Union had virtually acquired the status of "permanent settlers" in the Middle East through the treaty signed in Cairo last week.
The credit markets caught fire yesterday as prices advanced across the board and interest rates dropped sharply.

PARIS, June 2 -- Frank Froehling, who was unable to get past the qualifying round in some tournaments last summer after ending a five-year retirement, upset Arthur Ashe in the quarterfinals of the French open tennis championships today.

ALBANY, June 2 -- Praising the Republican-controlled Legislature for looking "beyond the politics of rent control," Governor Rockefeller today signed one of the thorniest measures debated this session -- a bill to decontrol apartments in New York City as they are voluntarily vacated.

YUBA CITY, Calif., June 2 -- Sheriff Roy Dean Whiteaker sat quietly in his cramped office at the palm-shaded courthouse here and thumbed absently through the stack of unread letters that cluttered his old wooden desk.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 2 -- King Hussein of Jordan today ordered his Government to be firm with the Palestinian commandos, whom he accused of seeking power rather than the liberation of Arab territory occupied by the Israelis.

LONDON, June 2 -- Britain made great headway today in persuading Commonwealth sugar producers to accept assurances from the European Economic Community. A possible obstacle to British entry thus seemed close to disappearing.

ST. LOUIS, June 2 (UPI) -- The Southern Baptist Convention called today for the legalization of abortion in certain cases, including those where there was "carefully ascertained evidence of the likelihood of damage to the emotional, mental and physical health of the mother."
Three major creditors yester- day filed a petition in Federal Court in New York to force the Sheffield Watch Corporation into a state of bankruptcy.
The Allied Chemical Corporation announced yesterday that it had raised prices on all nylon staple fibers for floor coverings, effectively immediately.

Contrary to the general belief created by the great publicity focusing on Edgar Caibett's Canonero II, there will be other horses in the Belmont Stakes on Saturday besides the excellent campaigner from Venezuela.

Last February the New York Stock Exchange appointed William McChesney Martin, former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, to study its rules, structure and operations and to recommend changes. Although Mr. Martin is still several weeks away from completing his study, debate is heating up over the key issues expected to be covered in his report.

La Compania Mexicana de Teatro, composed of nine Mexican film and stage actors, will open a limited engagement tonight at the Greenwich Mews Theater, 141 West 13th Street, in a Spanish language stage presentation of Henry Denker's play, A Far Country."

ALBANY, June 2 -- Trying to break an impasse over the proposed tax package for New York City, Governor Rockefeller made his first overtures today to Democratic legislative leaders in what could be an effort to put together a bipartisan coalition to approve $450-million in city tax authorizations.
TUBINGEN, West Germany -- Even theologians are not born martyrs. Why then should one have written a book he knew would bring him more unpleasantness than gratification?
Two women who allegedly held up a Bronx grocery last night and shot and wounded the elderly owner were taken into custody after a chase.

BONN, June 2 (Reuters) -- Twenty-four well-known West German women -- actresses, journalists, singers, film stars and fashion models -- had their photographs on the front page of Stern news magazine today with the confession, "We have had an abortion."
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- The House Agriculture Committee voted today to allot 62 per cent of United States sugar consumption to domestic producers for the next three years.
VANCOUVER, British Columbia, June 2 -- Bobby Fischer of Los Angeles won his match here with Mark Taimanov of the Soviet Union by taking the sixth game, making his score 6-0.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Administration asked Congress on May 23 to approve a compromise formula to keep Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty operating through a tax-exempt, nonprofit corporation.
The City Commissioner of Correction is not required to provide long-term methadone maintenance programs for heroin addicts in the city's prisons, the State Supreme Court ruled yesterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, June 3 -- The lower house of the South Vietnamese National Assembly today passed a controversial bill on presidential election rules that could leave President Nguyen Van Thieu with no serious challenger in the election next October.
SAN RAFAEL, Calif., June 2 -- Ruchell Magee used his own legal know-how again today to halt the pretrial hearings involving Angela Davis.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (UPI) -- If you're wondering whether that wedding cake is going to pan out for Tricia Nixon and Edward Finch Cox, you'll just have to wait until June 12. The White House reversed itself today and said the recipe would not be tested again in advance.

The city's ailing taxi industry is studying proposals for group riding, the use of credit cards and assignment of special theater district dispatchers as part of a plan to recoup losses and win new riders.
Personality, the 3-year-old champion in 1970 who has been far off form this year, was retired from racing yesterday.

District rent offices in the city's five boroughs will be closed except for emergencies during the next few weeks while the city's rent agency checks rent increases granted since last August, the city announced yesterday.
I want to commend The Times for its article devoted to drug addicts in the armed forces.

Leonard M. Heine Jr. is a husky - voiced investment manager in his middle 40's who made more than $100,000 a year for many years before he came to the conclusion that the little guy wasn't getting a fair shake in Wall Street.

NEW ORLEANS, June 2 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit agreed today to a rehearing by the entire court of its landmark decision directing the town of Shaw, Miss., to equalize public services for blacks and whites.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- New York City's Police Commissioner, Patrick V. Murphy, said today that he had not been invited to a White House meeting scheduled for tomorrow on killings of policemen.
Prenatal diagnosis -- the detection of birth defects at a time when the fetus can still be aborted -- is drastically changing the nature and potential of genetic counseling throughout the country.

On the evening of May 10, 1941, while Germany was preparing to attack Russia, Adolf Hitler's Deputy Fuhrer, Rudolf Hess, took off in a two-engined airplane from an airstrip near Munich, flew across the English Channel, and parachuted into Scotland with an urgent message of peace for the Duke of Hamilton, whom he had reason to believe would be receptive to his overtures.
MOSCOW, June 2 -- Metropolitan Pimen of Krutitsy and Kolomna was elected Patriarch today of the Russian Orthodox Church, the largest and most important religious body in the Soviet Union.

The Op-Ed article in The Times of May 21 by Aron Vergelis paints a pretty picture of Jewish cultural life in the Soviet Union. His most concrete statement is that ". . . writers of Jewish descent, who choose to write in Yiddish, publish numerous books annually."

A 16-year-old girl whose older brother died of a heroin overdose several weeks ago was found dead early yesterday on the steps of a Queens hospital, her head in the lap of a dead male companion. Both, the police said, had apparently died of overdoses of narcotics.

The Pittsburgh Pirates, who never were known for the quality of their pitching, even in old Forbes Field -- where the fences appeared miles away -- suddenly have come up with plenty of good pitching in Three Rivers Stadium, where the park is smaller and the fences closer.
A 63-year-old woman, who was part-owner of a Bronx rooming house, was found dead yesterday in the rooming house with a bullet wound of the body, a rope around her neck and a pillow over her head.

It is quite a sight to watch huge, pontooned rigs, with their jouncing human riders and strapped cargo, riding the roaring waters in "Run the Wild River." And this sight, enlarged on a theater screen in color, is the main diversion of a feature documentary that arrived yesterday at the Kips Bay Theater.

Those who went to hear the Poznan Boys Choir in Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night found themselves listening to the All-Philadelphia Boys Choir during the first third of the program. There was some logic behind this.

PARIS -- Mrs. Lucienne Saint Laurent, mother of the designer, Yves Saint Laurent, says she felt the fashion critics were too harsh on her son's winter showing and that their reaction saddened her. But these days she's been feeling a lot better.

PARIS, June 2 (AP) -- North Vietnam charged today that South Vietnam's offer to free sick and wounded North Vietnamese prisoners was a sham and denounced statements in Saigon that only 13 of 660 prisoners wanted to go home.

The President of France has been assassinated and execution has been re-instituted. But the public executioner, Frechette, alias Monsieur de Paris, has retired into bourgeois anonymity. The mysterious Le Dix, an opportunistic government operative, enters Frechette's house carrying . . . State Supreme Court Justice Michael Kern lashed out at "do-gooders" yesterday, naming specifically Kingman Brewster Jr., the president of Yale University, as he sentenced a convicted murderer to serve 25 years to life in prison.

For the second time in three days, the New York Yankees ended a distinguished pitcher's winning streak when they defeated Sonny Siebert and the Boston Red Sox, 6-1, at Yankee Stadium yesterday.

EPSOM, England, June 2 (Reuters) -- American-bred Mill Reef, owned by Paul Mellon of Pittsburgh and New York, surged out of the pack in the final furlong today to win the 192d Epsom Derby, England's major flat-racing classic for 3-year-olds.
WARSAW, June 2 -- West Germany has told Poland that Radio Free Europe's broadcasting license has been renewed automatically until July, 1972.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- A Government witness picked out a policewoman, not Heidi Ann Fletcher, in a line-up held today to determine the identification of a young woman who may have participated in a holdup that ended with a policeman shot to death, The Washington Post reported.
MOSCOW, June 2 -- The Soviet Union today sharply criticized recent efforts by the United States to promote a Middle East settlement and to improve relations with Egypt.
Metals futures, with the exception of platinum, continued to drop yesterday.

Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner and his wife were divorced yesterday. Mrs. Barbara Cavanagh Wagner obtained an uncontested degree on grounds of abandonment. Terms of a financial settlement were not made public.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Assistant Secretary of the Treasury Murray L. Weidenbaum, a principal architect of President Nixon's revenue-sharing plan, says the Administration now is "open-minded" about the details of the program. This bid for a compromise was echoed by other Republican spokesmen, but it is not yet clear how far they will be willing to go.

CLEVELAND, June 2 (AP) -- United States District Judge James C. Connell dismissed today suits amounting to at least $11-million filed by parents of three Kent State University students slain in a May 4, 1970, campus disturbance.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Nixon Administration, in the person of Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally Jr., formally presented its general revenue-sharing program to Congress today and ran into criticism from every point on the political compass.

The Borg-Warner Corporation announced yesterday the opening of a large plant in Japan to produce automatic transmissions for cars and trucks in a joint venture with the Toyoto Motors Group affiliate, the Aisin-Seiki Company, Ltd.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- A group of prominent lawyers announced plans today to lobby in Congress next week for passage of legislation that would end American involvement in Vietnam by the end of the year.

He was protesting what the opposition viewed as an effort to push through a provision limiting the number of presidential candidates.

In moves to help meet serious financial problems, American Airlines, Inc., yesterday announced plans for selling 3.3 million shares of common stock, while Pan American World Airways, Inc., announced a major reorganization of its staff just below the office of the president and chief executive officer, the 55-year-old Najeeb E. Halaby.

The New York chapter of the Japanese-American Citizens League sued in State Supreme Court yesterday to bar a designer of women's clothing and the product's world marketing agent from using the word "Jap" as a trademark.

The most recent Gallup Poll indicates that if the 1972 Presidential election were held now, three prominent Democrats -- Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Senator Hubert H. Humphrey and Senator Edward M. Kennedy -- would each run a very close race against President Nixon.

Columbia Gas System, Inc., announced yesterday in Wilmmerton, Del., the election of John W. Partridge as chairman and chief executive officer of the nation's largest natural gas system. Mr. Partridge, formerly vice chairman, succeeds Ceck E. Loomis who retired May 31.

CAEN, France, June 3 (AP) -Paul Leboucher, Mayor of the Normandy village of Landes-sur-Ajon, was found hanged today, and beside his body was a note saying, "I'm joining the Mayor of Sallen." The Mayor of Sallen, Rene Auvray, took his life Monday after 13 persons died when the floor of a village hall collapsed.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- George McGovern's campaign for the Presidency seems to be picking up a little speed. Or maybe Ed Muskie's is merely slowing down. But in any event, the Senator from South Dakota is clearly going to influence his party in the coming months, even if he is not chosen to lead it in 1972.

ST. LOUIS, June 3 -- The Southern Baptist Convention -- the largest Protestant denomination in America, with 11.6 million members -- ended its three-day annual meeting here today after stanchly upholding its traditional conservatism.

LONDON, June 3 -- In the two and a half year since the announcement of the Covent Garden Draft Plan, opposition to the redevelopment project for central London's famous market and theater district has been increasing.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- James R. Hoffa announced from prison today that he would not stand for re-election as president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

Erin Martin, a dancer best known for her guest appearances as the bride in American Ballet Theater's production of Jerome Robbins's "Les Noces," presented three works with a company of five other dancers Wednesday night at the American Theater Laboratory, 219 West 19th Street.

Thirty-two representatives of tenant organizations summoned to City Hall by Benjamin Altman, the Commissioner of Rent and Housing Maintenance, agreed yesterday to form a "watchdog" committee to protect tenants against harassment by landlords.

SEOUL, South Korea, June 3 -- President Chung Hee Park appointed Kim Chong Pil, vice president of the governing Democratic Republican party, to replace Paik Too Chin as Premier in an abrupt Cabinet change today.

ALBANY, June 3 -- Democratic members of the Senate touched off a long parliamentary wrangle today when they charged they had been given a bad count on a measure they espoused, but when they were given a recount they still lost.

MANILA, June 2 -- The Asian nations lying south of China regard its more friendly attitude toward the non-Communist world with hopefulness tempered by suspicion.

The trans-Atlantic airline price war expanded yesterday as Air France said that it would introduce a new $200 round-trip fare between the United States and Paris for any travelers between 15 and 26 years of age. The fare will be $220 during three brief peak travel periods.

Secretary of Labor James D. Hodgson said yesterday that the Nixon Administration had no intention at this time of intervening in the current steel or copper negotiations despite the wage and price increases earlier this week in the aluminum industry.

Increased consumer buying in May, peaking in strong Mother's Day gift purchasing, gave five of the country's large retail chains one of the best months of 1971.

James R. Hoffa has done the giant International Brotherhood of Teamsters a service by taking himself out of consideration for re-election to the union presidency next month. It would have been an affront to the nation if its biggest and strongest union had voted back into office a convict with nine years still to serve for jury-fixing and pension fraud.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The A.F.L.-C.I.O. called today for an increase in the minimum wage to $2 an hour "immediately, without delay," but the prospect for any Congressional action effective before 1972 appeared dim.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 3 -- Secretary General Thant reiterated today in strongly personal terms his intention to retire at the end of the year, when his second five-year term expires.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 3 -- In the South Vietnamese Presidential election of 1967, there were 11 candidates, and Nguyen Van Thieu won with only 35 per cent of the vote. In the election on Oct. 3, it appears, the President may have only one opponent, or may even run unopposed, under bill passed today by the lower house of the South Vietnamese National Assembly.

CHICAGO, June 4 -- A black economics professor said today that if the Federal Government and industry failed to help with the business development of predominantly black ghettos and rural areas then blacks would seek aid from Japan, the World Bank, the United Nations or the Soviet Union.

ALBANY, June 4 -- Democrats and Republicans in the State Assembly, continuing their fractious, time-consuming outbursts of recent weeks, could not even agree today on an adjournment date for this prolonged and exhausting session.

The United States moved today to intervene on the side of the New York Police Department in a court case in which the department is a defendant against complaints by apartment building owners and tenants in the area around the Soviet Mission on East 67th Street.

TOKYO, June 4 -- Premier Eisaku Sato today opened a three-week election campaign for the upper house with an appeal to the electorate to "show warm understanding" for Japan's foreign aid program, which amounted to $1.8-billion last year.

Mayor Lindsay's cabinet gave him a one-minute standing ovation yesterday morning after an emotional speech in which Corporation Counsel J. Lee Rankin praised the Mayor's behavior in the budget battle with Governor Rockefeller.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- United States narcotics agents and Spanish police seized 249 pounds of heroin in Valencia, Spain, last night, Attorney General John N. Mitchell announced today.

ALBANY, June 4 -- The State Legislature, which two months ago approved an austerity budget that resulted in the dismissal of hundreds of state employes and sharp cutbacks in welfare and other services, is planning to increase the expense allowance of each of its members this year by $2,000.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, June 4 (UPI) -- Nationalist China and the United States are hopelessly deadlocked over talks on Taiwan's textile exports to America after four days of meetings, informed sources said today.

HARTFORD, June 4 -- Negotiations between Connecticut's Republican Governor and the leaders of the Democratic-controlled General Assembly broke off early today after it had appeared virtually certain last night that agreement would be reached on a state income tax.

Hanoi's callous rejection of thirteen sick and wounded North Vietnamese prisoners of war represents the final breakdown of a major American-South Vietnamese prisoner repatriation effort that never had much chance of success.
TRENTON, June 4 -- New Jersey's recent attempts to protect its wetlands were praised today by a Federal official as he surveyed the coastal area from an airplane.
"He eats 'em up alive," Savino Ferraro declared flatly yesterday at Grand Central Terminal. "He don't quit, this horse. He's got plenty of reserve."
PARIS, June 4 -- After balking like a child before important company yesterday, the Concorde performed like an angel today.
LONDON, June 4 -- British relief organizations acted urgently today to get anticholera vaccine to India, where an epidemic has broken out among refugees from East Pakistan.
PEKING, June 3 -- On the streets of this capital as well as in rural villages, bricks are piled high and dust rises as a massive program of building air-raid shelters goes forward.

The Florida Power Light Company has named Marshall McDonald president, succeeding R. C. Fullerton who remains chairman and chief executive officer. Mr. McDonald was formerly head of a subsidiary of Union Oil of California. He was also made a director. H. W. Page was elected a vice president.

William F. Buckley Jr., the conservative editor and columnist, has offered to take custody of Edgar H. Smith Jr., who has spent 14 years on Death Row in Trenton State Prison. Smith's conviction for murder was overturned last month, and Mr. Buckley would take custody of him if he were released, pending appeals or the start of a new trial.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Dr. Arthur W. Galston, professor of biology at Yale University, said today that he had been asked by Premier Chou En-lai during an affable two-hour interview recently for any suggestions or criticisms he might care to offer.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, June 4 -- As the dairy farmer displayed a new concrete pen where 16 cows will be milked simultaneously, he said that Britain's entry into the European Economic Community would not bother him. "I'll just stay here on the farm and raise beef and maize," he added.

The May 10 news analysis article, "Legisdemain in Albany," does a profound disservice to the beleaguered but determined Democratic leadership in Albany. The implication in that analysis that our Democratic leadership contributes in some manner to tight Republican control in Albany is simply not in accord with reality.

In the aftermath of the killing of two patrolmen last month in an upper Harlem city housing project, Mayor Lindsay yesterday ordered a study of ways to improve cooperation and communication between the city police and housing project patrolmen.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Three dissenting Justices chided the Supreme Court majority today for handing down an "11th hour" decree yesterday ordering Hinds County, Miss., to be divided into single-member legislative districts by June 14.

Two more young residents of the Sunnyside section of Queens were reported dead yesterday of apparent overdoses of narcotics.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The nation and the Nixon Administration received moderately discouraging news today on the inflation-unemployment front.

A Queens Supreme Court Justice yesterday dismissed a suit brought by two Queens College seniors who charged that the police and college authorities failed to crack down on narcotics sales and crimes of violence on the campus.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 4 -- When Jim Pearson came home from Vietnam five years ago with several medals pinned to his paratrooper's tunic, he was in no great hurry to go to work.

The City Councilman who heads the Queens Democratic organization threatened yesterday to destroy another Queens Councilman politically in a dispute over the election of a new Councilman from the borough.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Chairman Wright Patman of the House Banking Committee disclosed today some details of the bank reform legislation that is likely to emerge from his committee.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 4 -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit has ruled that state laws permitting sex discrimination in employment have been invalidated by the Civil Rights Act of 1964. It was the first such ruling by a Federal appellate court.
Thousands of subway riders had to look for other transportation last night when a water main break at Broadway and 72d Street knocked out West Side IRT subway service

LISBON, June 4 -- The North Atlantic Treaty Organization decided today to seek exploratory talks with the Soviet Union and its Warsaw Pact allies on "mutual and balanced force reductions" in Central Europe.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- Air samples taken seven years apart in three big cities show sharp increases in lead concentrations, according to a report released today by the Environmental Protection Agency.

BOSTON, June 4 -- New England lobster men, in an effort to stake out a deep-sea fishing claim, have become involved in an international confrontation that threatens their work in the rich lobster beds of the Continental Shelf.
TOKYO, June 4 (UPI) -- The Textile Federation will voluntarily reduce shipments of man-made cloth to the United States effective July 1 despite President Nixon's rejection of the Japanese plan.

PARIS, June 4 -- In the peace and quiet of center court with fewer than 2,000 spectators to disconcert her; Helen Gourlay thought her way to the women's final of the French Open tennis tournament today.

OTTAWA, June 4 (AP) -- The Prices and Incomes Commission criticized today four major oil companies -- Imperial Oil, Ltd.; Shell Canada, Ltd.; Texaco Canada, Ltd., and the Sun Oil Company, Ltd. -- for refusing to take "remedial action" after, it charged, they increased their prices unduly last year.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- Scientists told Congressional investigators today of a new group of drugs that they said might mark "an important medical breakthrough" toward solving the heroin problem in the United States and in South Vietnam.

The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company announced yesterday that it would raise prices on replacement automobile tires by about 3.5 per cent and on conventional truck tires by 2.75 per cent to 3.5 per cent, effective July 1.

Like a housewife in a flurry of dusting before the guests arrive, the city is smoothing out the last sandy wrinkles of its 17 miles of municipal beaches for what the weatherman says will be the first good beach weekend of the year.
MOSCOW, June 4 -- William E. Schuyler Jr., the United States Commissioner of Patents, voiced optimism today on the prospects of licensing American inventions in the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- President Nixon announced today a broad, long-range program designed to assure the nation of "an adequate supply of clean energy in the years ahead."

The Belmont Stakes, often classified by cynical commentators in the past as the "best kept secret in town," takes rank on its 103d running today as one of the most popular and widely followed sports spectacles of the year.
TOKYO, June 4 (AP) -- The Nippon Steel Corporation said today that it planned to increase export prices for all of its steel products by about $10 a metric ton, or about 6 per cent, in mid-June.

The Friendly Ice Cream Corporation, which operates a chain of ice cream and sandwich shops in New York, New England, and New Jersey, reported yesterday record sales and earnings for the fiscal year ended April 24.
DETROIT, June 4 (AP) -- Domestic auto production dropped off this week because of the closing of almost all industry plants for the Memorial Day holiday.

BOMBAY, India, June 1 -- A team of Indian players, whose enthusiasm and occasional individual brilliance could not compensate for their lack of serious match experience, was crushed here last night by the international Precision touring team.

JERUSALEM -- Four years have passed since the outbreak of the Six-Day War. There are some people who maintain that Israel's situation has never been better. After so long a period, the Israel defense forces are stationed along the Suez Canal and the river Jordan, and the Arab armies, whether united or singly, are not capable of loosing their hold.

Hard on the heels of Paul Anka's appearance at the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, another relict of the pre-Beatles set of popular teen-age idols, Frankie Avalon, has turned up at the Rainbow Grill.

WACO, Ga., June 4 (UPI) -- A trailer truck carrying 10,000 pounds of dynamite collided with an automobile on a busy highway tonight and blew up, killing at least five persons and caving in the roof of a nearby school gymnasium where 200 persons were holding a gospel singing.

LONDON, June 4 -- The contemporary critics of our society often speak of its "hyprocrisy." It is a charge naturally resented by the society's leaders, for with few exceptions they feel perfectly sincere in what they do.

That startling statistic on the high cost to taxpayers of old-age protection for state and city employes comes from Dr. Thomas Norman Hurd, Director of State Operations.
LOS ANGELES, June 4 -- The New York Mets continued to make waves along the West Coast tonight when Tom Seaver pitched them to a 3-1 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

Despite lower volume, stocks on the American Stock Exchange included ahead yesterday .The index closed at 26.07, u:p 0.05 from the preceding, on volume totaling only 3,908,690 shares, compared with 5,183,000 shares on Thursday.

BONN, June 4 -- For the second consecutive day West Germany's central bank sold an estimated total of $100-million at prices that were tantamount to a 3.5 per cent upward revaluation of the mark from its official parity of 3.66 to the dollar.
YUBA CITY, Calif., June 4 (AP) -- Another transient farm worker's body was found today -- the 25th recovered by sheriff's deputies from fruit orchards lining the Feather River near Yuba City.
LISBON, June 4 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of the final communique issued by the Foreign Ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization here today:
The State Legislature cleared the way yesterday for a basic overhaul of the banking structure in New York.
ATLANTA, June 4 -- Jack Nicklaus drew even today with yesterday's youthful pacesetter, John Miller, to share the 36-hole lead by one stroke in the $125,000 Atlanta Golf Classic at 135.

NAIROBI, Kenya, June 4 -- A public prosecutor said today that 12 men who have pleaded guilty to charges of conspiring to overthrow the Government had tried to enlist the support of Julius K. Nyerere, President of the neighboring nation of Tanzania, but had been rebuffed.
The Kansas City Royals, with a new look and a new attitude, added another highlight last night to what is already a most successful season in their three-year history.

A Federal Appeals Court in Boston reversed yesterday a lower-court decision in a mutual fund case of major significance, ruling a management company guilty of "gross misconduct" in not obtaining refunds on commissions paid by a fund it sponsors.
ALBANY, June 4 -- Governor Rockefeller late tonight vetoed a bill that would have barred construction of a bridge that has been proposed across Long Island Sound from Oyster Bay, L. I., to Rye, N. Y.
The Salvation Army's latest stage musical, "Hosea," first staged in London last year, will be seen in two performances here with an American cast and chorus of 60 young soldiers and lassies.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The Senate virtually assured today the continuance of the military draft through the middle of 1973.

DANANG, South Vietnam, June 4 -- Thirteen disabled North Vietnamese prisoners, described as saddened and bewildered by the last-minute refusal of Hanoi to take them back, returned here today after a 24-hour sea journey to nowhere.

Six series of symphonic concerts, including the International Festival of Visiting Orchestras, will be presented during the 1971-72 season by Carnegie Hall, which will be observing its 80th anniversary year.
